The restroom ceiling was literally falling down.7. The tile grout was stained black and when we turned on the pipe to take a shower, a long snake-like bug came out the pipe. We called the staff to catch it and remove it, then we asked for our money back and went to the Wyndham near the airport instead. I would NEVER stay here again!! Yuck! They should be ashamed of this establishment!!This place is downright horrible. The pictures online while i was making a reservation were deceiving. The entrance was very dirty. The elevator looked disgusting, like it wasn't cleaned since installed. The beds were the only things tht looked ok and the non smoke room stank of smoke and mildew. I probably will never stay at an American best value inn, ever. This experience ruined the whole chain for me.Old TV, soft beds, tiny closet, big bathroom, no fridge or microwave. It wasn't bad if your primary purpose for staying is to sleep. Otherwise the single I was in was very cramp without much. The biggest free space was the bathroom.Had the unfortunate experience of staying here one night when our AC broke. For $50 I got a 20 year old 20" tv that made me wonder what I was paying for. I think the best part was the HBO lineup info next to the ancient artifact tv and an imprint that looked like maybe at one point there was a flat screen in there on the wall instead. It seems they do not have the money to put the work into it and unfortunately that makes it difficult to ever make the choice to stay there again. I said it is moderately priced because motel 8 would be cheaper.This place doesn't even deserve a star. This is the worst hotel I have ever stayed at. We decided to stay here because it was cheap and close. Once we checked in, the lady behind the desk was really friendly, but misleading. She told us that our room had a brand new, updated flat screen tv. But, it had a very old 32'' tv. We were only in our room for abt 5 mins, when we were told that we had to move to another room because someone else had already reserved it. (strike 1). So, in our new room, I decied to take a bath. Before i ran the water, I noticed that the molding around the tub wasn't all the way dry. So once water entered the tub, it leaked all the way to the first floor. So we had to switch rooms again. (strike 2). Then we got another room down the hall, which seemed much smaller. Everything was basically pushed together. So to add on to my anger with this hotel, the air did not work and the tv only got 3 channels. I called down to the front desk and the maintence man told me that the tv will work eventually; but it never did. It seemed like my whole night was ruined and I just couldnt wait til the am to check out. I could honestly say the only good thing abt this hotel was the pizza hut across the street.

This place is like an undercover shitty hotel. Everything is super fancy and the prices of everything in it is kind of outrageous for a place that doesn't even offer a refrigerator or microwave in the hotel room. Everything outside of the room however is really nice, such as the pool/workout area and the ballrooms.WORST HOTEL EVER!Want half the listed amenities, scowling, unhappy and incompetent staff with no discount?Look no further! The management doesn't know what works or doesn't in the hotel, they make promises they DONT keep. They have the nerve to accuse guests without confirming accusations and will try to charge extra to your room.  The pool is ice cold, hot tub and sauna broken with no fix date in site.  Staff complain out loud to themselves whilst completing their duties.Worst vacation EVER.   Do yourself a favor and don't go here.  Hotel smelled of illegal substances, breakfast waitress took our money then told us we didn't pay!! Paid for late checkout and was locked out of room.  I could go on but it upsets me and I think you get the point. Avoid at all costs. New management has ruined this place.Please please please reconsider reserving a room at this hotel. The entrance or lobby area is totally misleading...the beautiful Palm trees, the elevator, and the ample space gives the impression that this hotel just may be a 4 star facility...let me provide an analogy that best describes this place...it's a cheap bottle of beer dressed up as champaign (miller lite/Cristal). You can fool me with the bottling but I get it!!!! So yeah I got a taste of the Royal blah...and I totally know what this is after the experience. It's a dressed up motel charging 4star hotel prices. We paid 145 dollars plus the 50 dollar hold for incidentals. Save the $$$$ and get a room at a Days Inn. As I write this review I'm praying that there are no critters beneath me.After reading a few other reviews on other sites, I have to agree that the lobby is WAY nicer than the actual room.  There aren't refrigerators, despite what you might read on websites; however you can rent one for 10.00 a day (gouging).  There isn't a microwave either.  If you want coffee in the middle of the night, too bad; they do not have coffee to offer late nighters.  But if you want sugary lemonade then it is in abundance.  It is very difficult to sleep here when it seems like you're sleeping in the mezzanine, since you can hear every conversation going on outside your door, and people are a bit inconsiderate when you hear children running and screaming right outside your door as well.  From first impressions you'd think this place is super nice, but once you settle in you kind of realize that it isn't as great as you'd thought.  The pool is ok, but the spa wasn't working and I didn't even get to relax in a hot tub at all.  The front desk staff kind of acts irritated that they have a guest.  I stayed in a Days Inn just a few days prior to staying here, and it was actually better in a lot of ways, and much much cheaper. The experience of staying here isn't the worst, but next time I will opt for somewhere different and a lot less expensive.  Not even a free breakfast, Geesh!I stayed here for two days. It was a great price for a clean hotel room. We slept well and the hotel restaurant was greatI would give this place a 4.5 stars if i could but the friendliness of the hotel staff tipped me over. Stayed here with my family for 2 nights and it was great. When we checked in Kimberly at the front desk was friendly and helpful. Then about 10 min after we got to our room she called our room and asked if everything was ok...talk about customer service. The rooms was clean and big, but didn't have a mini-bar or fridge. The restaurant Giulio & Sons on the 2nd floor is worth eating at. Another plus was that our room faced the Henry Ford Museum so we got to catch 4th of Julu fireworks show! The only real "negative" for out-of-towers is its location. Aside from the Henry Ford compound and a mall you're not too close to any means of transportation or anything else.

The 'Crest! Definitely not a luxury hotel, but it's a Detroit mainstay. Extremely convenient during DEMF weekend. The people that work there are firm with you, but ultimately nice. One thing that may annoy some people is the old cigarette smoke smell in many of the rooms. Be sure to be clear with them that you want a non-smoking room when you reserve. And I can't forget The Clique! Cheap, greasy and probably one of the best breakfasts in The D.Ended up here booking a "3-star" hotel on Hotwire. This place is a 2-star at best.The location is excellent, a block from the bike rental place on the Riverwalk and a short walk to everything downtown. The Clique restaurant in the hotel rules.I'm really, really, not picky. I love simple, basic motels, and never really do much more than sleep and shower in them. However, the deeply ingrained scent of smoke was terrible, and a dealbreaker. The only other place I've experienced anything like this was also in Detroit, at the Corktown Inn. There were no insulated cups to go with the coffee maker, and initially no full-sized towels in the room to boot.For the hell of it, I called Shorecrest the morning of the big Jimmy Buffet concert this past July, and shockingly, they had two rooms available (recent cancellations) so I took them, both!  One slept 6, the other 8...haha...  Both under $100.  Definitely sketchy rooms, old smoke smells, but seriously right downtown!!  Cab rides were less than $10..  I would stay here again, in a pinch, or to save a buck due to it's fantastic location.  I'm not sure I'd hang out at the room, or party...but it was fine for what we needed it to be, a place to crash, and park our cars.....why bother with the other BS when you can just stay here...  DO IT!!  :-)You don't really go to the Shorecrest for luxury - you go there because of the ambiance.  I've been staying at this spot for the last 5+ years, religiously, when I am in town for the Detroit Electronic Music Festival (or whatever it is called from year to year).  Despite all the hassle they have to deal with from rowdy out-of-towner electronic music aficionados, the staff at the Shorecrest is incredibly kind and patient.  It brings a smile to my face every year when I make the usual call to reserve rooms and the woman at the front desk asks me if I want to book for my brother as well; yes, she remembers us every time.  I have much love for this spot, but I wouldn't recommend it if you're looking for somewhere more upscale.  It's a decent (and safe) walk from all the festivities in Hart Plaza and the rest of downtown Detroit.  There is a cafe inside called The Clique, which is decent, but we usually prefer to drive down the road a bit to the Motown Cafe and Grill.Rates are stupidly cheap, but they tend to jack them up for DEMF weekend - be warned to book far in advance as the rooms fill very quickly.It's the place to be when your attending DEMF (Detroit Music Festival). It's cheap, our bathroom tub was huge for all thos late night sex parties, and the diner below serves up some midwest breakfasts. All the cabbies know where it is when you need that 5 am ride home from The Works or need to get picked up to go to Old Miami at 7 am. It's sleazy, easy, and to the point. Hopefully you won't get stuck next to the tweeker guy we did last time. He was more cracked out than half of San Francisco. The ladies at the front desk are there every year and it's only thirty bucks more to stay and sleep that extra late afternoon on Monday when your finally coming down. Unlimited towels and a few block walk to the festival. You can even get a forty and chicken wigs two blocks the oppposite way of the festival. It's worth the walk to get booze to drink on the way. The 9 dollar Labbats beers at the festival suck. Get drunk at the hotel first. Reserve early for the festival. This hidden gem sells out fast!We were in the motor City for 2 nights and stayed at this property . It is a family run operation . Check in and out were quick . The property is older but clean and within walking distance to Ford Field, Comerica Pk, Cobo Hall ect . THe room could use a makeover but as indicated was clean with fridge,air condt, and not far from the room a well stocked ice machine . Staff always had a smile and were able to give directions . THey have a diner style restaurant on the main floor that serves up great food and a good value . Yes We would stay at this property again.

When I visit Windsor this is my hotel of choice. The rooms are always clean, the staff is always courteous.Plenty of parking, even for people towing boats on vacation.It's on a busy road that leads to the bridge and an outlet mall is just down the road. They have safety deposit boxes at no charge.I have never had a bad experience hereI highly recommend this hotelThis Holiday Inn is located close to the Ambassador Bridge and downtown Windsor, Canada. The staff was very polite and the front desk very helpful. The hotel was well maintained and the rooms are clean. The front desk area is large and the first floor also accommodates a bar and a restaurant.Pretty average all around. The value was great and the staff were very friendly, but the rooms are a bit old and it's very loud if people are in the hallways. Plus, the door didn't seal real well, so plenty of light came through at night from all 4 sides like it was the door to heaven, like in the movies. Good location though and very fairly priced. I would definitely stay here again when in Windsor.My wife and I stayed at this hotel a couple of times while on a small getaway and both times we enjoyed our stay. This hotel isn't in prime downtown location. It is situated about 7 minutes from downtown but is close to a lot of different restaurants and shops. For the price and service, I would definitely recommend this to anyone. This is a clean hotel. The service is always friendly and helpful. I have never had any issues with the staff or the cleanliness of our room. Great hotel!!I stopped by here on my way to Chicago and stayed for one night.  I didn't get to check out the amenities, but the friendly front desk made my late check in at 11pm a breeze.   The bathroom fan was pretty useless because the mirrors were foggy long after the shower was turned off.  The hotel includes free wifi, but it was too slow to stream YouTube videos.The hotel itself is located along the main road leading to the bridge between Canada and the U.S., which was very convenient if you're passing through.  If I was passing through here again, I'd come back to this Holiday Inn.Didn't stay at the hotel, but ate at the 24 hour restaurant that is attached to it. Don't know what time it was, but the food hit the spot. I had a chicken club sandwich I think with fries. Sandwich was pretty good from what I remember. Have no idea about prices. I actually don't recall who paid the bill. I do remember we were the only ones in the place though.

When this place was being built it was an eye-catching sight. A raspberry and cream Victorian dream gleaming on the Detroit skyline. I never had a reason to try it because I live too close, but a gift certificate changed that. The place is located near a storage unit in an industrial park and is a stone's throw to Fairlane Green, a shopping center with anything you could want that you forgot to pack. Nearby is the Henry Ford, Michigan's premier attraction. The interior sticks to the pink trend. It's kind of an Eighties Victorian theme with lots of old car ads lining the walls. The rooms are worn but well-appointed for the business traveler. Irons, Keurigs, mini fridge, etc. We had Room 122 and that one is close to everything-the pool, the lobby, and the restaurant.There's a business center and a small arcade. And a bar in house. The restaurant, O'Henry's, elevates this place to four stars. The breakfast was wonderful!Don't bother with this place. The service is TERRIBLE!!!! Stayed here a few times but over Christmas was the worst. The room card key reader failed so maintenance was called to change the battery. We left for the day but when we returned at 11 pm, the room door was ajar and all our stuff was gone from the room. No call, no note, no nothing!!! We called the front desk and they knew nothing about except to tell us there was a bunch of stuff in the office. We went down to the front desk only to find all our stuff on a dirty luggage cart in an insecure room off the lobby. My wife's personal items were put in a plastic bag, our clothes were draped on the rack and my CPAP machine was sitting directly on the dirty cart! GROSS!!!! The clerk knew nothing about it and they had to put us in a new room. When I asked for the GM the next morning, I was told he would not call me but I should try to call him on Monday. Seriously???? The place is very trashy and dirty. The rugs were soiled, there were ladders outside so the anyone could break into a window and it was gross. You would be better off staying in your call. Don't let the cute exterior fool you. It is a horrible place!!!It's a bit noisy at this time, and the building is old. Apart from that everything is good. It is worth the money you pay, and is clean. I recommend it.New management and boy was it great! What an amazing experience! I definitely recommend this restaurant. The hotel and restaurant experience overall was so pleasant that I can't wait to come back. The helpfulness, cleanliness and delicious food are all reasons that I'll be back! Oh, and the fact that it's pretty and pink! Overall great experience.We were in Dearborn visiting the Henry Ford museum and Greenfield Village. Nice hotel somewhat dated but still very clean, staff was very nice and helpful, room had a microwave, mini fridge and my girlfriend was excited to see a Keurig machine in the room. I'm 6'2, and had to bend over to use the shower, that's my only complaint. We used hotels.com to book this room, it's located in a semi-industrial area, but very quiet. I was somewhat concerned that they lock all the gates to the parking lot after dark, except the one by the main entrance, obviously they've had issues with non guests in the parking lot, and this additional security is warranted, we were there 3 nights, Thursday, Friday and Saturday, and it was quiet and our car was fine in the well lighted parking lot. I'm usually skeptical about restaurants that are attached to hotels but this one is a pleasant surprise, I wish we had gone earlier they had an excellent breakfast of great value, large serving and quite tasty.Very nice rooms. Good rate. Friendly and helpful staff. Had breakfast at restaurant on site and it was good.Time for my first vacation of the year, so I check out Expedia.com. I found this one online. I just couldn't say no. It's big and it's pink and it could be had for just $96/night. So, I bought 3 nights.....It's looks like a Victorian Mansion on the outside and well, on the inside too. Cool antiques all around. Looks like you are walking into a real 1890's hotel. This has everything I look for in a hotel. To make it easy, let me just make a list for you:Great staffPleasant looking hotelClean inside and outNice reasonably priced full service restaurant on site - O'Henry'sNice Pub / Lounge too - Squire's PubMicrowave Oven in roomRefrigerator in room Big Screen TVCold ACComfortable bedsPretty quite at night.No sketchy people to be seenNice inside courtyard with a gazeboPerfect location if you are going downtown or to the Henry Ford / Greenfield VillagePlus they gave me a discount coupon for 20% off my next visit. Guess where I'll be staying next time?My boyfriend and I stayed at the Best Western Greenfield Inn for two nights while attending a music festival in downtown Detroit. We selected this hotel because it fit our budget while offering a safer locale than the cheaper Detroit hotels. We were on the whole pleased with our stay: our room was comfortable and well-appointed, and the location made it easy to get in/out without having to deal with parking, sketchy neighborhoods, or a border crossing, as would have been the case at comparably priced hotels nearby. My only disappointment was the sauna, which was barely warmer than room temperature.Oh yeah, and it's pink. Really, really pink.We, my wife and two daughters (14 & 11) stayed one night this past weekend after attending the Christmas event at Greenfield Village. It had poured rain that night and we were all looking forward to a quick dip in the pool and soak in the hot tub. We arrived at 9:30 PM and upon check-in am advised that kids under the age of 21 (!) are not allowed in the pool after 9:00 PM. The hotel was near empty no one in the pool area when we went by, and they were not willing to flex. Also, we discovered that the fitness room as not open to anyone under the age of 18. Strange rules. For the business traveller I would also caution that there aren't any proper workstations in the rooms either. Just a table that's too high to work at your laptop from. They tout themselves as offering a "Victorian elegance" experience. They are in such bad need of serious renovations that I would describe it as "fleabag Victorian". There was nothing elegant about this hotel and I would venture that Queen Victoria herself would not be amused!They haven't got a clue. Not staying here again.We stayed here due to an impending ice storm on the night we had tickets to Holiday nights at Greenfield Village. We got a great price on Hotwire and were pleased with the king room. There is a mini fridge, small microwave and keurig in each room. The bed was comfortable, the flat screen was nicely sized for the room. The bed was not amazing but comfortable enough with a large selection of pillows. The drapes closed tightly to keep the light out very well and the room was fairly quiet. For the price and proximity to The Henry Ford and Greenfield Village, I think it is likely we will stay here again.I recently stayed in the Executive Lafayette Suite (room 400) and it was glorious. The suite was incredible and completely worth the money. The bar was comfortable and friendly. They make a mean Manhattan with dried Michigan cherries. I scheduled a massage for my companion and she loved it. She frequently gets massages and said that it was fantastic. The pool and workout area was perfect. I personally appreciated the adult only hour that the pool had. A few laps with no kids around was just what the doctor ordered. The staff was professional and polite. Just up the road is a huge mall (Fairlane Green) with a Target, tons of restaurants and a thousand stores. I would suggest anyone stay there.Pink. Perfect. Prime location. Rooms are great with huge televisions. Extremely cleanFriendly staff.Great food. Good bar.What more could you want.I was recently treated to a stay at this hotel in the Lafayette suite. Oh my! I can't say enough positive about it. The suite itself was really more of a two bedroom/ two bathroom apartment. It had a full kitchen with a full sized fridge, triple sink with garbage disposal, dishwasher, a microwave, a Keurig, stove, and oven. Complete with dishes! There was a dining room with seating for six. The master bedroom had a wonderfully comfortable king sized bed with a ton of soft pillows and two built in vanities. The main bath had a good sized soaker tub and the Jacuzzi tub was in the master bath. And my favorite part... I was able to bring my Australian Shepard with us. The pool was wonderful (I really appreciated that there was an hour of adult only time). It was nice to be able to relax without a bunch of kids around. The workout room was better than I expected with a good selection of equipment. I'll absolutely be returning.I just left this place a few hours ago after staying overnight. One weekend a month my boyfriend and I try and find just a really basic and clean hotel to stay the night in to get away from our families. Neither one of us make enough money to live on our own yet, so one night a month we splurge halfsies on a room.Our requirements are simple. Internet and TV. When we're together all we want to do is watch Netflix movies and TV shows. We ended up paying close to $100 for a room which was a little out of our budget. We chose it because from the outside it looked like it was really well kept. The rooms, lobby, and hallways were very clean looking so we felt as though we picked well. Unfortunately, everything we picked it for failed us.Our game plan was to watch Arrested Development off Netflix until The Walking Dead was on AMC. Then we'd watch another episode or two before going to bed. In theory, great idea, but neither one of those things happened.The internet in the hotel is awful. We had a connection that was 1/5 bars, if that, and kept cutting out and failing. We complained to the desk. The attendant behind the desk admitted that people complained all the time that the internet didn't work, and their receiver boxes always broke, were really cheap, and never worked right. I asked if they had any other ones to use. Come to find out when I took their extra ones back to the room that none of them would work. Why? Because their connection came through a telephone line, and their newer receivers were obviously made for cable modems and needed Ethernet cords. Neither of which the room was equipped for. Sadly, our Netflix movie watching night was lost.We thought we were okay because we had decent cable and the list of channels listed AMC as one of them. We flipped through and noticed only channel 20, AMC, DIDN'T WORK! We went down to the front desk AGAIN only to find out that they changed cable providers and we were the 6th group of people to complain about not getting AMC. I felt a little better we weren't the only Walking Dead fans that were dying a little on the inside. Sadly, the two things the boyfriend and I were looking forward to left us disappointed. We didn't have a working internet, nor full cable. We were really upset here we were paying almost $100 a night for two MAJOR amenities to not work.When I politely complained saying that I felt we shouldn't be paying the full amount for these two major things not working they tried to make it up to us by a voucher for a free breakfast at O'Henry's. I realized that was the best we were going to do and to let the dream go of even a 10-20% refund. The kick in the shorts in the end? When I went at 11:06 am (check out was 12:00) to cash in on the free breakfast I was told they are no longer serving breakfast since it is past 11:00 am.Not cool. Not cool at all.I'd come back here if they updated their internet to cable or Ethernet, fixed their TV cable, and dropped their prices. $100 is a lot of pay if your services are going to not work and you are not going to cater to the vouchers we were given.The bf and I will not be coming back here. We'll stick to our good experiences at Holiday Inn Expresses.Cheap room well located. Close to shopping and good places to eat. We spent two nights here while visiting the Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village. The rooms were nothing special, but they were clean, the air conditioning was good and the staff are friendly and helpful. Free shuttle to and from the historic sights saved us $5 a day in parking and was very convenient. Free breakfast was standard fare that hit the spot. Liked the Free Press left at our door each morning. Report wireles problems were not encountered by us. Our package contained tickets to Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village and made the value better. Looking for a beautiful BNB experience? Try somewhere else. Here you'll find a place to stay at a decent price.It's big, it's pink, it's faux Victorian, it's dated, and it's perfectly located. We stayed here for two nights, a weekend. Our room, which faced the parking lot, was spacious, quiet, and comfortable. It's right off I-94, just across the freeway from shopping, and 3ish miles from the Henry Ford Museum (shuttle service available). The room was old and perhaps a bit dim but we survived. The staff was very helpful and attentive. The shuttle to the Ford Museum and the airport saved us some time and money. Not a luxurious place but it's more than great for getting a good rest and seeing the area.We chose this place because we wanted to go the The Henry Ford and Greenfield Village, they offered a package deal, and the reviews were good. We were VERY satisfied. The room was charming and very clean, the bed was comfortable with lots of pillows, the lobby and restaurant were charmingly decorated with lovely antiques. The package deal included 2 nights, 2 full breakfasts (excellent), 2 passes to 2 venues of The Henry Ford, and free shuttle service, all for about $250! A great deal. The dinners at O'Henry's were okay, not great, but not bad either. I will write a separate review for O'Henry's.Great value, friendly staff, convenient location, comfortable rooms. The Henry Ford package enabled us to enjoy a spontaneous, affordable family vacation. The courtesy shuttle to local attractions was a nice bonus. Rooms are clean, if dated; free wi-fi, refrigerator and Showtime are welcome extras. Restaurant, not so great.I left this place about two days ago, I stayed their for five days and loved it. As soon as I walked in the room was clean and it was big. The reason why I didn't like is that when I walked in for the first time the room smelled like ciggarettes but got the order out by spraying some of my cologne. The room I stayed in had a king size bed, a mini fridge (this was a plus!!!), study desk, TV (with great channels). The place was calm right off the exit of the highway and as well near local stores. At the morning it tends to get noisy in the hallway due to the cleaning people and as well some of the occupants down the hall were smoking pot in there room. The wi-fi signals are terreble but hey we can live without technology. The have parking in the front and back of the hotel in which they tend to close the back entrance at night. I am willing to stay here again for my next visit.We have been staying here, twice a year for ten to 14 days each visit, for six or seven years. It is our home away from home when visiting Michigan relatives. The rooms, especially those on the second floor, overlooking the courtyard, are spacious and gracious. O'Henry's Restaurant (with full bar) is quite good. The new owners have invested some cash in fixing up the parts of the place which were getting to be run down, and it is looking much better. Our favorite motel has gotten better.
review_content_20: Nice rooms and facility but wireless signal is terrible in the rooms.I think that the rooms and the hallways could use a little fixer-upper. The hallways looked super old and the countless black and white photos of children was to say the least strange. The staff were great though. They were friendly and helpful. The one thing that i was little pissed about was they forgot my wake up call the first night i went there...no biggy because i had a secondary alarm in the room...but still they should pay better attention to things like that. I also had a chance to have breakfast at the restaurant downstairs O' Henry's. It wasn't too bad...again the staff at the restaurant were great. The location is great (unfortunately i didn't have a car so i couldn't explore that much) but the Henry Ford museum is like 2 miles away and there are also a lot of stores and restaurants not to far either.it smells.  really bad.  my first experience was the smell of hot dogs in the hallway.  Then my 1st room smelled of stale smoke.  I changed rooms and it was better.  The hallways are a maze, the restaurant is pretty awful, the service is ok.  Did I mention it smells?  I wouldn't stay there again.  Also internet is slow, oh so slow.We visited this Best Western in November 2010. Great location as it was close to major freeways, shopping and plenty of free parking.   The room was clean and the bed was comfy. However, there was a need for updated cosmetics. Overall, I would recommend as it met our needs for a quick trip to the Detroit Metro area.Great hotel! Comfortable beds and great pool! Only reason it didn't get 5 stars was the terrible restaurant (O'Henry's...one of the worst I've ever eaten at; dinner and breakfast) and guests making lots of noise in hall all night.

review_content: This place is under renovations, so when you drive up, it doesn't seem so bad. There is a nice new marble sign with the name of the hotel, and the building was repainted a nice dark grey. First you have to be buzzed in by front desk, then you walk into a small lobby with a giant, I am guessing, bullet proof glass that separates you and the front desk. Kind of off-putting and scary when you think the hotel needs that much protection against the outside. Hallways and rooms are out of date and need serious updating, but like I mentioned they are in the process. There are a few of the rooms that have already been renovated, but they were not available when we reserved. Our room was not that bad considering how old the hotel is. Some of the plaster falling off the walls near the corners, baseboards missing and a little carpet ripped from sides of walls. But to our surprise, we had full size kitchen, which was kind of cool.The parking was behind locked gates, so we felt the cars were pretty safe, however we were told we had to have our cars out Sunday night because they were going to paint on Monday morning. So we had to park in front where there was obviously no security. Like any big city, do not leave anything in your car, one couple had their back window smashed in, but all other cars were fine. The neighborhood still seems to be in its up and coming stages, there are a few bars/restaurants within walking distance, the downtown area, about a mile is also within walking distance.For the price we paid, about $60/night, where all other hotels were running at close to $300/night, this was well worth the money. Once renovated, I bet this will be a really nice hotel.After my stay, I can totally see how someone was murdered here. Google it for yourself. It screams of snuff films. If you want to feel unsafe and dirty, stay at the Corktown Inn / Corktown Hotel / Trumbull and Porter. This "hotel" has had some many names that it makes you wonder why they're constantly attempting to re-brand. It's because they're trying to outrun their awful reputation. The signs outside are "Corktown Inn" and "Trumbull and Porter." But when I booked, it was the "Corktown Hotel" (please pick an identity). Unfortunately, I didn't check Yelp before booking- I only looked at TripAdvisor, which will be my next stop.I've stayed in hotels for conferences, vacations, and even stayed in college dorms for 4 years. This was the worst living/housing situation I've ever encountered. It's absolutely atrocious that an establishment can be pest and mold-covered, yet attempt to present themselves as renovated and clean. Don't even bother looking at their website, it's a lie.I've attached numerous photos of the mold-ridden, dingy, old and broken, ant residence. Yes, I found some ants too, but they didn't want to split the bill! The television is one I remember having as an impoverished child. Shaky static images on an old Zenith tube television atop a heavily stained dresser. I didn't even look inside for fear of finding anything disturbing. Further, the headboard was broken. My dad used to work at HoJo's and the "blankets" were just as scratchy and flat as I remember as a poor kid. We took a travel blanket out of our car and slept with that. I checked the mattress for bed bugs because the place was just that gross. The front desk looks like something out of a tragic comedy. One of those moments that really makes you rethink what you're about to do, but it was NYE and everything else was booked or way out of an average person's price range (e.g. suites at MGM).The walls are paper thin and when our neighbors were banging on it at 2am, we called the front desk. The man working there told us that it was the vending machine! Wow, I guess we look stupid enough to believe a vending machine across the hall was causing the noise adjacent to us. Thanks front desk. He hung up on us (stellar service) and when we called back were hung up on again. So we knew we'd be leaving immediately, even though we booked this crap shoot for 2 days. They couldn't pay me to stay any longer. If it wasn't frigid winter in Michigan, we would've checked out and slept in our car. The cherry on top was the 5am wake up call from one of the guests walking and screaming down the hallway. We were on the same floor as the front desk, and only a few rooms down, so I'm sure they heard and could not be bothered. I double and triple checked the deadbolt on our room door. This place was a nightmare.Corktown Hotel, I see you're in the habit of responding to these messages with a half-a**ed apology and convenient plug for what you purport to be a new/not disgusting place. I just want my money back because I will NEVER EVER EVER EVER come back.I understand that this hotel is under renevations, but there was no excuse for some of the stuff we encountered while staying here. Honestly, I'm glad we were only here a night because any more than that and I would have been sleeping in the car. I heard pretty mixed reviews about this place, but I wasn't prepared for some of the stuff I saw.Our friend went in to check us in and honestly the outside looked fine. The parkinglot is gated which is nice.We went inside and the hallways were old. It's obvious that the place was being updated but a lot of things were falling apart. The elevator is small and honestly kind of scary. We encountered a lovely "$2.00 blow jobs" sign scratched into the mirror.Up at our room, the first impression I got was that it smelled like weed and cigarettes. It appeared to be clean enough, but upon further inspection we were proved wrong.The floor was filthy. There was a gum stain. The walls were super dirty too. When I pulled back the blankets I was greeted with the wonderful sight of a cum stain, what looked like boogers, and a ton of cigarette burns. Needless to say we didn't sleep with those blankets. The sheets were pretty clean aside from a stray pubic hair. The pillows were ok too except one had eyeliner all over it.Thank god there were no bugs. The bathroom wasn't super great. The toilet paper was almost fully gone. The tub had black mold around the edges as well as some strange brown scratches in it. It smelled like a public bathroom. Also, there is no lock on the door.Just as we finally settled down and decided that we would just suck it up, we noticed that NONE of the plugs in the main living space were three pronged. If you have a laptop or anything needing three prongs, good luck. You'll have to plug it in in the bathroom next to the sink. The television was also unplugged and unusable, and the WiFi was super slow.Aside from this, and the fact that the entire room just had a gross layer of nasty all over it, there were some upsides. It was decently quiet. The beds were pretty comfortable. The room was a nice temperature. The staff were friendly and accommodating. You definetely get what you're paying for and I guess if you don't mind a pretty gross room, it isn't horrible to stay at.Ok, so this is really a 2 star hotel, but considering the reviews I read and the price, I was expecting something much worse. For about $80 a night during Memorial Day weekend (where everything is $300-400 a night), the Corktown met my expectations. The place felt pretty safe, the neighborhood seems very hipstery (a brewery just opened around the corner), and you had to use your key card to get into the building. The room was small but clean, had a full size bed, working AC, older tv, and decent bathroom. One day we did run out of hot water in the shower, but otherwise it was ok. Staff was friendly and helpful as well.In all, a decent place to stay if you're on a budget and want to be fairly close to downtown.BEWARE OF BEDBUGS!!!! I got over 10 bites from a one night stay at this hotel. Customer service was horrible. They tried to overcharge me and were really rude.This hotel is just what I was looking for. Yes, the front desk is somewhat odd because of renovations, and the room had some scuffs on the walls and dust on the dresser--but that's what I expect when I book an inexpensive hotel. I found everything perfectly adequate, and didn't feel unsafe at all.You absolutely get what you pay for here. I have traveled all over the world, so I have experience with less-than-savory conditions. Be prepared for:The good--keycard to get into the building, parking lot, and rooms; very quiet (we felt like we were the only guests staying there); close to downtown in Corktown; very inexpensive; clean bedding (I check, too, for bedbugs and had no problems); clean bathroom; and the employees were all very friendly and helpful.The bad--dingy; old carpet; leaking ceilings in the hallway; cracked windows; and poor WiFi and TV reception. Our first room had a malfunctioning air conditioner, but they quickly moved us.The ugly--powerful cigarette smell even though the entire hotel is a no-smoking zone, and the sheets reeked of it and made for a very uncomfortable night. In all honesty, I cannot recommend it and suggest you spend a bit more for some more comfortable accommodations.I won't bother commenting about the accommodations because the place has BEDBUGS !! I did all the usual checks when I arrived with a hi power led flashlight. Lifted the mattress checked the bed cover underneath couch pillow - nothing. 15 minutes after going to bed I felt something crawling on my shoulder and up my neck. I turned on the light and sure enough it was a bed bug. The clerk was extremely rude and would not refund me for the night I stayed, only for the extra night I was supposed to stay. Needless to say, I should have checked out bedbug registry FIRST. It lists 3 complaints :bedbugregistry.com/hotel...Ugh.My landlord booked this place for my roomie and I when my heat was out and it was yuck. So yuck.The area is fine, I'm pretty familiar with it. I love corktown and it is really close to attractions and if you haven't explored Detroit it's probably a good location to check out the old tigers stadium and bars and whatnot. But holy hell, this place is dirty. I wouldn't stay here again. The hallway smells, and supposedly they have bed bugs but I luckily didn't see any.It's not that bad. It's 2 miles away from Comerica Park, and an Uber ride from the hotel to the game was less than $5. Sheets were clean, the decor is a little outdated, but I would compare this hotel to others I have stayed in in New York and Chicago that are older hotels. I don't know if I would venture out on foot to explore the neighborhood though.So after reading some of these reviews, I was preparing for the worst. I actually ended up having a fine time here. Stayed during MoPop festival, hotel was pretty packed. Walking distance to park venue, good food and bars close by. Yeah the place smells like smoke, the room is clean, wifi could be stronger, receptionist was nice and helpful.Well, in all fairness, this is a motel dressed up as a hotel. The front staff is very friendly and helpful and considering that they are in the process of "rebuilding" the hotel, I will be kind. Because it really needs a huge million$$ overhaul.The good,- located off the freway close to downtown Detroit- free parking; although the lot needs repavement- front desk personnel very friendly- the Rates from standard ($50 a night) to higher for bigger rooms (I stayed in the standard room, which is a single room occupancy room equivalent to a dorm)-They are rebuilding (and I hope it happens quickly because the rest of the city is passing them up)The bad,- soiled mattress (but clean sheets)- some holes in the comforter- a leaky bathroom faucet (they must have a high water bill)- worn carpeting throughout- old scratched marred furniture - not even vintage or antiquish- no coffee maker, no refrigerator in the room; no cafe inside the hotel. There's a Burger King one block away- the TV had cable for 1/2 the stations didn't work; the color was washed out.Very few guests were in the hotel, so it was quiet.This is a good hotel to stay in overnight and if you're passing through and can't get a room elsewhere.My wife searched for days trying to find rooms for the Buffett concert. We were supposed to stay 2 nights, but after pulling into the parking lot, no way we were staying here. Reviews are bad. Very sketchy area to say the least. Prostitutes roaming the area. Had to get buzzed in just to talk to someone, and the receptionist is behind nearly 2" glass! That should tell ya something. Google it! See for yourself, this should be a last resort stop. Run while you can! Wife said 'no nookie' if we stay here..All I can say is you get what you pay for.My first issue arose after reserving a room for 2 nights. I decided to cancel one of the nights a few days later and called back to do so. They had no record of my reservation. Lucky that I called!The next issue and the one that will most likely ensure that I will never stay there again was cleanliness. I wasn't expecting mints on the pillows, but they carpet clearly hadn't been vacuumed, there were stains on virtually every cloth surface (chairs, drapes, comforter, lamp shades), and the TV stands and walls had crud all over them. I even found a fossilized French fry on the ground. Luckily I was drunk and freezing when we checked in, or we would have been shelling out cash for a different hotel. I definitely took a scalding hot shower and burned all the clothes I wore while there when I left.The last issue was that I called the front desk from the room phone to find out where I could order a pizza and no one picked up. So I called from my cell phone and what do you know? They picked up right away.The good: location (perfect for the St. Patrick's Day parade in Corktown), price, and a funny story to tell the grandkids one day.We stayed in the newly remodeled room last weekend and we loved it! I am looking forward to the rest of the hotel being renovated so all the rooms and exterior will be just as nice. Although I can understand the reviews from people who did not stay in the new rooms because the exterior and hallways need much improvement. But, never once did I feel unsafe while staying there. The location is great. You are just outside all of the hussle and bussle but close enough to all of the expressways. Parking is free and secure. The staff is friendly and there are lots of great restaurants near by. I would stay here again and save my money for all the fun that the city has to offer. The room is for sleeping and it served it's purpose well!I'm giving this review one star instead of zero because I realize the room wasn't as bad as one of those seedy hotels I've seen on episodes of Law and Order SVU- Although we did learn that someone was murdered in the hotel a couple of years ago- our fault for not reading-up on the place before booking the room. Anyways, the first negative we encountered upon entering our "premium" room, was the smell- we were greeted with the smell of stale cigarette smoke- but this was the least of our issues. More concerning was that there was no phone and no alarm clock- you couldn't call out of the room if you needed to, and no extra lock on the door. Every piece of bedding in the room (literally every piece- comforter, blanket, sheets, including the extra linens we requested) had cigarette holes in them. The furniture in the room was filthy, we found spiders in the drawer of the nightstand, the walls and ceiling covered in unidentifiable stains, and our towels had small black hairs embedded in the fibers. In comparison, the following issues were not that big of a deal, but still not what I would consider expected for a $175 room- there was no lid on the toilet seat (which is necessary when you don't want your clean clothes touching the filthy floor), there were no tissues anywhere in the room, the front office staff are behind a bullet-proof glass window, and the cards to enter your room and the gated parking area didn't work well. We've read that new owners are trying to call this a "boutique" hotel and have renovated seven rooms, but until all the rooms they rent are updated, I do t think you could call it that.We stayed here for the Movement Electronic Music Festival in Detroit. The stay at this hotel was far from adequate. We are actually checking out a day early because this hut was such a shitty amenity. Let me just say that I recommend staying here if you're okay with the following: 1. Resident prostitutes roaming the halls at all hours of the night.2. Every floor smelling like marijuana (curious if this is a covert grow house).3. Paper-thin walls so that you can hear the show on TV in the next room - along with the aforementioned prostitutes performing their business.4. Random "goodies" left in the room. For us, a tie-off bag for shooting what appears to be heroin.5. Having to spray your entire room down with Lysol as to not worry about the random stains throughout the room and bed.6. Gated parking that's never locked - when it should be...no wonder people get their cars broken into.All and all...don't stay here if you have the option of sleeping in a car.The location is great. Plenty of bars and restaurants within walking distance, not to mention coffee and records. Heck, if you aren't in a hurry you can stroll all the way downtown or to Mexicantown in 20 minutes. But yeah, it kind of sucks. I don't need much; I'm a man of simple tastes. I was ready for the comically famous vending machine.But the hallways smelled oppressively of smoke, and our bedroom wasn't much better. They didn't bother bringing towels 1 of 2 days. The walls were paper thin so you could hear every radio, conversation, or, uh, sexytime like you were a part of the action.So you can stumble home from the bar, but I'll try for a plan B next time. Like Hostel Detroit, or maybe the St. Regis up in New Center, where I've had good experiences for similar price ranges.This hotel was adequate and clean. However, when I walked out the hotel this morning our vehicle was stolen within 4Minutes but it was found later in the day. BUT if you want to stay in downtown Detroit for an inexpensive night of $85, then this is your place.I honestly thought the park across the street was called "Dan Savage Memorial Park," (and not Dean Savage Memorial Park), and now I know exactly why I thought that. One of the vending machines at the Corktown Inn stocks what may be the most comprehensive selection of underwear and assorted vice accessories in America: Jezebel halter tops, leopard print thongs, standard mens' boxers, chocolate flavored condoms, vasoline, playing cards, and scope. If all that keeps you too busy to step outside this "fine hotel" for air, the next vending machine over offers a wide range of packaged dinner foods, including ramen and Chef Boyardee.Aside from the vending machine offerings, you can tell a lot about a hotel from the reception staff. The woman at the desk, despite seeming stoic on the surface, was quite pleasant-natured and a bit quirky in a good way."Expedia... Expedia... Expedia..." she says out loud, as she combs through the laminated index cards of the antiquated manual room card catalog. "Standard, no. You pay standard, I give you king."As other clientele shuffled in- a mix of aging rock stars, truck drivers, a woman in pajamas, Japanese businessmen, and a cool cat in a leather jacket who puts his thumbs up and says "killer!" (as in, "awesome!") when you open the door for him- I took stock of the used furniture for sale across the lobby, a dresser for $60, TV stand for $100... Detroit-style scrappiness at its best. This "fine hotel" is making ends meet while keeping prices low."One night, one night. Two nights," said the stoically effervescent receptionist. She'd make a fabulous accountant. All her mathematical reasoning is broadcast out loud." Sixty, sixty, one hundred twenty."Sounds reasonable, especially compared to the offerings downtown. And these days, Corktown is arguably a better place to hang than downtown. "How many key? One key? Two key?" Well, the most important thing about a hotel is the room. I was generally very pleased with it. Spacious and comfortable, functional WiFi (despite no promises from the desk) and I imagined that my hardworking receptionist had scanned the room earlier:"How many bedbug?" as she lifts up the mattress. "Zero bedbug."Good. I don't like bugs, especially when they're not paying their share of the rent. The rooms look like they've been recently rehabbed, if perhaps not dusted for a week or three, and could probably be a hair cleaner (read between the lines here). But if your main thing is sleeping well, it's unusually quiet, thanks to the brilliant (and unusual) entry layout with doors recessed ten feet in from the hallway and out of earshot of the slamming doors that often curse even the fanciest hotels.Three stars for the hotel itself, but an extra star for the unique charm and the surrounding neighborhood (Mudgie's, PJ's, Steak Hut).
review_content_20: I'm used to roughing it, but I regret not staying in the hostel instead. The cigarette smoke in the hallways was pretty overwhelming and the walls were paper thin. They also didn't seem to replace our towels on 1 of the 2 nights I stayed. Such a good location, it's too bad it's not slightly nicer.I don't even know what to say.  A friend recommended this place to me before Movement festival last year.  I didn't want to pay a lot for a room, and while this looked a little dingy from the website, I wasn't prepared for the reality of this hotel.Firstly, when I arrived, the lobby was full of really questionable characters, and the receptionist was behind bullet proof glass.  The lobby has an assortment of vending machines - including one dispensing underwear - and the receptionist apparently also can sell you a variety of frozen/microwaveable foods.  My next concern was that there was no/little security for outside doors other than the main lobby.  There is a key used to get in, but people had propped open doors and they stayed that way for hours.As for my room, when I entered it, I was honestly really, really afraid that I'd end up getting lice or bed bugs based on how dirty the room was.  But, we checked the mattresses and I didn't see any evidence of bugs, so I decided to stay there (and happily I didn't come home with any 'cooties' from the room).  The bedding was stained and had burn holes. The mattress was incredibly uncomfortable.  The carpeting was very stained and smelled badly.  The whole room smelled like stale beer and stale cigarettes.  On the upside, the TV had free porn.... that truly looked like it was filmed inside this hotel. (Like, the room decor in the movies matched what was in my room).  The other guests.. I was there for a festival and holiday weekend, so I think the demographic was different than it usually is.  There were a lot of questionable looking people around but they didn't seem dangerous.  We did have a problem with people knocking on our doors at all ours and trying to enter the room uninvited but I think they were just drunk, not dangerous.   It seemed like there were a lot of residents living there.I have never stayed in a hotel where they cared less what went on in your room, and I'm not sure if that's a good thing or a bad thing.Ultimately nothing bad happened to me there, and I'd be tempted to stay again if I wanted to party in Detroit all night.  That said, the rooms here are cheap, but I was able to pay a similar amount by getting friends to share a suite at a nicer hotel closer to Hart Plaza.They run a shuttle to the festival for Movement / DEMF, which is a plus.The best run down hotel I've ever stayed at.  I just got back from Movement festival in Detroit, and was happy with our visit.  It's not the cleanest motel, it's in a bad neighborhood, the front desk is behind bullet proof glass, they sell panties in the vending machine, and they play shitty porn on one of the TV stations.  But for the price it can't be beat.  The staff was really friendly, especially considering all the drunk/high out of their skull guests that are in and out of the place that weekend.  There is a dollar shuttle that takes you to and from the festival all day which was an awesome perk.  The guy running the shuttle was even nice enough to drive us down to the liquor store late at night after he was done running the shuttle.  We offered to throw him a few bucks which he twice turned down since we had been tipping him a buck pretty much every time we had taken the shuttle.Everyone at the Corktown Inn that weekend was pretty much there for DEMF, and the whole place had a nice camaraderie going.  It was easy to just start a conversation with people as you waited for the shuttle, or were walking down the hallways.  The place just felt like it was made for Movement.  The bottom line:  If you're looking for a cheap place to stay for DEMF and don't mind sacrificing some traditional services you get at a hotel like frequent room cleanings in exchange for a laissez-faire attitude towards your activities (wink wink) then Corktown Inn is the place to be.Cheap and clean!We stayed here during the Movement festival. It's a bit far from the Hart Plaza (the cab fare is around 10 bucks) but the motel offers shuttle bus back and forth only for $1! Although the staff is sitting behind bulletproof glass they are super helpful and friendly.Don't expect anything fancy, but it's a good place to sleep one or two nights.I have stayed at the Corktown Inn twice now, both times on a Friday night. Both times the hotel was pretty empty judging by there being only about a dozen cars in the parking lot. We did encounter some shady-looking people in old Mercedes in the parking lot, but they kept to themselves and we never felt endangered. As someone who grew up in Minnesota, the bulletproof(?) glass was kind of shocking, but the staff was helpful and friendly. One of the elevators was out of service the second time we stayed, and there was a burned out light just outside our room. The rooms themselves are very cozy with a bed, two chairs, a 5-year old television, and nightstands. The clock in our rooms both times we stayed was not set and was flashing 12:00. The bathroom and shower were nice, and the room appeared very clean.  We had a burn hole on our sheets one night, but other than that things were spotless. The best part of our stay, and to me the most important part, was that our room was extremely quiet. I did not hear a single other person both times we stayed. Compared to the other hotels downtown which are only a few blocks away, the Corktown Inn is a great value for about a third of the price. If you're going to downtown Detroit on a budget, I believe this is the best bet.As far as bargain places to just rest your head at night go, the Corktown Inn is a pretty good gig.  They have perqs like incredibly useful and thorough vending machines (from beverages to dinner to toiletries to...underwear), security gated parking, close location to downtown, helpful staff, three channels of HBO, functioning heating/air conditioning units in each room, decent pillows, and a good shower/tub combo.  Oh yeah, and two channels of free porn, and one more channeling the security cameras on the premises.  Cons?  Little quirky things, like the sheets had burn holes in them, the carpets were pretty worn, and there was some questionable (but not threatening) patrons wandering the halls.  None of which really matter all that much if you're just looking for a place to rest your head (and maybe find a microwave burrito) for a discount price.

hotel_name: Hawthorn Suites By Wyndham Detroit Southfield
review_content: Let's start with the positives...............priced right I guess. Spacious rooms with a kitchen.Negatives.......dirty....loud....needs a remodel bad. I apparently got stuck in the room next to the room where the staff parties and hangs out because the house keeping staff of men and women were yelling and drinking and partying it up at 3pm until mid evening. Literally, I couldn't have gotten out of my room to walk to my car because they were hanging out in front of my door. Regardless of that...the hotel was just poor all around. I chose it for price...and I won't make that mistake again.0 stars is accurate! I booked a room for one night and I was disgusted. I asked to view other rooms to see if I had another option but all of the rooms appeared in the same disrepair. After my stay, by the way I slept in my clothes, I did contact the front desk and requested the general manager call me he never did. I called back and left a message for the assistant general manager and she never returned my call. If it were up to me I would shut this hotel down as it is in disrepair and not fit for human living. Please see the pictures that I am attaching.I truly cannot understand how a manager or an assistant manager would allow a human to stay in this environment. Further to ignore the request of your guests only exacerbates the obvious problems. Since no one did reach out to me or respond to my request, I can only help others who might find themselves mistakenly booking a room in this dump. If you had the experience that I had perhaps we should start a petition to close this property. As a matter of fact I think we should all contact the corporate office and request at this property be condemned.Can I give this place 0 stars, please??!!! HORRIBLE, DIRTY and DISGUSTING hotel. Front desk staff, one lady was nice and one had an attitude. You can hear people above you arguing all throughout the night.I can't believe I booked this place and didn't read really any reviews, disappointed in myself i wasted my money. They didn't have do not disturb signs for our door, no comforter on the bed when we walked in the door, dirty furniture, dirty floors, shower rod not attached to wall, toilet not attached to the floor, no clean towels, alarm clock un plugged and with the battery hanging out of it. WHAT???? WHO DOES THAT?!I'm not going to list all that was wrong because that would be the LONGEST review in history. Just know do not waste your money!!!! PLEASE. Stay anywhere else that you can. And if you need WiFi, well expect it to be kind of crappy to it kept disconnecting. Whoever owns this hotel needs to get it together. Please update, clean and get a staff that cares to be in Customer Service and cares about their job, might be a nice touch. I hate leaving any reviews with 1 star, but that was beyond necessary it was the worst hotel experience in all my years.I expected more from the suites. The interior was dated and looked as if it's repairs were put on the back burner. The microwave didn't even have the turntable inside of it. Overall, I would not stay here. It's loud on the weekend and had me nervous to sleep. People were outside arguing and fighting at 3am, while other cars were speeding through the parking lot. The only plus was that it was spacious, but that wouldn't have me returning for a weekend stay. It appeared as if it was the local hotel to hang out at on the weekend. The guest that stayed above us were very hood and the parking lot felt like Rouge Park before the policing started (locals will understand what that means). I would like to see how it is during the week when most people are working or the idea of a hotel stay is for business/relaxation and not partying. However, I won't be chancing it. Overall a disappointment.Decided I would do a staycation for Christmas break and booked three nights here. I was immediately disappointed when I noticed how filthy and unkept the grounds were. It was too late to cancel as I pre-paid via Hotwire.The first room was hideous. The furniture in the suite was worn and dirty. I could hear loud rap music and children running overhead. I asked for another room on the upper level, which wasn't much better. I could still hear the other guests fairly well.The hotel lost power after being there for about three hours. I left because that also meant that there was no heat. When I returned in the morning to get my things, the staff informed me that I wouldn't be refunded the first night, but the remaining nights would be. Their offer to me was to return for a "make-up" night. No thanks! I'll take the loss.Don't stay here. It's like a low income subdivision. The room smells like cigarettes and burnt vacuum belts...not clean gross. Do not stay here. The photos are misleading. I WAS SO UNHAPPY that I decided to check out early. I didn't want to make a fuss as everyone seemed content with the low standards presented. They attempted to charge me an early check out fee!! Are you kidding they should pay ME for sleeping there. I barely slept. Between the smell and worrying about my car all night I would not recommend this place to anyone. Too many nice hotels in the area.Don't do this to yourself...Honestly this is one of the WORST hotels I have ever seen. I travel a great deal and have often stayed at this hotel chain with great results, but this particular location is terrible!The best description of this location is NEGLECT! Horrible housekeeping as a result of management apathy. The room had torn and ragged furniture (I will post a pic) the walls were dirty and carpet ragged also. The bed only had two over used lumpy pillows the size of a small couch cushion. As I stepped out the front door of my room there was a smelly trash can that had leaked some sort of black ooze  from the bottom. (Seriously? Trash can outside my room door?)The only positive was the staff was friendly and tried to make it better but to give you a picture of how bad it was. I forfeited the money I paid for a 5 night stay and paid MORE money to stay at the Hilton!!The great staff help and location clean suites with fire places Took awail for the outside ,Was told they where fully booked up at thr complex and where trying to get all the Rooms cleanHorrible! So sure it has a full kitchen. Where in the heck are are the dishes and pots and pans? There's a hole in the closet door! The chair has stains galore! Never again will I EVER stay at a Hawthorne! I should have stayed where I typically stay. Back to Marriot!Can I say the WORST place ever!!! Not only did they give me keys to one but TWO DIRTY rooms and have the nerves to tell me that they can't give me my money back that I just handed over to them in cash until the morning!!! They had no problem taking my money to give me two dirty rooms..I would NEVER stay here and I will tell everyone I know about about how unprofessional and disgusting this place is...they don't even deserve one star!!Great rates, clean room. Due to the other reviews, I was hesitant about staying here but decided to try it. Very happy that my husband and I did. Barbara was friendly and helpful at check in as Valerie made checkout easy. Will stay again!Wow, where do I begin? I'll keep this brief but detailed as possible.There isn't anything good about this place, don't stay here.To confirm some of the claims that other reviewers have made as true:1. Fact - There is a $60.00 cash deposit that you are required to pay (doesn't include the cost of the room itself) in addition to a contractual agreement you must sign. This agreement pretty much lays out the ground rules and addresses how your deposit can be forfeited. My concern was why not just hold the deposit on a credit card as a opposed to cash? When I went and had discovered this information I had to make an extra trip to the ATM to satisfy this requirement. This alone will ultimately discourage customers from staying here because its a form of a hustle. It isn't honest, we're already paying an average of $72.00 for a room + the $60.00 cash deposit. Needless to say I lost my deposit because evidently if you are even a minute late after checkout you lose it. The customer service rep was sarcastic and actually joked about the fact that I lost it. Not only was that unnecessary and inappropriate, keep in mind that as a customer I can relay much more damage in the form of word of mouth than anything.2. Fact- The rooms are dirty, no phone unless you pay extra. No dishes in the apartment, tons of safety hazards, blood stains on toilet, curtains.3. Fact- You will be greeted by loud shouts in the morning chanting "Room Service!" by the time that I had opened the door granted I told the housekeepers that I would be leaving out shortly. They continued to state how much "I" was holding them up and preventing them from doing their jobs. No professionalism whatsoever.4. Fact- Ghetto.This "hotel/motel" was selected as the host location for our family as we traveled in for the funeral of a loved one. We blocked 20 rooms. When we arrived, we quickly noted, THIS PLACE is a disgusting DUMP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Period. If you choose to stay here, you WILL be utterly disappointed. The staff is discourteous and unhelpful; they make you pay for the entire stay upfront as if you are an "hourly" patron with a hooker and they  barely agreed to give us a receipt! Our room was filthy, smelled like cigarettes and debauchery, spots on the bed, nasty stains on the couch and BUGS galore! I killed a mosquito the size of a horse...and I live in Florida! I wore shoes in the room the entire evening because the carpeting was almost gummy to the touch. NO iron, I didn't even bother to enter the "kitchenette" in fear of something crawling from under the refrigerator. If my flight had arrived before it did at 10:30pm I would have certainly selected another hotel. Even more strange, this appears to be a well-established corporate area. VERY gloomy place!Lets start with the room and I wish I had taken pictures. Burn marks everywhere( non smoking establishment may I remind you), filthy bathroom, filthy couch and terrible kitchen. The smelly garbage can sits right out in front of your suite so when you wake up the next morning expect that. The security detail there is absolutely horrible and sub par to be polite (which they aren't), and Southfield police department is there at least three to four times a night. The breakfast buffet, although petty good, makes you wonder if you should eat it being that the rest of the hotel is so nasty. Housekeeping seems to walk around in a drunken stooper most of the time they are seen or available and I don't believe that most of them even work there, so please protect your valuables, or better yet start somewhere else. The price is to high for what you get. Period.its a scam and a mess. !. to the 'cash' deposit'  , the smoke odor in the 'non- smoking ' room, the lack of blankets, the small pillows, the unprofessional staff, the filthy rooms.DO NOT STAY THERE!!!This has to be the worst hotel in Southfield. When I arrived there was what appeared to be a motor cycle gang in the lobby,Me and a few of my closest friends had a gathering there(total of 8 women). At Around 11pm a black male wearing all black, and a ski mask  knocked on the door and announced he was security. He then demanded to be let into the room. We were clearly afraid at the time and refused to open the door. I can admit we were laughing and having a good time, but there was no wild party at all. After refusing the man, we were evicted, we asked for a reason why and we were told that it's in the contract and the Security can evict whenever the volume in the room is too loud. This has to be a scam! The lobby personnel acted as if they had nothing to do with it. The security stated that they were acting on the behalf of the hotel. They took our deposit and room fee. This place is a dump, that has to scam for profits.This review is two parted... the hotel itself I give 3 stars.  It's not the Ritz but for the price you pay you get a lot.  It's great for a family on vacation who would like the home "essentials". You get a full kitchen, etc. and is much nicer and larger than most other "Extended" traveler hotels.  The value for what you get is great.  I give it 3 stars.Then we have the hotel staff and it all goes down hill.  - one star.I arrived to check in at 20 minutes to 3pm. I remember checking my time because as I walked in I found myself waiting inline behind a gentleman telling the hotel desk clerk a long story.  She never looked past to acknowledge me the entire time and I was curious how long it would go on.  This happened at 2:41 and probably went on for a few minutes.  (The gentleman actually apologized after he walked away... hotel desk did not).  So now I hand my ID and credit card to the clerk, Nicole.  Nicole tells me "Check in is at 3pm".  I glance around wondering if she is not aware what time it is.  I politely ask her if there is a possibility that a few rooms MAY be ready 15 minutes before check-in time.  (Apparently on this property a fairy god-mother waves her wand and rooms all become ready at once).  She says "It wouldn't matter, check in is at 3."  Wow.  (I understand at 10AM... but 15 minutes before??...) Okay, I let her know I've never heard of such a thing and Nicole taps the "check-in" sign and asks me have I ever seen that?  How courteous and welcoming.  Not!  So at this point I thought my reservation was already paid for through my online reservation so I chose to stay and handed her my ID and credit card again for her to check me in while I wait for the magic clock to strike 3.  She slides me back my stuff and tells me to have a seat in the lobby.  So I wait in the lobby for a few minutes while she calls me back up and loudly announces "You do know it's a $50 deposit?"  Well, yes, I'm aware hotels (and most any other business where renting is involved) requires a deposit, that's why I gave her my credit card.  I ask her is there a problem with that being on my card and she looks surprised... I'm not sure what level of professionalism goes on here but it is lacking.  At this point she started telling me about how they only have two rooms ready (at 5 minutes to check in time) and blah blah blah... I tell her I don't care which room it is, just check me in.  So she checks me in and I leave the lobby passing by the Fed-Ex guy who she greets HAPPILY as I leave (lucky him).  I then drive around to the room, grab my luggage and open the door to find bed unmade and glasses and cups all over.  Um, no.  I drag everything back to the car and drive back in.  I now have to interrupt her conversation with Mr. FedEx to explain this room is NOT ready.  She takes my card back and then proceeds to talk to Mr. FedEx.  Then, when she decides it's time to check in guests she goes to the back and starts talking about how now it's 3pm and she needs to call people to see if rooms are ready... blah blah blah... I don't care.  Had this been done 25-30 minutes ago when I arrived I wouldn't be as frustrated but instead I am still in the lobby.  Finally, she gives me a new key to a new room...  She does apologize about the room and asks me to double check with her by calling to let me know if it's ok.. which it was.Overall, the hotel itself was fine but the management needs to really work on the courtesy and treatment of guests by workers.  Most hotels I visit are inviting and happy to have your business, especially in an area where the number of hotels is overwhelming.  I understand the property has went through a few changes recently, and saving money is key, but there are plenty of people willing to work with a smile out there to have such piss-poor attitudes.  Oh, and cool points for free wi-fi.First of all let me say that this is The worst place to stay at, EVER. We stayed there memorial day weekend, from Friday through Monday. When we arrived, it took about 3 tries to get our correct room (from walking into other peoples rooms to the key card not working). When we finally got our room, the room was decent but we had absolutely no towels in the bathroom and the sofa sleeper had no sheets or anything. We ended up having to share the ones from our bed. I must admit that I did like the fact that it had a full size fridge and stove, but that's it. Friends of ours that also stayed there over the weekend had people from the hotel "staff" walking in to their rooms at all hours of the day. We were literally scared to leave anything in the rooms. We found all kinds of stuff in and around our rooms from pieces of hair weave to used condoms. We had to keep a close eye on our toddlers so they wouldn't touch anything there. This place is just plain horrible, from the place itself, to the people that work there, to the sketchy people that were in and out of the rooms all day and night. If you can, pay a couple extra dollars and stay somewhere else!!I stayed at the Hawthorne Suites with a handful of colleagues and our first priority was a full kitchen (check), second priority was being close to our office (check). For those reasons plus the reasonable price I give this place three stars. The rooms were clean - although the first room I checked into had a strong smoke smell. I was promptly moved to another room that seemed to have a faint smoke smell, but I would imagine it's hard to keep people from smoking in an extended stay hotel.The staff was nice and the breakfast was mediocre at best. I had oatmeal every morning - the eggs and bacon just didn't look appetizing.For the location and amenities, I'd go to Hawthorne again.We had a 2-week stay here, and had a terrible experience.On arrival, our kitchen was dirty and completely unstocked - we had no silverware, cookware, or dishwashing liquid.  The sofa and chair had stains, the kitchen tiles were cracked, the TV in the "loft" room was broken, and the bathrooms were not well-cleaned.The stove had not been cleaned in a great while, and on our second day, it caught fire.  There was no fire extinguisher nearby, so we put out the fire with a wet towel.  The general manager Ajay was unhelpful and, despite saying he would come by to make sure things were okay, never once spoke with us about it, and was hesitant to give us any sort of discount despite the fact that our room CAUGHT FIRE.Housekeeping was inconsistent and unfriendly.  There were days we called to ask for clean towels other toiletries, and we would return to find our room largely untouched with a large plastic bag full of our items on the couch.  Some members of the housekeeping staff would enter our room unannounced, not in uniform, and talking on their cell phones.  (I should mention, though, that some of the housekeepers were very friendly and efficient).The general manager, Ajay, was unfriendly and very unhelpful.  Wyndam Hotels should be ashamed of this property and the way it is being managed.
review_content_20: when i go there i lock the door.  Not that i feel unsafe but there is nothing else between me and the outside.  All other residence inn i have been to have a door to the building and then one to the room.  Anyway, this hotel is pretty run down and i would not go there on my own (have to for business).  Depending on the building you are in, you can be close to the highway and have a lot of noise from it.The hotel is now the Hawthorne Suites and it sounds as if the place is now much nicer than it used to be.  I suppose that buildings might still be older, but all the furniture was new, the place was clean, the breakfast was amazing (eggs and bacon and all), the workout room was sufficient, and the kitchen even came stocked with plates and silverware and all.  It was perfect and a great, great deal for the price.  (Probably a three star in general... Ok, but nothing great.... expect that the price definitely bumps it up to a 4.)

review_content: Got a free shuttle to The Henry Ford and to the Airport. Breakfast is great. Internet is free and easy. Price is good and pool is nice for kids. Decor is blah.Being a small business manager, I normally only use Yelp to give a referral.  That is sadly not the case here.  To make a long, painful story short, the first problem was overcharging of my credit card.  Of course, there was no one available to fix that issue.  I'll also add that they strongly favor corporate accounts and treat those of us spending a paycheck to just get away as a major inconvenience; constantly asking things like "who are you even here with - why are you even renting a room here?!?" Also, (just like the overcharge) their phone staff just tells you what they think you want to hear ... including "checkout is 12pm". Well, checkout is at 11am,which is fine, but don't make the mistake of leaving your family there one minute longer because the staff will threaten police involvement and make your wife and toddler wait in the lobby, with all of your belongings, until you get back.
