A holiday stay at Holiday Inn is a terrible idea ...unless you're staying with your colleagues for a convention or something.Visited quite a few times, very nice hotel. The pool area is beautiful, the bar has live bands, the free breakfast buffet wasn't anything special but for free it works! My only gripe is, every time we have stayed there is always a huge spider somewhere!! All different times of the year, different rooms, so there must be some issue with them. They might want to look into that. Nothing that would keep me from going back but next time I'm bringing my own spray!! :)Went to this hotel for an office Christmas party, December 11, 2015. This is by far the best Holiday Inn I've been to! The food was so good, not the average banquet food. The food actually had flavor and great flavor at that!!! The staff was amazing!!! Every single staff member I encountered was friendly and went out of their way to accommodate. The pool and hot tub were crystal clear and the pool room was nice and warm as was the water! The breakfast was nice, more on the heavy side but delicious! I would recommend this hotel for staying and especially for banquets. The food was a traditional Christmas dinner with ham, turkey and most of the fixings. The meats were flavorful and best of all not dry! The gravy was tasty and real mashed potatoes! The stuffing was good and the veggie mix was not standard or mushy! The desserts were wonderful a great mix of pies, cakes, and cheese cakes and very scrumptious. Great Hotel!!!My hubby and I went here the Sunday evening after valentine day,  we had a very pleasant experience. Crystal was probably one of the best customer service personal I have come across in a long time. Room 133 was a typical hotel room.Beds were comfortable, sheets were awesome .Toilet was a little to close to the wall for my wide behind. .but manageable..Love that the light goes over the shower!  I hate taking a shower in very dim light...Pool area was gorgeous. Love the fact that it went from 3 feet to 9 feet deep...Hot tub was perfectly heated. . Extra hot.  But unfortunately the seats sit high and the water was extremely low..and there are no good jets.. . also the drain covers stock out horribly. . I stubbed my toes numerous times because I cannot see them under water...Besides our room, the pool area was the only room we visited. . But there is tons to do here...This review is only for Charlie's, the bar/lounge in the lobby.I went for a band's performance. Didn't order food, but the drinks were NOT good. I ordered a vodka tonic and I don't know if it was the tonic that came from the nozzles, but my drink was flat and disgusting. I stuck with beer for the rest of the night. Decent prices, though.Nicely renovated hotel, but most important - the staff went above and beyond for us. Ended up here because our car broke down on the way to Columbus, Ohio and they helped us with transportation (from where we were stuck) to pick up our luggage (where are car was towed) and helped us with a room that fit our family's needs. Thank you - highly recommend!!Outstanding value. Near to Detroit, and a safe area, without having to stay downtown and be charged parking at a downtown hotel. The service is outstanding and the staff are friendly and helpful. Hotel is clean and food is good.Fantastic! Clean, friendly, reasonable, and a staff ready to give full effort. We stayed here for a wedding and decided after the 1st night to bring our babysitter for the weekend out and get her a room so the kids can enjoy the pool and convenience. The pool is huge and all very clean. We dealt with one real bitch of a waitress in the bar so it took away the fifth star (yes, she was that bad) but anyone looking for a room downriver, this is the best all round hotel mixing in service and value that you'll be able to find!This hotel gives a good all-around Holiday Inn experience. There's a pool and exercise room, and free wi-fi in the rooms. The restaurant and bar aren't too bad if you don't feel like driving elsewhere for food (and you do have to drive; no walking here!)Also the staff nicely recovered when no one was available to drive me to the airport - very quickly, one of the staff filled in and took me to DTW.The hotel was fine.  It was very clean, the pool was large and clean, the staff were very helpful and responded quickly to requests or concerns. We are thinking this will be our regular spot to stay when visiting relatives in the area (we've tried several of the hotels along Northline and in the area).

The building is new. In my opinion it is a bit overpriced, but I didn't have a bad experience there.5 years ago this hotel was one of the best in Dearborn when it was Hyatt. Now, it's comparable to any cheap motel. The carpet is very old in most of the floors and coming apart that makes you wonder if it ever gets cleaned. One of the shower towels had red lipstick staining it. The bed was comfortable however, I woke up the next day with couple red bumps on my face and chest which could suggest bed bugs. The phone in the room was from 1980 and doesn't work. How can you have a hotel room without a functioning phone ! Next to my room there was a couple staying with children and those kids were very loud, so apparently their walls are deteriorating or not sound proofed. It was a bad experience and won't come backHere again.Aww..sad to see so many people being let down by this establishment when I had a blast there! We got this hotel through Hotwire -- 2 nights for $160(incl. tax). I couldn't be happier with the location, the service staff and the view from our place! The bed was comfortable, the bathroom was clean and stoked with towels, and the TV worked just fine. Only a light fixture was bad by the bedside but that didn't bother us. There was some sort of church convention going on when we went so the hotel was packed -- though I barely was bothered. The poor was nice and had dry towels :) We didn't get a chance to eat there but I'm sure it would've been alright :) Overall, I feel like I got a bang for my buck and I'm happy!I have to say this is a level of a motel, not a hotel. Don't let the outside fool you, the lobby is structured to attract customers but once you are in the room, you will see the messy details. I was here with friends visiting for the weekend and decided to stay for a night. It definitely wasn't my choice, I usually yelp places before making a choice like this, but it was late and my friends and I wanted to crash after a long night of partying. This was the closest.The beds were neatly tucked, everything looked great walking into the room. The bathroom even fooled us. We were too tired to pay too much close attention. I woke up to my friends complaining on the phone (talking to the receptionist) about how disgusting the bathtub was. I guess my friend wanted to take a quick shower and she couldn't because well the bathtub was closed up and filled with dirty water and mud. Let me mention it again, the bathtub plug was closed, The receptionest says the pipes get backed up sometimes, but the plug was literally shut, someone closed it, please explain how the pipe went through the plug to fill the bathtub. It makes no sense...we had to ask for a new room to shower, they didn't even offer or even suggested to give us some money back. It was disappointing.If you pay Hotel prices, you better expect hotel service....cleanliness and customer service is what gives a hotel 5 star. I only give 2 stars, 1 for clean beds(as far as I know, they are clean) and 2 for letting us shower in a different room.*Disclosure: I stayed here for a blogger weekend and received a comped room.I had never stayed at this hotel or actually even been in this hotel before last weekend. It used to be a Hyatt Dearborn, and in fact will be rebranding sometime this month or the next to another chain hotel, but for right now it's the adoba hotel. I had a king-sized room all to myself, which was pretty awesome. The room itself is very nice, and the bed was comfortable. I was on the 14th floor and had a view of Ford and Detroit off in the distance. The bathroom is a little small, IMO, but the functionality of it was fine. Rooms also come with Samsung flatscreen TVs, contrary to some of the older reviews here ... I only had the TV on for about ten minutes but the picture was great.We ate in the hotel restaurant, Giulio & Sons, three times (two breakfasts + one dinner) while here - check out my review - and I'd recommend that as well.Hotel has a gorgeous lobby area. We stayed here Thursday through Sat AM; Thurs/Fri wasn't that busy, but Sat the hotel started to get VERY busy, as there was an orchestra association conference (MSBOA) and also a dance group in attendance. I'd stay here again if I ever needed to stay in the Dearborn area / closer to Detroit. We also got a sneak peek of the rotunda area, which is rented out for events, and it had awesome views all around.The hotels is a grand lady who is showing her age. She still looks like a 1970s Hyatt (which it was built as). I have a feeling that if it stays like it is for another twenty years it's going to be a pretty trendy neat place. Now, it's kind of warn out, but really still a nice hotel for the price. I would recommend it.I won't recommend the restaurant. It's one of those dated places that have lots and lots and lots of food, most of it without much flavor.The hotel was a big disappointment. My husband and I stayed here on our wedding night in one of the suites. Big mistake! The suite was not worth the money. Bill was well over $300 for one night. It was unattractive, very outdated, with peeling wallpaper and old furnishings. It didn't even have a frig or microwave. Hotels at half the cost at least have those amenities. The TV didn't have any premium channels available.Unfortunately, they also had a dance competition of some sort that weekend and our suit was across from one of the captains. We knew this because they placed an ugly sign outside the doors of the suites. We endured a lot of loud talking and "going and comings" in the hall outside. What a night to remember. We were very tempted to just leave but just tried to be a good sport.We were checked out the next morning by a woman at the front desk claiming to be the assistant hotel manager. She needed to look the part. I don't consider a sweat suit and messy hair to be presentable for hotel staff and management especially when you're paying this kind of money.This place was once a 5 star hotel that has not been updated in years. When you first see the building you are very impressed with it's size and style...but, very quickly you realize you are not in 5 star heaven. I read the other Yelp reviews, so I was not expecting 5 star treatment....I love having Yelp. Yelp is always right on the money.About 25 years ago, I stayed at this beautiful hotel when it was a Hyatt. It was state of art in design and service. I felt like I was visiting a an old beautiful friend that had left herself go. Sad...On a brighter side...I used a Groupon and it only cost me $80.00 a night. The $80.00 is total...taxes, etc. Plus free parking, a free appetizer every night and the bed was oh so comfy. I enjoyed my stay, but sorry to see the place in the condition that it is in...Oh...the service is below average...but for the price I was happy.I was overcharged by $450 dollars for a one night stay. Called the day we checked out after seeing 6 different charges go through on my credit card - I was told it was a mistake and that they would credit me a partial amount until they could figure out what was happening. It's been four days, no credits back to my card and I get the run around when I call, and of course no call backs. The hotel itself was fine, although rampant with small kids...there must have been a dozen in the room above me from the sound of it...The room service was also fine and prompt.We are here right now. I'm so grossed out I called Priceline to get the heck out of here and Adoba won't refund us because they said we've been here since 5. We have not. But let me paint a picture.An opulent lobby at first glance. Look closer and its dirty. Trash on the floors, dirty elevators. The halls for the rooms have carpet so worn, there is tape to keep it down. For real. The room is stifling warm. The carpet filthy. Food crumbs and such, dirty. The bathroom mirror is dirty. The shower curtain is dirty with stains.The bed.Oh my God.The bed has 4 layers. Flat sheet, comforter, flat sheet, flat sheet. There is no fitted sheet just a flat sheet on the mattress. No mattress pad, just a thin sheet between me and a mattress I can't even describe because it makes my skin crawl. There is a bed skirt, but it too is stained. Oh, and you can see how miserable the mattress is.My husband called the front desk (after having to plug in the broken phone) for a fitted sheet. With a promise to call back unfulfilled, he called again and was told they didn't have any fitted sheets. He tried to explain the sheet comes off and he moves a lot in his sleep. He got a sorry and that was that. He actually asked me if he should go to target and buy sheets. Thinking a shower would help our mood we discovered the shower doesn't drain well at all. Ankle deep water was the icing on the cake.We also tried the pool which was also filthy. Garbage on the floor, dirty towels all over. Don't even get me started on the pending $100 charge to my debit card for "incidentals"Just don't do it. This place sucks.Called four days before check in to request a refrigerator. Upon check in I was told it was first come first serve. Due to a gluten allergy I have a car full of food that melted by the time they got me a fridge.... Additionally, I got up to my room after check in & the key did not work. Twenty five minutes later they sent a new key which also did not work... I have been waiting almost an hour now. Still no working key, the safety lock is about to fall off & the room is very dusty. I have missed check in for my seminar because of this... The wifi doesn't work & the sweet sound of doors slamming all night is just the cherry on the top of this over priced hotel. I hope my continuing ed seminar is held elsewhere next year so I don't have to stay here again.This place is disgusting. I wish I could give it 0 stars. There was an earring left in our bed, the staff at the front desk were extremely rude besides maybe two employees. The only good thing about this hotel was the location and the fact that the manager refunded our money because of our bad experience.This is a cheap motel disguised in a grand looking hotel on the outside. The following were some of the mishaps during our stay:1- Room is really outdated, the Air conditioning unit takes enormous amount of time to change temperatures, rendering us shivering the majority of the night. 2- Room service: advertised products are not actually served, after placing breakfast order, 10 mins later a call was made telling us some of the items will not be available for breakfast. 3- No shower gel! we had to bring our own, and when we asked for it, they stated" the hotel ran out" incredible ! so they gave us two bottles of lotion, that was their version of accommodating us. 4- house keeping does an absolutely horrendous job in cleaning, merely did the bed, did not clean bathroom , vacuum or take out the trash, I have stayed in 45 dollar motels before, where house keeping was better than this.5- No Bellman service, despite the front desk telling us they will help us once we are done checking out, No carts or anything of the like either. Dont waste your money with hotels.com or this hotel, you are better off paying 45 dollars in a cheap motel instead.I just spent time reading a lot of the reviews here. From what it seems like, they have a sincere customer relations employee responding to all reviews but the management doesn't seem to be listening to the feedback. Which makes me feel guilty giving this rating of 3, but well, I would have given it a 2 otherwise.The hotel looks good, from the outside. the elevators are fancy, and the rooms are good. The bathrooms are kind of small and need renovation. My complaint is about the room service- A. Why is there no room service menu?B. Why does dinner service shut at 10? No in room dining post 10? C. Even their bar stops dinner at 10! It doesn't make sense to me. There must be some work around. I, sadly, am a sucker for marriot points and will not return. These guys need to sort some stuff out if they need their rating to get better. Good luck.In 1999, we (Henry Ford High) used their ballroom for prom. It was fun to come back and reminisce as an adult!I have mixed emotions about this hotel. For the price the rooms are not bad (actually quite large) even though they are very outdated. The front desk was backed up with 40 people waiting and only 2 people working. They also did not have any sense of urgency so this exasperated the problem. We had a conference in the hotel and the meals, amenities, and staff were great. The bar downstairs is extremely overpriced ($24 for a double jack on the rocks!) and the service there was average.All in all this was probably a fair value but it could be an exceptional value with just a few improvements.I was really excited to stay here with my husband for the two nights we had booked. We got a good deal for the room online. The hotel itself is beautiful, inside and out. I love the elevators, the way you can see all the floors if you go up and look down. It has a nice classy feel to it. The gift shop, coffee shop and restaurants are definitely nice as well, same with the pool. Although I will say the pool looks smaller in person. Our room was a Standard King room, it included a king size bed, flat screen smart TV, a desk with a desk chair and two other additional cushioned chairs. The view was pretty nice, I like the wide windows. We also had a small coffee pot and some coffee, which we did not use. The room is nice, the layout makes it feel open and spacious, I like that. It doesn't look like the typical hotel room, layout wise. I really liked how the TV was on a pull out stand that you could adjust for a good viewing angle. I do have some complaints however. The bathroom could definitely use some TLC. The bathtub looked old, and had black rust/gunk around the drain. The sides were tiled, which isn't really good because it holds dirt. *I will admit I am VERY PICKY when it comes to tubs/bathrooms so most people would probably be fine with*. I ended up showering with flip flops on haha. Also the shower curtains should be washed after every guess visit. Ours had soap residue and water stains. The bathroom was also small, but not a big deal. It had shampoo, lotion and nice smelling soaps. The room could use some updating, style wise. The curtains and carpets just seem outdated. Also the carpets were sticky in some areas, and the ground itself was very uneven. The bed was very firm, but I like that. The pillows were soft and comfortable. I enjoyed sleeping in it for the most part.It was a bit noisy, and we could hear the conversations of our neighbors very clearly. This was probably because we were placed in a connecting room (with a second door inside the room that connects to the room next door). So you might want to stay away from that since the noise travels through the doors. This isn't really the hotels fault though, just noisy guests. The room doors were also really noisy at night and woke me up several times as people left/entered their rooms. Again though this could be solved if people just closed the doors slowly.Also the air didn't seem to get much cooler when we turned it down.I enjoyed the free internet, and the free parking as well, there is A LOT of parking areas. Also, they tried to charge us 10$ for two waters from the room. We never even had water in our room besides the Kroger bottles we brought with us. We even called when we first went in to our room and noticed there was no water, to make sure they didn't charge us for it thinking we drank it. They said they wouldn't yet they did. The charge was taken off but still annoying.Would I stay here again? Probably not if I ever returned to Dearborn. Don't get me wrong, it is very nice, and if you get a good deal it's worth it. It just wasn't MY favorite. However, If they ever renovate, and I am in town, I would try it again.I'd read some horror stories on this hotel, so was expecting the worst & my expectations were very low. I have to say I was pleasantly surprised: Yes, its an old hotel (1976). Yes, it's only been partially updated - the room's fixtures in particular needed refreshed. And the gym - don't even bother - walk over to the LA Fitness at the mall across the street instead and get a day pass....But everything that could have been changed that was important, had been done. The beds were comfortable, the room was quiet, I had a fantastic Samsung HDTV, fast and free internet, and the restaurant was not at all bad (if a bit heavy). The hotel markets itself as eco-friendly - I'm not exactly sure what was so green about it, but I very much appreciated the boxes of water over plastic bottles - nice touch.So yeah, groove on the 1970's futuristic interior, drink an awesome carton of water, and check out the view across miles of Dearborn's finest parking lots. Just don't expect a boutique hotel experience. Solid 3 stars.Found this hotel last minute online for under $100. night. I was in town with a friend to attend a concert, and sadly, our plans to stay in Detroit itself did not work out. I was a bit concerned staying in the burbs in regards to traffic... but apparently this isn't much of a problem in Detroit outside of the actual concert traffic.First off, having underestimated the traffic headed into the concert, we chose halfway on our drive between Chi town and the D to skip checking in at the hotel until after the show. One quick call, and I was told a late check in was noted and all set. We arrived at 1 am, and were quickly helped at the desk. Though it may not be brand new and sparkly, the hotel appeared clean and well cared for. With as many people as we saw sitting out front (post concert attendees), the hotel was quiet... though with 700+ rooms, it is easy to space out guests. The room was also spacious and clean. The water in the shower did drain pretty slowly, and one of the sinks in the room had a small leak... but that was the extent of the issues.There is a small Starbucks with a limited menu located in the lobby, and a large mall literally across the parking lot which is nice in the event you forget to bring something, or need extra clothing.The area in general has a very suburban feel. There are nice apartments nearby and the mall appeared large with stores like Macy's visible. There are also a couple of Starbucks and other coffee shops within a 10 minute drive. We also saw several bars and restaurants which appeared new int he vicinity.Overall, a clean, quiet, safe location to stay and rest. Though it is not right downtown, we were able to get into the city center in about 20 minutes time on most occasions,Nice hotel, with a cheap price! Pretty modern And very clean! Valet and self parking!
review_content_20: Can I give negative stars? Seriously, my husband, my two year old son and I stayed here last night and there are few hotels that are worse. First, we found out they don't have cribs available. So that means my husband and I get to sleep in the bed with our two year old son. Which means we get kicked in the head and the stomach all night not to mention staying half awake to make sure he doesn't fall out of bed. Then, the first thing we see when we step out of the elevator on our floor was a roach walking across the floor. Our room was average for most hotels. Then when we got back on the elevator, there was broken glass on the floor. I do have to say, everyone we met who was working at the hotel was very friendly. I should probably give one star for those people.From the moment we pulled up to the dark entrance, we knew it would be a weekend from hell. Let me preface by saying that we travel at least 10 times a year, staying in all different hotels and I have personally never found enough unsatisfactory that I found it necessary to complain, until this past weekend. No bell service, 1 attendee at the front desk with a line of angry people waiting, filthy rooms (I'm talking mold and chewed gum on the headboard, not to mention, maintenance had to come to my room 3 separate times) A staff member who shall remain nameless (SUE) harassed 2 children in front of at least 20 adults and when it was brought to the 20-year-old manager's attention, she practically rolled her eyes. I will NEVER stay at this hotel EVER again. I don't even want to think about it anymore, it makes me so sick to my stomach. Should be torn down.And I just went through all of the responses from Adoba...bathtubs still not fixed. Liars.Not cheap, but not expensive either. We stayed because it is close to the Henry Ford museum. The music was on in the lobby all night which we could hear from our room, so that was a pain. But the rooms were spacious and they are also dog friendly.Not too bad!  Stayed here as part of a conference that I attended recently.  Like other reviewers, I found some of the decor and furniture a bit outdated.  The service was good...not great.  The conference rooms/accommodations were fairly typical.  The good:  Stayed on the 14th floor, great views!  The amount of channels available on their cable was astonishing.  The room service was prompt and attentive (the burger was good too). The bad:  Outdated decor, Average service (outside the room service).  I would go back!On the outside this hotel is beautiful and right in front of a big mall. It literally takes 5 minutes tops to walk to the mall. On the inside the hotel is even more beautiful than the outside. There is a Starbucks right when you walk in. They have the best breakfast I've ever had at a hotel by far. The pool and gym is amazing and indoor. The room was nice. I have to take off one star for this hotel still having old school standard definition TVs. How hard is it to buy a flat screen TV for every room in bulk. Oh well. It was still a good experience overall and I would go back.Good place for conference (big hotel), meeting and such, nice parking, not too busy location....BUT..Room is not good where I stayed. not cleaned up well. Bathroom is awful (even after I mentioned it to front desk), ventilation/HVAC is bad. I will stay nearby newer (and cheaper) hotel while attending meeting/conference from now on.I have traveled all over the world with my organization. To arrive to Dearborn  Michigan, at the Adobe hotel. The whole set of the hotel is bad including the station  elevator button. Room did not get clean until 4pm. Request clean face rags only for maid to say you only get one. Front desk management was rude. Had no coffee in room. Trash was every where. Floors where not vacuum and trays where not picked up for the two days I was thier. Guests smoking drugs.call corporate office and has not heard back yet. Not a good place to relax.I have stayed here several times in hopes that the first two times were just pure coincidence that my terrible experience wasn't an actual reflection, unfortunately staying this last time just proves this place  should be a motel! My first experience the front desk staff double charged me and instead of offering to refund offered me a "free" in other words come back and stay for the same amount we just charged you. Considering I'm in Michigan a lot I stupidly took this so call "free" room. Upon arriving to my room my second visit I was exhausted from my 5 hour drive only to find that my room hadn't been cleaned from the people before and there was fresh blood stains on the sheets of the bed when I called down to customer service she said she'd call me back...when she called back her response was "it's not possible that the room wasn't cleaned, I just checked the clip board and it was marked cleaned." I requested for her to come up and look which she said wouldn't make a difference. Finally after hours of complaint and taking the dirty sheets off the bed and too the front desk she finally moved my room to another one but STILL charged me for the old rooms open water! This last experience once again wasn't any better, I checked in at 2am and checked out by 8am, would of checked out sooner had I realized that my tub had hair chucks and dirt filled in it floating, when I told the manager she said oh that happens our building is old just rinse it off and I can send a engineer up to fix it. What kind of customer service is this? I'm not paying motel price for motel services I'm paying hotel prices...n getting less than I would at the worst rated motel. She wasn't apologetic nor did she even attempt to accommodate us in any way. A picture is attached of the disgusting tub. I would never ever stay at this garage hotel again.My stay here can be summed up as utterly disappointing. For how large, centralized to nearby businesses and how expensive it is, this hotel really needs to step it up and act like a hotel, not a motel. When I checked in, my room's toilet was leaking and constantly running, the lighting on the wall was falling out of the wall and everything was extremely run down and dirty. I ordered food daily and it was some of the most flavorless and overpriced food I've ever had. I had better and cheaper food at The Henry Hotel across the way. I had several encounters with staff who seemed annoyed with having customers and honestly, didn't seem like they wanted to be working there. I waited for 20 minutes to get my receipt upon checking out and they just never tended to me. I called when I got home to get my receipt emailed and sat on hold two different times for 45 minutes each and never got helped. I usually stay at The Henry when I'm in town monthly for work and for being a direct competitor I don't know what this place is thinking. Do yourself a hugeI had a miserable experience.  It was freezing. It was my wedding night too. They knew that the heater wasn't working but they still pretended that they are working on it! Avoid this place like the plague!!!! Even worse is how they refused to refund me!2.5 stars really, not terrible, but nothing special. Staff was very courteous, lobby nice, rooms average. We were unable to control the room temp with the thermostat and it was quite stuffy. The pool area was pretty dilapidated.This hotel has the potential to be a solid 4-star, but...  it falls a little short.  My husband and I stayed overnight and came to the same conclusions...1)  Room service, Martini lounge, restaurant - while all nice, we thought were pretty overpriced.  For a large pot of coffee from RS, we paid $13, and tipped on that!  Martini's averaged $9 - $12 PER drink at Archimedes.  Dinner was pretty good, but not worth spending  $25+ an entree by any stretch.  The in-room water-in-a-carton was $5.  Really.........?  2) They're not very generous with room items.  Two bath towels are standard, had to ask for more.  The toiletries were "meh"...  I can't use shampoo/conditioner in 1, I have long, thick hair, so just as well I packed my own.  Also, the in-room coffee maker was one-serving, and of course, they leave one regular, one decaf, leaving the couple to fight over who gets the regular, hence our ordering our high dollar coffee via room service.One cool thing is that they're all digital - including menus!  I enjoyed looking over menus on a tablet...    Plus, staff was very nice and helpful.  I have nothing bad to say about any staff experiences.Another great aspect is that it is right there next to Fairlane Mall.It's clean, close to shopping and points of interest, but a bit spendy compared to other places.The hotel is a beautiful structure, but don't let the beautiful lobby fool you.The problem starts with customer service and the administration.  I booked my room through a third party vendor.  The next day once I had flown to Los Angeles I find that my cc had been charged for a full room price in addition to what I had paid the 3rd party vendor.  The customer service from that point was horrible, I could find a manger, and everyone politely passed the buck, or placed me on hold.  My next call is the BBB, I'm sure I won't be placed on hold as long.Very disappointed. Ownership/ management has taken this regal looking building and allowed it to decay--with reference to both the structure and the level of service.On a holiday weekend with the hotel booked to capacity, one elevator did not function, and the rest were stuffed into the others, causing up to 20 minutes to get from your room to the lobby.Understaffed hotel, line out the door in the coffee shop all weekend bc only one person was working. This place has gone in the opposite direction of the neighboring Henry, which had reinvented itself into a beautiful, trendy and contemporary hotel. I'd look into staying there instead in the future.So I booked my room through a third party site at a really good rate for this so called four star hotel for four nights.  The outside and the lobby area look expressive however when I got to my room I thought I was at a 2 star hotel.  This room was very small, no sofa just bed and an awful looking chair.  At one point I went to turn on the standing floor lamp. Upon reaching under the lamp shade for the switch I found the light fixture was off of its base and exposing the wires.  I'm glad my 6 year old didn't try to turn it on.   My 2nd night in Detroit was very cold.  I turned the thermostat up to heat the room expecting a good nights rest.  That morning I learned the heat in the room was not working since me and my family were freezing that same morning.  I called the front desk and was told they would send an engineer to fix the heater ASAP.  When we returned that night I contacted the front desk to make sure we would not freeze again and was assured the problem was fixed.  We got the the room to find a large portable heater.  Not an offer to change our room?  This is not what Ive experienced in a 4 star hotel before.  Each night I would pull our car to the front of the hotel to let my wife a son out so they would not endure the long walk in the cold weather and rain from the free parking lot.  I was never asked by the valet attendant if I wanted to use that service.  I give Adoba Hotel  2 stars for the free parking, free internet and easy check-in.  I won't be back, however I will stay downtown next time.So Im surfing the travel sites looking for a good rate for my third trip ever to Michigan and I see the Adoba Hotel, which excited me because I stayed here 6 months ago and had an incredible time. The hotel is absolutely gorgeous... Glass Elevators!! I rode them like 300 times!!! Anyway... Im looking at some recent reviews and can't believe this is the same place.... Not sure if these people live in castles or if the hotel had some off nights.  I sort of wish I gave the hotel some review love after my trip but no complaints equals no motivation to review.    My experience was quite pleasant, my room was spacious and the bed was super comfortable... so much that I inquired about the mattress type and found it was made by the brand.  I loved the lobby and the pool area. The breakfast buffet is amazing and the last night I stayed I had a ribeye steak that rivals the Ruths Chris that I frequent back home... I still dream about that piece of meat.  I will for sure book there again this time around. DONT LET ME DOWN ADOBA!!!!!Firstly, I just want to explain that the ONLY reason I am not giving this hotel a 5 star is because the pool/hot tub/sauna closes at 10:00pm.I recently booked this hotel through hotwire because I had a 6am flight out of DTW. When we received our confirmation and showed up to the hotel, we were floored! The hotel is absolutely gorgeous inside and the outside looks like some sort of fortress. The front desk staff was super friendly and we even received two free drink tickets to enjoy at the "welcome reception" for new guests.The bed was very comfortable and the room was spacious with two sinks. I would definitely stay here again and would recommend it to others. Although I was only there for a few hours because of my super early flight, I had a great time. The TV wasn't a flat screen which didn't bother us but thought we ought to include it in our review in case that's a deal-breaker for others.Also, it's across from the mall and 15 minutes from DTW.This place is awesome!Stayed one night a while back and it was such a great deal. The place was clean and tastefully decorated. We had an interaction with the manager and she went out of her way to ensure we were happy customers. Even put us on the top floor.Best part mighta been the grub. We got there as they were closing so they treated us to an extra cream puff or five :)No joke...this hotel is SO dry. Bring lots of tissue. You will need it to blow crusty snot from your nose and sop up the blood that is gushing from your nose. :/I stayed at this hotel for 3 days, this past weekend for a dance convention. While I like the whole idea of a green hotel, I wasn't impressed at all.Back when this hotel was The Hyatt Regency, it was super fancy and a nice place to stay. Since it switched to Adoba, it's truly not worth the price point, IMO.My room was not stocked as it should have been. There was no information for room service or local attractions as every other hotel that I have stayed in did. The carpet was worn and warped in a few areas. The bathroom door was filthy and the wallpaper was peeling off of the walls in the sink/coffee area. The only reason that I did not give this hotel 1 star is because the bed and pillows were SO comfortable! Again though...not worth the $120+ a night.The price and location of this hotel support the four-star rating it receives. But, mostly, since we were traveling to Detroit with our 33-lb. dog who travels with us 99% of the time, the fact that they were pet friendly was an added bonuses. Our story begins when we pulled up to the hotel after spending 10 hours on the road (three of which were spent in very bad traffic), we found the valets to be extremely professional, kind, and helpful. They helped unpack a lot of our gear at a late hour in a pleasant demeanor and during our 2-night stay, we continued to find the staff at the hotel to be nothing short of friendly, helpful, and courteous. And as with most service industry folks, if you throw them a little extra green, they will up their level of service even more.  As many yelpers have stated, the hotel was built in the late '70s and the decor was certainly a throwback to a what I call "mid-western Ramada  chic" circa 1987. I have been lucky enough to have been a business traveler in my previous career and also have family in the hotel industry, so I've stayed at some truly exceptional 5-star properties: the Ritz Carlton, A number of Fairmonts, Le Parker Meridien in NYC, some JW Marriotts, so with that said, If you've really got your heart set on a haute coture boutique hotel that would don the pages of Dwell or Vogue, you might want to shift your expectations, but if what you seek is a safe, clean, almost anonymous -feeling hotel (they have 700 rooms), then this place is great as a home base. We felt wonderfully safe at all times, both in the hotel and leaving our car in the parking lot. A large mall is right across the street, so while I'm not a mall shopper, it was definitely nice to be able to run in there for some necessities since we were on the road for two weeks. The distance to the Henry Ford Museum is minimal (go there, it is one of America's best kept secrets). It's also a quick drive to other local points of interest: Dearborn, Corktown, Midtown, Belle Isle, Ferndale, etc. etc. We grabbed a yummy latte in the morning from the Starbucks downstairs since our in-room coffee maker was leaking (my only complaint). I can't give a rating to the onsite bar or restaurants since we're poor grad students who ate out of a cooler most of the time we were there, and when we did splurge to go out to eat or drink, we preferred to have a bite out in Detroit to support the local businesses. We loved our experience and would have no problem staying there again given the fact that it's Detroit and is very much a town still rebuilding itself. My last and most important observation is that the bed was extremely comfortable and clean and as far as hotel experiences go, this is the biggest thing I care about after traversing around town all day.
review_content_40: From the moment I walked in I was impressed. The hotel was immaculate.  This was previously the Hyatt so I wasn't too surprised. The check-in process was a breeze and I was very impressed with Nicholas who assisted me. I felt like he took ownership in his job and I could tell he liked working there. He explained the layout of the hotel in detail and even pointed out how they were "going green".  He also told me about the "organic" menu at the on-site restaurant.The beds are great and the rooms what I would expect from a former Hyatt hotel.  Definitely on the nicer side of things.  I recommend trying it out!Love the banquet hall! Wedding reception went great with the staff really helpful and on pointOur organization has a contract for our conferences 2 day stay over, for the last 2 years I have gone and it has progressive gotten worse.  The lamp had no switch has to screw the blub off and on. Carpet is in terrible condition in the rooms and in some of the corridors on the main floor and above.  It is mended with duct tape or gorilla tape lots of it. I was charged 15.00 a day for parking. Outrageous.  Rooms are overpriced next year I will be stay at another hotel as will my friends that came with me. The employees were very good. But management sucks.NOTE: My rating is based on the hotel's venue, event planing and wedding services, not the hotel stay as I cannot comment on that.I was very underwhelmed by the staff and front desk who may not be treating guests at an event with the same care as they would paying guests. We came there for an event (so we were not paying hotel guests but still a guest). We were looking for a place to hang our hat before the event (about 2 hours to kill in between) and we came to find out that if you weren't a paying for a hotel room and in possession of drink tickets, you can't get a drink anywhere..even in the restaurant, they refused to serve us a drink unless we paid for a room and had drink tickets...seriously ?!?!!? I'm sure there must be some reason for this hotel to do this..but I have never seen this out of any good hotel I've been for an event.I know I will likely not host any of my events (or recommend it) here as my guests would have to drive away from the hotel to relax and have a drink in between the event if they didn't have a room for the night.If I were this hotel and someone was hosting an event in the ballrooms, I would get a stack of tickets or at least allow guests of the event to sit at the bar and have a drink during the lull times.Oh..one other point..no one on the front desk will tell you that the restaurant also won't serve you without a ticket (even if u get an appetizer) . So, either the front desk has no idea about the hotel or they just didn't want to say no....overall..it may be a great hotel with a great bed but it must be they have some bad element nearby to have such an unheard of policy with drink tickets (and no one really wants to let you know until you directly ask)..I can't think of any other reason nor have I ever experienced such a policy.I checked in on New Year's Eve and I didn't get much sleep because some hoodlums were in the room next door blasting music til well after 1am. I Called front desk to complain and they didn't do anything about it, so I slept with headphones in. The next night my husband requested an extra blanket at around 10, so someone brought up a blanket, knocking on the door, prompting my dog to bark briefly until the knocking stopped. After that, management called my room at 11:30 pm and asked me if I had an animal in my room. I guess the genius check in clerk didn't mark it down and charge me appropriately. I was holding my dog upon check in. Why disturb me that late and bother me with your staffs mistake? The Unprofessional management here also claimed that my dog almost "bit" one of the housekeepers earlier that day. Funny how a dog can bite someone from inside a crate. My dog is 4lbs and has never bit anyone! He Also lied and said he stood outside of my door for 25 minutes and listened to my dog bark nonstop, which was also false. (Don't you have better things to do anyways?!) My dog has a shock collar. He also stated that he was doing me a favor by not relocating my room because I wasn't in a "pet friendly room" (the stains on the carpet tell me otherwise) This place claims they're "pet friendly" but management obviously hates animals. Will never stay here again!Very nice lobby area and check in.  Get three complimentary drinks.  The elevators are very fast and there are five of them.  The rooms were nice, nothing special but very clean.  I really liked this hotel for its price range.Very nice hotel, rooms & beds were very comfortable. Wish we could have stayed here a few more days. The lady that checked us in was very friendly. Upon check in, they had cupcakes, cold water, and were given drink tickets at the front desk. Restaurants were a short drive away.I like this hotel. We stayed to get away from home.  It's quite pretty we liked the restaurant too and not many hotels around here have a sauna. Nice staff.  We changed rooms because the first one had the tv on the side and the swivel wasn't enough to see from the bed.  Next room had heat issues but nothing out of the ordinary. We got the room online for under $100. I would stay here again.Good hotel. I got it off of hotwire for a great price. Lobby and service are extremely nice and helpful. The room are okay. They do not match the swankiness of the lobby, but they are clean and quiet. The lobby and service are  4-star quality, the room is 3-star. Internet a little slow, but okay. It might have just been the room location.If it is the right price, this is a solid hotel, but it is not overall a 4-star hotel like it is indicated on some sites.This is the hotel formerly known as the Hyatt.  It is a new Green hotel and has been getting better and better each and every day. The staff is working hard to make it all work while maintaining a green atmosphere.Check out happy hour in the lobby bar for fun! The food upstairs is really great!Things are sliding down hill a little here. We visited for an event and hoped to get a glass of wine. We learned their liquor license had lapsed. No wine for you!If I could rate this an absolute zero I would.  This place use to be a Hyatt but is an absolute dump now.  There is mold in the showers and the service is horrendous.  We had a work event here and the phones have been out for days, I was in a supposedly clean room and a day later I went to throw something in the trash only to find dirty diapers.  I could understand if this slipped by the cleaning person for one day but not two!Really nice and quiet.They are pursuing a green and eco-friendly business plan, with the in hotel restaurant being predominately Organic. Great restaurant by the way.Really nice staff, was driven in a complimentary town car to a business meeting this morning. When I arrived and they checked my ID I was given 5 drink tickets for a complimentary wine or beer in the lobby every evening from 5 till 10.Some of these may have been extra features due to it being the off season and the hotel not being full for a convention. Nevertheless a really superb place.The hotel is decent... Rooms could be and should be upgraded for the price!!! The tv is old, the phones are old, the iron is old, the bathroom is extremely tiny. No menu for food had to try and read it off of the blurry old school tv... For a random nights stay it would do the job i guess. The Henry across the way is way better.This is a 1970s style and it doesn't clean up well with the Reno because it is so dark inside - the pool and gym are really dated and the surrounding area looks like dated suburbia - boring place to stay -I cannot comment on the rooms themselves, because we never made it to that point.  I was in town overnight with my mother to pick my father up from the hospital.  We had booked the Adoba hours before we arrived, and we did not arrive until late, especially because we went to see my father before we went to the hotel.  Immediately after making the reservation I called the hotel to find out their exact pet policy (I knew they were "pet friendly", but that was it), as we had a couple of small dogs with us.  I was only told that it was a $30 charge per dog.  This was acceptable.  The hotel was booked in my mothers name so when we arrived at nearly midnight she went to check in.  She was told that the hotel required a 3 day notice for pets, and that if they were to give us a room (which they wouldn't) it would be a $75 charge per dog.  This, obviously, is more than double what the girl told me just a few hours earlier, and she had not made a single mention of the 3 day notice policy.  I am astonished that a business would feel it acceptable to blatantly lie about their policy.  Needless to say, we were put in the position of trying to track down another room at midnight, when this could have been done earlier in the day, which was the last thing we needed to deal with after the stress of the previous week.Absolutely HORRIFIC.  DO NOT STAY HERE.  It is truly run like a flop house.  It is a run down Hyatt with a new name.  The restaurant is a glorified, OVER-PRICED buffet, they do not have room service (well, they will say they do, but I assure you they DO NOT), carpets are stained, lounges are covered with table cloths over the registers because they do not have a beer, wine or liquor license...just a terrible experience from start to finish.

hotel_name: The Dearborn Inn, A Marriott Hotel
review_content: Ended up here on a business trip and glad I did! Wonderful staff and great food. I especially enjoyed the apple pie and homemade vanilla ice cream !!I stayed in this place about 5times. It is gradually becoming worst. One thing to be a historic hotel and there is another thing being horrible in maintaining the place. Last two times, they sticked me to the Burkbank house which is worst than a motel 6. The rooms smelled like mildew. The carpet was old. The Computer chair was old and bed was sagging. Worst was the shower. TINY ! You can not face the shower and raise your left arm because the wall was there. you have to shampoo your hair sideway. The iron  in the room was from the 1980's and no heat. Brown steam came out. I suppose the main building is better but DEFINITELY NOT THE BURBANK HOUSE !I am done with this one. Had the Herny hotel was soldout, I would have stayed there with similar price. Even the Courtyard on Mercury drive has bigger rooms and showers as compare to this so called historic hotel. Time has past them by. Dont stay there !Pretty hotel.  The main lobby area is beautiful.  Pros- easy way to get to Henry Ford.  Rooms are clean, nice desk area.   Easy place to stay when attending a wedding close by the hotelCons- parking situation is a bit confusing.  You have to check in in one building then drive to another building where your room is.  They have multiple buildifs so it was difficult to know where to park and to find which building was which.+ beautiful building, friendly staff-  pricey, tiny rooms, needs renovationsI stayed here for a couple of nights for a wedding.  The front desk staff was very nice to us at check-in.  The room on the other hand was super small, you could hardly move around.  The bathroom in the room was also very small.  As I walk around the hotel, it is a nice place, but you can see some hallways and floors that just look too tired and are in need of updating.  Staying here was just not worth the premium we paid.The wedding was nice and the food was good, nothing outstanding.Good hotel and meeting/conference space. Historic property with modern rooms. I have had some rooms there that were very large, with sitting area and TV, etc.  Great Location in relation to Henry-Ford related tourist sites. Property has important and interesting regional history. Pretty good restaurant and bar as well. Well trained restaurant staff sometimes sloppy like anywhere but all in all a good spot to stay, eat or both.I have attended many solid conferences there and it would be a nice place for a wedding.I've stayed here twice now, and nothing but pleasant things to say. The staff is super friendly with multiple greeting points, reception is more than willing to accommodate room requests. The beds were surprisingly comfortable (almost feels like a pillow/foam topper or something) and clean. Bathroom/shower is easy to use.Oh, and if you're hungry, the bar inside the hotel in the main building is open until 11pm. Huge beer list (managed to snag a bottle of Boddington's Pub Ale) and good food. I got the chicken scallopine and creme brulee, and both were delicious.Definitely coming back here if in the Dearborn area. Oh, and it's owned by Marriott, so make sure you have your rewards number!I have heard so many great things about their brunches held here I had to see for myself ~  Confirmed!  Extraordinary! Our family decided to come here for Mother's Day Brunch held in the Grand Ballroom.   The ballroom itself is so beautiful! The gorgeous chandeliers and white linen complete the elegant ambience.  There is a delectable buffet spread that is almost artful! it's spread out so every dish isn't on top of each other.  There is a great variety of mouth watering food to choose from such as salmon, salads, omelets, lamb and desserts to die for!  The prime rib especially was cooked to perfection as it melted in your mouth!  Service here is pristine.  Kim, who originally took my reservation over the phone, was there to greet us and check us in.  Our waitress, Clarisa, was very attentive and personable.  She really helped make my mom feel very special! The gentlemen working the omelet station, carving station and waffle station were very polite and friendly.  Every employee we talked with deserve a round of applause for knowing how to treat every guest.  It was such a pleasure!I would come back again in a heartbeat!  It is definitely worth it for the great service but also the historical value of the property itself.  It's great to explore around the beautiful site!Stayed for a night and was immediately impressed with the grounds although one of the dorms is being renovated. The main lobby is beautiful as is the sitting room just beyond the main entrance. We were placed at the McGuffey dorm and noticed that there are no mini-fridges in the room.  Room wasn't anything spectacular but I have no complaints as this is a "historic" hotel. The outdoor pool was terrific. No spa. The bar was nicely updated as was Emerson's restaurant where we had a terrific brunch. I would definitely recommend.This was my fifth or sixth stay at the Dearborn Inn in Dearborn, Michigan and by far it is my favorite property to stay at if I'm in the Metro Detroit area.  It is located next to Ford's headquarters (which means you'll see experimental cars being tested in camouflage), with easy access to the Metropolitan Airport, downtown, and Ann Arbor if you have a car to get around.The hotel is furnished in a traditional decor and is set on a large, grassy property.  It has a concierge's lounge, quality room service, free parking, and exercise facilities.  Basically everything I look for during a business trip at a reasonable price.  When I'm in Detroit for work, this is where I'll stay.Great hotel, excellent service, very well maintained and clean.  What more can I say?  The staff is very friendly and helpful.The food was wonderful, the breakfast buffet in particular can't be beat.  We ended up eating all of our meals at the hotel because everything was so fresh, tasty and reasonably priced.I would definitely stay here again.This place is very convenient but don't be fooled by the dinner they provide here. I was helping out for Dearborn High School prom event and all of the guests received a three course meal. Lasagna was burned from the top layer. Salad is hand cut ( not pre chopped for you) Cheesecake was alright and the service was kinda slow. But overall very beautiful place to book!I only stayed one night but this was like an oasis in the middle of a desert. Wow! The lobby is huge and beautiful. Great gym. Friendly beautiful staff that were very helpful. Room was nice. Bathroom was a tight squeeze with little room for my big toiletry bag. No shower cap amenity which is annoying. They offer valet parking for $12 but the self park space is right next to the hotel and free. I will seek out this hotel in the future.Classic and historic with a beautiful lobby and restaurant.  I chose this property because it offered the same rate (a package) as the Courtyard a few miles away which I stay at often for business.Pros:  Friendly Staff, terrific location to the Henry Ford (museum and Greenfield village). The outdoor pool is the best I've seen outside a resort.  It is huge and has a 12 foot deep section and lap section.  My kids loved it for over 2 hours. Excellent buffet breakfast on Sunday.  Free wi-fi and Shuttle service to/from Greenfield Village.Cons:  Room was extremely small and dated. We were not informed that they had or we'd be staying in a building not connected to the hotel.  I was told our room was a bit larger than those in the main building.  While the bathroom was modern, the mattress in one of the beds sagged.  Luckily we were there for one night only because for four of us, we were very, very cramped.  The hotel offers room service but there would be no room to eat it for four people unless we ate in bed (which we did for our carryout).  I would not stay here again with the family and would instead stay at the Courtyard 3 miles away which offers larger rooms.  The upsetting part was that I checked the sq. footage of both properties and the courtyard's rooms were only a few sq. feet bigger but in reality, they are much larger.  With luggage, we had no room to walk around and no view.  At least at the Courtyard hotel, I could have received a balcony or patio with a view of a quiet courtyard.  As a Marriott Elite member, I expected a better room but was disappointed as I have stayed in much nicer rooms in the last two months at Best Western, Hampton Inn, Holiday Inn Express, and certainly Courtyard by Marriott.  But if you are staying for one night in the summer and have kids,you cannot find a better pool!There's a lot of history here. This is nice to admire when you're strolling the grounds, however it makes things a bit cumbersome when you're spending the night.  The rooms are on the smaller side, and while this might be a 4 star hotel by European standards, things are bit shabby.  The heating/cooling was wonky on both of my stays.  The hot water in the bathroom sink only made it to lukewarm, which made shaving quite an adventure (which I suppose is not an issue if you have a beard or are a woman).  There are not many outlets in the room.   However, there is free, good Wifi. Maid service was so-so. The onsite restaurants and bar are good options, free parking is ample, and you are a short drive to downtown Dearborn (if such a place exists), Greenfield village, and Detroit. As far as Marriotts go, this is more in line with a Courtyard experience, and is an ok option if you're in Dearborn for a few days.Nicely done, well maintained, but a few low end items that make it disappointing for the price.  There was no hotel map, so I went to the front desk to ask where the fitness room was. At 8:40 AM, when one would think it is the busy time of checkout, there was one person at the front desk. The front desk person made a point of assisting an employee before a paying customer.  Nice. Then, since it was morning, I decided I wanted to have coffee by the fireplace. I looked around and did not see a coffee service so I want to the bar. They told me they had coffee for purchase. I asked at the front desk, and they said that they did not have a coffee service available. No coffee when paying over $200 a night?  That is common at Hampton, and even days in.  I guess Marriott doesn't feel the same way. It's the details Marriott. You should know know.Beware! Bedbugs! I have pictures and video still! I forget which building my room was in, but it had bedbugs and they had to switch my room in the middle of the night after claiming they didnt have bedbugs. Two associates from the hotel visited my room after I called the front desk to see for themselves. Luckily, I was there for a wedding and was so tired that I left my bags with the bellhop.The next morning, I expected a courtesy call from the front desk or even the hotel manager, but nothing! Then they tried to charge me full price for both nights and I put up a stink! They gave me a reduced rate on the one night, so I wrote corporate! I never heard back from them either. Needless to say, I do not stay at any Marriott properties anymore.Its a shame because it was a cute place with lots of history and a good restaurant. It was fascinating to read about the history of the hotel and see all the pictures they have hanging up. Henry Ford would have been mad, but he probably would have hooked me up too and at least extended a sincere apology!This was our first stay, and definitely not our last! Overall, the staff was pleasant.  It's a beautiful facility.  It's quiet, clean and comfortable.  We had the breakfast buffet one morning and it was delicious.  We upgraded to a cottage which had it's own appeal.  Our next stay will be in the hotel itself just from a convenience standpoint.  The only hassle with the cottage is getting ice.  The closest ice machine was in the hotel at the end of one of the wings.Beautiful renovation, elegant and comfortable. Beds were comfortable, grounds are lovely (even in December!) Complaints: no mini fridge in room, no hair dryer, breakfast buffet moderate at best.However the bar food was good, wonderful bartenderAnother meeting??? What, you call it a presentation? One of our tooling suppliers had a dog and pony show for all of the engineers at Ford.  There was a nice turn out. They do a great job here at the Dearborn Inn for meetings, water bottles, pitchers of water during the meeting and a nice continental breakfast. Lunch was outstanding as well as the steak dinner. The wait staff was outstanding. Did I mention all the food was great?If I'm throwing an offsite meeting or training or any type of presentation, I'm calling here first.I hosted a Christmas luncheon for a customer here and had a great time. They had a lunch buffet with excellent meats, salads, sides and dessert. I will be doing this again next year for sure.Staff was great and the amenities were amazing. Highly recommend!
review_content_20: I had my wedding this past weekend in Dearborn and since the reception was nearby, we had all our guests stay at the Dearborn Inn. I've had my out-of-town family stay here for years when they were in town, and I was not disappointed with this experience.Our guests were treated extremely well (most from out of country). We dropped off gift bags and the reception staff seemed happy to deliver them. Great attitudes!The lobby is always gorgeous and the grounds were cause for a conversation topic amongst our wedding guests. Beautiful flowers and gardens make for a really special place for guests to stay, especially if they have some time to kill while in-town people are busy. Free tickets to The Henry Ford Greenfield Village are amazing, since that's my favorite place in the entire world. :)Our honeymoon suite was wonderful, with chocolate dipped strawberries and lots of room. Although I was exhausted from a long day of smiling for cameras, I appreciated the nice touches before I crashed hard and slept like a rock.The rooms are a bit small, because the hotel is old, but I can't even fault them a star for that. They're tidy, super clean, and well maintained, and the service staff is super friendly and ready to do anything to make guests feel extra welcome.I'm not often a 5-star reviewer, but I can't recommend Dearborn Inn enough for people who are traveling to Dearborn or people who are planning to host a wedding in the area. Enjoy the ambience and never look back!Love this hotel and have been going here for years. The front desk staff was outstanding and very accommodating, as well as the wait staff at Ten Eyke tavern. I couldn't give 5 stars for the simple reason of the concierge lounge. The evening food was almost inedible and the employee, Paulette, sat with us (actually took the best seat) and did crossword puzzles while we fended for ourselves. She was in uniform with a nametag yet did nothing but sit there the entire time. I think the hotel can find a more suitable "job" for her......Unexpectedly very nice place. The grounds were wonderful and the rooms very nice and overall very clean. I was pleasantly surprised by the stay, the only downside is it was slightly challenging to find a place to eat as you are literally surrounded by Ford.I was here as part of a digital summit for bloggers held by Ford. The catering for lunch wasn't the best (however the cookies were amazing), but the grounds are beautiful and the wifi was great. I would definitely stay here next time I'm in the area.Dear Dearborn Inn,Thanks for the nice, albeit short, visit. I especially appreciate the incredibly comfortable bed, complete with a handful of squishy (read: goose down) pillows and the firm yet soft mattress. Detroit has a lot to offer and I'm glad to see a really lovely and charming hotel so close to Greenfield Village. Henry Ford would be stoked. Even though your lobby is awfully pretty, your rooms are a little bit stale. I was a bit disappointed for the lack of mini fridge or mini bar. My poor pizza leftovers from Buddy's had to be tossed for fear that I would wake up smelling of pizza. No one needs that. And I have to say, the shower sprayer in particular is incredibly awkward. Even though I'm vertically challenged, I had a hell of a time showering with limited water pressure and a crappy handheld sprayer. But I digress.Your room service was quick, your staff quite friendly and included toiletries were decent. I didn't get a chance to visit the workout room or garden, but I hear they are both pretty solid. Maybe next time we can spend a little more time together and WiFi can be gratis? Here's hoping. Yours truly,Snacks McGeeI've been to the Dearborn Inn a couple of times recently for various large events in the ballrooms. For dinner, I've had an amazing chicken dish at one event and lousy, cold, tasteless pasta at another. I stayed consistent in my drink order as well. One event my drink had alot of booze. The other had less than a shot. What's with the inconsistencies?The room we had was small and our bed was even smaller. The description said we paid for a queen. The bed was either a double or full. After a long night of dancing, the last thing I wanted to be was pushed off the bed the whole night and in a fight for pillows.Beautiful hotel, great location, nice employees. But otherwise very inconsistent.I've stayed at The Dearborn Inn quite a few times. I've stayed in king rooms in the main building just for traveling, the large suites in the main building for family holiday parties, and the large suites in the annexed building for a friend's wedding. I love the rooms in the main building, they have a lot of character, but find the rooms in the annexed building to be a bit more generic. The Dearborn Inn is very accommodating to large groups, has a gorgeous lobby, especially during the holidays, and even the ballrooms are wonderful (went to a prom here back in the day). I also love their brunch...and the robes!It's very close to Greenfield Village (though I'm not sure if we're calling it that these days?) and basically anything you'd want to do in Dearborn!Pretty inn that I've never been ashamed to recommend to friends when they come into town. Within walking distance of Greenfield Village, it was once an airport for Henry Ford.Rooms are nice and the restaurants are good. If you travel up Oakwood to Michigan Avenue, you will find an active nightlife!Sometimes you just gotta feel as though you're working off a bender with Zelda Fitzgerald. The environment, decor and energy of The Dearborn Inn will make you feel as though you have stepped through time to enter a world of underscored glamour -- but not glamour in its opulent, gilded sense. Glamour in the "I spied that sickly-looking Colin peering down upon me from his bedroom window" sense. I felt like I was the ne'er-do-well cousin sent to live with the well-behaved side of the family whilst my parents set out for a better life. In other words, all of my high school AP English conceits were met. History is the selling point. The entrance is stately, the lobby is impressively proper, the grounds will make you feel as though you're an incoming freshman at your boarding school/university of choice -- where jackets are required. This isn't a 'oh, you fancy' or 'g-l-a-m-o-r-ous, yes' type of place. It's a mansion. The typical guest (during my stay) were gray-haired and buffet-loving. But, I don't need a rock-star life all the time. Sometimes, I hanker for a quiet, well-groomed hotel with red brick, stately columns, white terraces, and manicured lawns. This isn't a hotel to stay in if you want the hustle and bustle of a city. Stay here for a peaceful quiet respite. Stroll the grounds. Wear pearls.Expect colonial furniture in the bedroom, high-thread count sheets, cherry wood, small walk-in closet. I stayed on the 4th (highest) floor and enjoyed a pleasantly spacious room that included two walls of windows with views of trees and grass, overstuffed chairs, sturdy (and impressive) desk, and a lounge. As I am given to flights of dramatic fainting, lounges are always welcome. I had a perfectly suitable bathroom (nice flooring, marble to add texture, enough room to move around)Charming. You will be charmed -- in the Jane Austen, not Alyssa Milano, sense.I've always wanted to visit Detroit and recently visited for the first time.Keeping it real, here, folks and telling you what you need to know.Positives:-charming historic Inn where the common areas really make you feel like you're stepping back in time to the 30s when Henry Ford would visit the dining room-one free (small) bottle of water in the room-luxe beds with high thread count linens (I slept well)-back garden has a lovely lounge area with umbrellas-decent fitness center-extremely courteous staff-lobby area has a display with the hotel's interesting history-bathrobes in roomNeutral:-Bath and Body works products= something between a "meh" and an "AOK"Negatives:-no free wifi-the bathroom seemed downright institutional with bars and a shower chair which was weird. I'm pretty sure they gave me a handicapped room. Was the hotel that crowded that they needed to give me such a room? I also feel strongly that just because someone may be in a wheelchair doesn't mean that an institutional bathroom is the way to go. -the hairdryer is hidden behind ironing board in closet. I don't blame them for hiding the fact that the hairdryers seemed like they had been made in the 1980s and it took me about 15 minutes to dry my hair. It also smelled of burnt hair. UGH-house keeping didn't replace the bottle of water I had drank and the large bottle that costs $5 had already been opened by someone who had stayed there before me which is really gross. Tip: if you can, just get a cup of water from the fitness center where they have a water coolerThe following is a negative for me, but might be a positive for someone else: It's rather remote, so that if you don't have a car, you're reliant upon someone who does; ie no early morning coffee from a real coffee place (sucks for a coffee fanatic like me) and if you're hungry late at night after the lounge is closed and room service is over, you're SOL, as there is no mini bar in the room either.If you do have a car, awesome, because Dearborn is a cool suburb with good eateries nearby, not to mention what I like to call "Ford World" ie, the Henry Ford theme park, I mean, Henry Ford complex/park.Conclusion: It's really not worth the high price of a stay, considering the lack of room amenities.Strongly recommend. Lots of history. Great ambiance. Marriott level service which is premier.We were attending a Wedding at the hotel and we decided to spend the night rather than drink and then go home. The hotel is steeped in history. We were walking to one of the ballrooms and passed a room called the Edison room and sure enough, there was an old picture of Thomas Alva himself. It looked to be about a century old. Henry Ford, Thomas Edison, Harvey Firestone and other famous folks were all buddies and they all walked the same hallways that I walked when I visited the hotel. Going to a museum is one thing, but living there is quite another.The food in the restaurants and what we were served at the catered affair, was all very good and the hotel service was great too.The room we had was comfortable and well-appointed. The walls were a bit thin but with the air conditioning running, the noise level was not obvious.This is a place that I would recommend to others and I would be comfortable putting friends and business associates.Dearborn Inn is top notch when it comes to class. The lobby of the hotel is gorgeous and perfect for wedding photos. The courtyard is very spacious, the gazebo right in the middle of the courtyard makes for a perfect setting for an outdoor wedding. Aside from the main building, there are also several detached houses on the opposite side of the courtyard, each containing 4 beautiful suites. I stayed there the night before the wedding and my wedding night, and because of the honeymoon package, each day we got a bottle of champagne and chocolate covered strawberries. The rooms in the suites are just as quaint as the rest of the hotel. I ordered room service breakfast for the day of my wedding, and it was delivered at 9:45am (at the time I requested) on the dot. The hotel bar is just as classy as the rest of the establishment. Drinks aren't the cheapest, but you really shouldn't be going there for drinks if you're expecting to get a 36oz beer for $3.50. I had relatives from out of country stay there and everyone raved about the hotel. I highly recommend it for any out of town guests, or if you just want to "fall off the grid" for an evening by yourself.Love this hotel except I wish the furnishings inside the rooms was less modern and more vintage... It used to be vintage and then they modernized it and it needs to be more of the period.Went here on a family vacation to see Ford Motor Co. Very convenient to all of Ford sites. We found the rooms adequate and comfortable. The restaurants were good and prices reasonable. Offered us transportation to the sites close by where we could connect to sites further away. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful. One of our daughters' favorite stories is being stuck in the elevator at the Dearborn Inn and having to be rescued by maintenance.My favourite hotel in Detroit bar and restaurant are brilliant, the fresh breakfast omelettes are a must along with the fresh muffinsGreat location! Walking distance to the Ford Museum and Greenfield Village, but they also provide prompt and frequent drivers to same. Good value: room included vouchers to the museum and Ford attractions, and a safety depot box. Attractive, traditional decor. Clean, bright interiors and beautiful grounds. Rooms quiet, good beds - great night sleep. The staff is excellent, excepting the lounge where we sat unattended for a while then left. Room service was prompt and they got the order right. Staff very friendly and helpful. Food is mid-west nice. If we visit the Henry Ford again, we'll definitely stay here!I stayed at the Dearborn Inn in DEC 2012. While the hotel is nicely decorated and holds a lot of history, you may want to reconsider actually staying here.I reserved a 4 night stay, but upon check-in I was informed the actual price was twice the price I was quoted. When I questioned this I was told by the clerk that reservations are not handled by the hotel, they are handled through a call center and he was sorry for the error but there was nothing he could do. I took the room (#406) and went about my businessAfter arriving at my room I found it to be small; smaller than my bedroom at home. I was not the guest room advertised on their website (cache.marriott.com/prope...). There was barely enough room to walk at the foot of the bed and forget getting around to the far side of the bed as the walkway was blocked by a sitting chair. The lavatory was comparably small and uncomfortable to use. I can't imagine trying to stay in this room with more than one personLater that night my nephew checked in and we asked for rooms close to each other and he was assigned room #404. His room was approximately 3 feet larger than my room (right next door). While this isn't a huge difference, it made it seem a lot larger due to the already small area. I said that, to say this; if you choose to stay at this hotel, inspect the room and if you find it unreasonably small, request to see another because chances are you'll find one a little bit larger. I assumed all guest rooms were the same, so didn't think to request another (besides they probably would have wanted to up-charge me).Another point of interest; the guest rooms do not have free wi-fi. If you want in-room wi-fi, you'll have to pay an additional $12.95 (+tax) per day.The day after check-in I met up w/ a couple friends who were staying at The Henry (another Marriott hotel 5 mins away) and couldn't believe they were paying the same rate as me. They had an indoor pool, hottub, sauna, workout room and free in-room wi-fi. I immediately went to the courtesy desk and asked the clerk to call The Dearborn Inn and see if she could relocate my reservation, which she did.If you find yourself looking for a hotel in the Dearborn area, I do not recommend you stay at the Dearborn Inn. Do yourself a favor and check out The Henry.This hotel is gorgeous. Very stunning to stay the least. I had an all-around experience with this establishment as I attended a company holiday party there and afterward stayed in one of the beautiful and charming rooms. The whole evening, start to finish, was incredible. The evening began with a cocktail hour in the lobby area of the hotel. Service was excellent. Note: even the lobby area was fancy-smanchy. The cocktail hour ended and the entire party was moved to a huge ballroom. There were roughly 500 attendees to the event so needless to say, the ballroom was uber-huge. The tables/chairs were well-placed and again the service was great. The food was to die for but I can't remember if it was catered in or from the hotel restaurant so I'll skip the details of my meal. After my meal, the party continued in the ballroom where they moved some tables and had a dance floor available.
