The prices aren't too crazy, and the quality of the food is good.  The portions are enormous (but that is true of everywhere in Detroit!).The Facilities: are okay.  The lobby is fantastic.  The fitness room is on par with most similar hotels- a treadmill and dumbbells up to 50 pounds.  The pool looks nice, though it was closed for most of my stay.  A penthouse restaurant is currently being built, and should be open soon.What didn't I like?  The interior soundproofing was a big lacking; noise from the hallways and adjoining rooms sometimes carried quite a distance.  At night, the elevators can be faintly heard.Overall I would recommend the Crowne Plaza for a stay downtown.I like this hotel! Comfortable beds, nice front desk staff, nice restaurant and bar staff, nice valet staff. They have a little hybrid Starbucks in the lobby that makes the more popular Starbucks drinks. It's only about 3 blocks from the GM building and across the street from the convention center. The room that I stayed in had a great view of the bridge to Canada with a pointed window. There isn't much in the immediate vicinity of the hotel, but if you walk a few blocks, there are lots of bars and restaurants, even a little casino. If there is someplace you want to go and you don't have a car, the valet will take you where you want to go within a reasonable distance, but they will also call a cab or uber for you if you need to go far. They took me and my coworker to whole foods about 5 mins away and waited for us! The customer service at this hotel is awesome. The only complaint I have is their housekeeping staff is SUPER LOUD while cleaning the other rooms. At times I work odd hours, so I sleep odd hours, and they woke me up :( Other than that, super comfortable!!!Took advantage of a Travel Zoo discount which gave a 1 night stay + breakfast at the Jefferson House for only $99. The hotel is modern & clean, the rooms have great views of downtown, and the breakfast was tasty and featured giant portions. Knowledgable & helpful desk staff. One block away from the financial district people mover stop.I can't say enough about our stay this past weekend. From the valet to the bellman to the front desk and restaurant staff... it was lovely. As a former Ritz Carlton employee, I am aware of stellar 5 star service, and they delivered time and time again. The location could not be better. Our views of the city were breathtaking. The staff is what made the trip so much more than I had imagined. Very particular attention to detail and the needs for our weekend. Having grown up in Michigan I am so excited to share my experience and hope that others follow suit and stay at the Crowne plaza. Nicole and Dawn at the front desk are always helpful and pleasant. The bellmen, and others you meet in the elevators are genuine and friendly. Valet is on top of it, always... Even with our multi-vehicle situation. Breakfast was outstanding. The GM, Charles was present and helpful as well. Highly recommend staying here, and we will always when visiting Detroit.We stayed at the newly renovated Crowne Plaza for only one night while attending an event at Cobo Center across the street from it. Our experience was similar to many of the other reviewers' but more positive:(+) The staff were extremely friendly but (-) not always sure of how things are supposed to work there -- for example, I was given two different answers by two different people when I asked how much it would cost me to keep the car in their garage for a few hours past my checkout time.(+) The interior of the room was new. The bed and the linens were very comfortable.(-) In the evening, we waited forever for hot water to come and ended up taking a lukewarm shower. (+) In the morning though, hot water came right away.(+) The view was nothing short of spectacular. Our room overlooked downtown and we could see a bit on the river on the side. (-) The WiFi connection was a bit spotty, only one or two bars. Enough to read / send emails but not adequate for video streaming.($) Valet parking was $25 per day with in and out privileges. Parking at the Cobo rooftop is $10 per day, there is no in/out and you can't leave the car overnight.(+) The location is perfect: Cobo is across the street, People Mover is at Cobo and can take you to Greektown shops, food and entertainment.(+++) The restaurant downstairs is not cheap but the food is outstanding. Salads would be $15-$19 including your proteins, and other entrees are $22 - $35. The restaurant staff were super courteous and knowledgeable. Honestly, this was the biggest surprise. We didn't expect much from this restaurant and were blown away by their food.Would I stay here again? Absolutely. As long as they keep their prices reasonable.We stayed here for my husband's holiday party last weekend.  The valet/main entrance is not very well marked and it's difficult to wind back around as you are in downtown Detroit.  The front lobby was beautiful, but the staff did not even greet me.  I'm obviously pregnant and was dragging a suitcase, plus carrying my camera bag and purse and not a word, not an offer of help, nothing.  We were given a corner room, which was small, but offered an amazing view of the river, Ren Cen and Cobo.  The shower had to be cranked all the way to hot to give me a warm enough shower, the separate dressing area from the bathroom was wonderful but the bed was not overly comfortable.The staff working the holiday party on the 25th floor were very nice, but the food left alot to be desired.  I had chicken piccatta and I'm fairly certain they made the chicken that morning and possibly microwaved it.  Everyone at our table was having such a difficult time cutting their chicken that water sloshed out of several glasses.  We would possibly consider going back, but it would take a heck of a deal.This was the highlight of our stay at downtown Detroit! We came here for the weekend for the Auto Show at the Cobo Center. The Crowne is a perfect location. And we had a room with a view!! A beautiful corner room with floor to ceiling windows on either corner and the bed facing out. The room looked out onto Windsor, across the river. The GM building was lit up at night and we could see almost 180 degrees from the GM building to the Cobo Center. The room itself was very small but given the view, this was less important. I didn't like that you walk into the room and practically walk right into the bathroom. The bathroom should have been set off a little from the front door. Also, I was a little skeptical as I walked down the hallway for the first time. It felt like a cheap apartment building, with big, beige metal doors that seemed exceptionally narrow and dizzying carpet designs. The entire building smelled and felt clean, though. The lobby was welcoming and seemed nice. The front desk staff seemed cheery and welcoming, though not very knowledgeable when it came to recommending restaurants or modes of transportation. We had to ask a number of people before we finally decided to just Google/Yelp ideas. Figured we'd start by asking the locals. Better to do the research on your own, we found. Valet parking was a hassle. We tried parking across the street on Friday night (~11:30pm) and thankfully, the parking attendant was blunt with us, informing us that cars are broken into on a nightly basis and that they leave the lot at midnight. They recommended the hotel valet parking. We did this, for ~$20/day. When we went to pick up our car on our way out on our last day, it seemed extremely disorganized. There was no where warm to wait. And our wait was a solid 25 minutes. Granted, there were a number of people waiting for their cars, so the valet guys were very busy and were doing the best they could. They just seem to need a better system. The people in front of us were getting frustrated, as they were brought the wrong car three times! I would stay at this hotel again if I ever visited downtown Detroit again. It seems like the best option available within walking distance to anything. And it must have the best view.When we first arrived everything went smoothly. The room was comfortable and the front desk service worked well. But after our check out the valet service "lost" our car upon checkout. We had to wait slightly over a hour to find our car. It was hidden behind two other larger cars underneath the hotel. Don't stay here. Not worth your time.My husband and I recently stayed at the historic Ponchartrain now Crowne Plaza Detroit Downtown.I will start with the positive.  The view is amazing, and the building itself was constructed to maximize the views.  Very cool. The price was not high, not low...  the high end of medium I guess would be a good way to describe it.The room service- very good!  Very, very delicious breakfastRealistically - they have ALOT of work to do when it comes to service.  I hate to say this, but sitting and waiting like idiots for a valet that doesn't exist with no sign to clue you into the fact that there is actually no valet is not a good thing.  My husband stayed in the car and I ran in to see what we should do.  This had to be done at the front desk - there were several people in front of me.  So I had to wait in line to figure out if there was a valet or not.The place was really not that clean. Probably not the staff's fault - the problem probably lies with not enough staff...They really don't seem very equipped to take care of really simple things - like to get change for a $20 so you can tip your maid - which, if you don't personally tip your maid, you really, really should! All in all, they may want to consider staffing up so that they can deliver the normal things that people may want/need while paying to stay at a hotel.
review_content_40: Pros: Location, location, location.  Stayed here with friends for the Jazz fest and would recommend for any event at Hart Plaza. Recent renovations make for modern lobby decor, and *some* industry vets make for great service (particularly the night shift).  The architecture of the CP makes for gorgeous views of the right side of Detroit from nearly every room. We had a wonderful look at the Ambassador Bridge over COBO.Cons: Parking.  Valet fills up quickly (something we weren't told when we decided to delay parking for a quick shopping jaunt) and there was no mention of a valet agreement with the nearby Holiday Inn Express until we had parked at COBO (with no in/out privileges). Actually, there was no mention until we arrived after a night out and all nearby structures were closed. Would have been smooth sailing if we had known that initially.  Also, thin walls and (beautiful) glass paneled doors make for tons of noise in the halls and, potentially, in your room.  Reminded me of some of the noisier floors at Motor City - great base for a night out, bachelor(ette) party, or something similar but not the best for a restful night.Stayed one night for a little getaway. Staff was friendly and helpful. I loved the pool and Jacuzzi. Room was kinda small but we had a nice view. I would definitely stay again.Average rooms. Found a cigarette butt on our chair and a yellow stain on our towels. YELLOW STAIN!  Gross. Justin at the front desk is absolute prick. Very unprofessional staff all in all. Belle hop was a sweet heart though.Bed is one of the best I've ever slept on at a hotel. Staff was excellent, pleasant and accommodating. Food at restaurant was great!!! Never thought I would crave Brussels sprouts but they were incredible along with the other menu items we tried. Would go back just for the food.  Great cuz it was right across from COBO and easy access.  Very clean. Only negative was bathroom was small but as long as you aren't totally obese its functional and fine. Views were awesomeMy work reserved a room for a colleague and me at the Crowne Plaza Hotel near the COBO Convention Center.  We were attending a work conference at the COBO Center, and the Crowne Plaza offered "discounted rates".  We were unable to make a reservation over the internet due to the discounted rate, so we had to call several times in order to get a hold of the manager to make the reservation.  This seemed strange, but I didn't think much of it.I pulled up in the back and was told the garage was valet only.  I hate valeting my car because it's old and falling apart, but I was told the parking would be free.  I left my car and headed into the hotel lobby, which was on the next floor.  There was an employee who hopped in the elevator with me to escort me upstairs.  It was kind of strange, but I thought nothing of it.  When I got upstairs, there was a massive line to check-in due to the fact that many people were attending the conference.  I waited about 20 minutes to be checked in and all seemed fine once I got my room key.  I headed to elevator to go up to my room on the seventh floor.  After waiting for about ten minutes, another hotel employee escorted a group of us to the creepy freight elevator.  Apparently they were having some problems with the four normal elevators.Up on the seventh floor, the hotel hallways started to small really musty.  I got into my room, and everything was brand-new.  So new in fact, that some one had left a strip of painters tap in the bathtub where the faucet was supposed to be.  I thought it was strange, but figured I could use the handle to turn on the shower.  I realized that I forgot some toiletry items and headed back down to see if the front desk had them.  I didn't want to wait for the elevator again, so I took the stairwell closest to my room.  I walked down a few flights and saw a construction zone sign on one of the floors and then an authorized personnel only sign on the next floor.  I got the bottom and reached an emergency only exit.  I headed back up the stairs and had to once again wait for the elevator to take me down.  At the front desk, I had to wait another 15 minutes only to be told that all of their toiletries were locked up, so I was out of luck.  When I told the person about the missing faucet, he remarked that many people were having issues with their rooms.  He didn't offer to change room, and I figured as mentioned above, that it would be fine.My colleague arrived, who is from Detroit, and explained that there were probably so many issues because the hotel had been closed for several years and that they had just opened in time for this conference.  In the morning, we awoke to take showers, and alas the faucet did not work for the shower. We had to switch rooms at seven am and this made us late for the conference.  That room thankfully had a working shower.  The bathroom door had a clear glass, somewhat translucent, which made it very awkward when someone was in there changing.  This room on the 21st floor did offer a nice view of Detroit/Canada.Throughout our stay, the elevators either were completely out of service or took forever or we had to take the freight elevator.  The hotel staff seemed very confused and inexperienced.  They were always friendly, but it seemed that they weren't trained enough to handle all of the problems related to the opening.   The rooms once everything was situated were nice enough.As we walked to the conference, there were people polling the hotels guests about their stay.  I wasn't sure why and didn't comment.  The morning of our departure, we heard music from the 21st floor and looked down to see a huge protest in the front of the hotel.  It turned out to be a UNITE HERE protest, which normally happens when workers rights are being violated.  When we left, the valet staff had to clear a path for those of use leaving the parking garage, otherwise, we would have been locked in by the protest.  This is not something I want to deal with as a hotel guest.  Please pay your workers a livable wage and offer benefits.The only nice thing I can say about this hotel is the staff are very hospitable.  Not dressed to well, but at least they render good customer service. From the bell hop and valet staff to the front desk receptionist, then to the hotel operator and lastly the room attendant staff, everyone was a delight and very professional. Also, the location of the hotel was very good in downtown Detroit in proximity to the rest of the sites in the downtown area.  My family was very safe walking around and hopping on and off the people mover.Unfortunately, I can't say the same thing about the hotel room.   The property itself is not too good.  We checked in on 3 July and stayed until 6 July.  We rented a room with two double beds.  The bedding was not soft (or quiet) and the general condition of the room is not something I want to see again.  The beds were uncomfortable and the sheets were scratchy and loud.  Even my daughter remarked that the thread count on the sheets hovered around a  2.Then on the last day of our stay, the morning of our check out, the hotel lost water pressure.  The only compensation the hotel gave us was two 10 ounce bottles of crappy water.  2 small bottles of water for three people.  This is what we had to brush our teeth and faces with in the morning.  I was sooooo glad when we checked out of the hotel. A stinky letter was written and slipped under the door sometime in the am of the morning and that's it.I do not recommend this hotel to anyone....not even my enemy.  I'm so done with this property.This is the worst $200 rate hotel I have ever stayed.  The suite size is nice and roomy.  But the shower stall is so small, it is about 2x2.  If you are a guy,  you will fully occupy the shower stall.  The so called double size bedroom has a full size bed for two adults.  This is so small that you can't get a good rest.  Restroom is also very old. Stay away from this hotel if you have a choiceThis hotel is fantastic! I enjoyed my stay there. it is centrally located so you can walk to things, such as Greek Town where I had a great meal. The hotel staff goes above and beyond. I had a sad experience where I left a very special necklace in one of the rooms and then flew home to the west coast the next day so I wasn't able to go retrieve it. The hotel staff responded to my request to mail the necklace back to me with great kindness. They refused my offer to pay shipping costs. I was warmed by such kindness. I will always recommend this hotel to friends as the ambience and service are top notch. Thank you manager High Fisher and staff!I was down here recently for an event at Comerica Park. The hotel was sold-out. I was expecting the customer service to suffer as a result of the event, but it was still stellar. Hugh, a front desk associate, was one of the reasons I had such a great stay. Great customer service!I love this hotel. I have stayed at a bunch of hotels in downtown and probably will come back to this one again.My room was very sizable, when I walked in, I was shocked that it was a suite, the first portion of the entry way is the living room area and the window overlooked the Ren Cen and into Windsor. Very picturesque view from the 23rd floor.Hotel was clean, the staff was excellent, the rooms are very clean. I was really impressed with the place. Hands down one of the better hotels I have stayed at (comparing it to the Westin, Holiday Inn Express, the Atheneum, Greek Town Casino, and Hilton Garden Inn) since having to travel to Detroit. It is easy to get to, it is close to  everything that I need. Greektown, Compuware, the People Mover, Hart Plaza.One other reviewer does bring up the fact the rest rooms are smallish, but at the end of the day you are only spending a small amount of time in there. They are still new and have to smooth the edges out, but for the pricing, it is well worth it.This hotel also goes by the name, Crown Plaza Pontchatrain Hotel.  The hotel has just re-opened under new management and has been renovated as well.Positives and negatives about this hotel.  Positives - The hotel staff were all very nice and friendly. I found the rate for this hotel to be very reasonable compared to others in the area. Our room had a very nice view of the lake and Canada.Right next to the Detroit Convention Center.Negatives - The rooms are small and the bathroom is just tiny.  Bathroom door had a glass window on it with shaded glass.  Everyone in the room can tell what you are doing in the bathroom.  Very limited privacy. Only two of the restaurants on the first floor were open during our stay.  Prices seemed very high and we ate elsewhere during our stay.Our door only seemed to lock if we pushed really hard on it to make sure it latched properly.Fire alarm went off several times suring our stay.  All were false alarms.  We were told they were having problems with the system.  You have to valet your vehicle while staying her at a price of $25 per day.  The valet service was very disorganized during our stay.  They had a very difficult time finding peoples cars and the system seemed to be all screwed up.  This could be due to only being open for a week.  But they could really make some big mistakes.  During my four day stay here they gave me the keys to someone else's car twice by mistake.The swimming pool is tiny and was very over chlorinated.  You could hardly stand to sit in the room with the fumes from the chlorine.  Again, I think they are still trying to figure out how to run things.Lastly the bellhop does not come on duty till 9:00 AM.  So if you want to check out before that you are on your own to try to find a cart, which is no easy task.The hotel staff seemed very confused and inexperienced. They were always friendly, but it seemed that they weren't trained enough to handle all of the problems related to the opening.Okay.  It wasn't horrific.  It wasn't great either.  I'd say it was on the poor side of mediocre.Recently, a Metro Cars driver tipped me off that the Ponchartrain had reopened as a Crowne Plaza.  He told me that it looked nice inside, had a nice view of the river, etc.  Okay, my wife and I were looking for a hotel downtown on short notice.  We planned to make a night of it at our current favorite restaurant in the Detroit Metro Area, Marais, and we figured that it would be safest to find a hotel and let someone else do the driving.  We picked the Crowne Plaza Detroit Downtown for the fact that we found an available room at a reasonably low price.  We figured we'd give it a try.  Why not?Well, I'll tell you why not.  Eh...sometimes, you find a deal, and it's a steal.  Sometimes, you just get what you pay for, and if you just paid a little more, you would have gotten something decent.The hotel, at this point, seems understaffed.  I don't know if that's true, but it seems like it's only half-open.  When we drove up to the comically understated entrance--so understated that we weren't even sure it was the entrance--there was a cab blocking the drive.  No valet.  No doorman.  No sign even confirming or implying that we were at the entrance.  It seemed almost deserted.  My wife went in and had to ask for the valet while I stayed with the car.  No bell staff were around.  We carried our bags ourselves, which wasn't a problem.  We didn't expect to have anyone take our things.  We just found it odd that there was just nobody around except the one guy at the front desk.  The cafe area in the lobby isn't open.  Supposedly, the gift shop items are available--just ask the front desk if you'd like to buy anything.  Apparently, they're going to serve Starbucks coffee. [Sarcasm/On] Ooh! How wonderful! [Sarcasm/Off] Okay fine.  We check in.  We go up to the room.  The view of the river is nice.  We are overlooking Cobo Hall.  Nice modern decor.  Then, I start to become dissatisfied with the room.  Stains on the white tile floor grout.  A solitary pubic hair on the floor, which I just discard with a tissue.  I don't tell the wife.  I start to think, "Yeah...I'll just wait to shower at home.  All I need is a place to sleep without driving home."The next morning, we get room service for breakfast.  They have some tasty breakfast items like their fried egg sandwich.  I get over myself.  I take a shower.  I survive.  The hot water, which seemed to take a long time to come up the night before, came up reasonably quickly.When we went to check out, we asked the front desk for change so that we can be nice and tip the valet.  I had used the last of my change to tip the housekeeper, because, hey, people need to make a living--not because I was especially impressed at how well-kept the place was.  Don't get me wrong.  It didn't look too bad.  It only started to look bad when I started to look closely.  I started to notice things like hallway carpeting that needed vacuuming--or at least closer attention to the vacuuming.  But anyway, we were told by the front desk that they didn't have change for a US$20.  We were advised to go to the restaurant to get change.  My wife went to the bar.  The bartender gave her some attitude about needing change and said something to the effect that my wife would need to buy something to get change.  My wife explained that the front desk sent us there for change, and all we wanted to do was get change to tip the valet.  My wife tipped the bartender just for making change, because, man, if it's that much of a problem to make change, well...here's a dollar for your trouble.We figured that it would be cheaper for us to find a hotel room downtown, take a cab to Marais in Grosse Pointe for dinner, and get a cab back rather than getting a car service to take us from home to Marais--to really enjoy the night safely.  Eh...we went back to Marais exactly one week later with friends.  This time we took the car service from home to dinner and back.  It was probably about the same without the hassle and annoyance of dealing with this less than mediocre hotel.  I'm thinking my two stars are overly generous.The floor had a stain on carpet, made the room feel dirty. The water in the shower NEVER even got warm. You have to pay 25$ to have the car valet parked PER DAY! The valets all seemed confused and pulling in and unloading luggage was a mess. Cars were just left in the way of the driveway, unattended blocking space and nobody was in control. The room was over $175. No breakfast, not even stale bagels or juice. No fridge in room, if you want to have anything chilled, bring a cooler. If you needed something in your car after the valets parked it you had no access to your car, you had to call ahead and have car brought around . Much better options closer to the  City Center. I will never stay here again. The staff seemed pleasant, but in no way did they seem like they would help you any more than they had too.Only Pros of this hotel is good view.Again it depends on your room.Cons: * I hate the way the bathroom has a glass door and when you are with family it's embarrassing to go into it          * Rooms are too small for the price          * No Oven or Mini Fridge as most of the hotels have.          * Paints & Carpet smells old.          * I am with my newborn and Thermostat doesn't work.It's too cold in the room and it's snowing out.Heard this is common complaint in most of the rooms.The restaurant downstairs is utterly fantastic and the hotel itself offers some amazing views of downtown Detroit, but for the love of God they need to fix the hot water issues at night! After being outside in teeth-chatteringly sub zero temps, I was looking forward to a hot shower before dinner. After running the water for a few minutes, the water was still freezing. Same thing a full 10 minutes later. We called the front desk to inform them of the issue, and they told us that someone would be sent up to investigate. Another ten minutes passed before I finally gave up and took the coldest, quickest shower in my life, and I came out feeling like an icicle. I might as well have gone outside and rolled around in the snow. From reading the other reviews on Yelp, this seems to be a systemic issue. Crowne Plaza is a beautifully renovated hotel in a prime location with one of the best restaurants in Detroit, but without hot water at night, those Michigan nights can be extra frigid!

review_content: We stayed the weekend here for Beerfest at Eastern Market. I booked several weeks out and got it for $114/night. For the price, it was fine. We needed a comfy place to sleep & shower. It worked for that. Based on previous reviews, I checked the bed for signs of bedbugs when we got there and did not see anything. We kept the window open to compensate for not being able to turn off the heat. The room was clean. The bed comfortable. There's no exhaust fan in the tiny bathroom. The CRT TV wasn't bad but the poor cable signal, channel line up and volume issues were pretty annoying. The hotel was quiet except for the occasional door slam that I suspect came from the utility room (we were at the end of the hall). We never heard anyone in the hallway. The valet parking was fine. Even with that added to the nightly price, it was still a lot cheaper than other hotels in the area. We weren't looking for a luxury hotel experience, just a decent place to stay while in town for an event. It did that.The front desk staff was very nice. We ordered in pizza Saturday. They made an effort to acquire plates & such for us. They even offered to bring them up rather than making me wait downstairs. We did not try the restaurant. A previous review mentions a hotel shuttle, they don't have one. We used Uber or a cab to go back & forth to Eastern Market. Word of caution, the housekeeping staff took/tossed my personal bar of soap from the shower. They provide a free bar and left a new one, so I'm guessing they thought it was there's. Not a big deal. They also charge a $50/per night refundable deposit for the room. Not sure if that's standard but I wasn't expecting it.I'm giving St. Regis Hotel two stars because I thought I would die during the night (a'la American Horror Story), and I woke up to write this tale on Yelp.I traveled to Detroit for a work event, so I arrived at the hotel around 11 pm by myself, which prompted the clerk at the desk to repeatedly ask, "Are you alone? Is anyone else with you? You're all by yourself?" DO YOU SEE ANYONE ELSE WITH ME? Nothing could make a woman more uncomfortable close to midnight in an unfamiliar city asking if I'm flying solo, so please don't.Feeling uneasy, I located my room. My comfort level was increasing but immediately began to deteriorate as I heard snatches of a conversation between two men, one who kept mumbling, "I don't know what you want me to say, Keith." Keith, dissatisfied, disconnected from the call. Keith's phone friend aka the man staying in the adjacent room to mine (PAPER THIN WALLS) proceeded to phone a woman and complain about Keith's self-harming tendencies for several minutes while I tried to avoid eavesdropping, which was damn near impossible considering the particle board separating my room from his. p.s. Keith, I hope you're alright, buddy.Then, I noticed a glaring light in the parking lot, which was a spotlight that I could not block out because there were no drapes on my window. Fine, I thought, I'll sleep with the lights on and my contacts in just in case I'm attacked in the middle of the night. Unfortunately, I found sleep near impossible due to how uncomfortable my accommodations were, so I attempted to connect to wifi to get some work in ("attempted" = key verb). There is no wifi at this hotel, but don't worry, I have a hotspot that causes AT&T to send me text messages relevant to my data overages.  I didn't even bother with the TV.I kept waking up throughout the night mistaking the spotlight for the sun and being so grateful that it was time to leave. Finally, the sun did rise, and I was jolted awake by an incessant, shrill beeping noise. I had to move the bed and nightstand in order to locate the source of this obnoxious noise, which was a dying walkie talkie. Very eerie. I managed to turn the damned thing off and slip back into a brief sleep before quickly packing up and getting the hell outta there. The valet was nice though - she cleaned the snow off my car. :)I'll start by saying I developed more anxiety by reading the reviewers prior than my stay at St Regis. That said, the reviewers all have a point.It's a has been boutique hotel saddled at two stars and fighting (to its credit) for the third. It has a certain level of charm to see the old world built into the facade, lobby and lay out of the room. But it presents poor competition in the era of fresh smelling holiday inn expresses and comfort inns. I stayed partially comped by Henry Ford hospital which made the booking worth it but cannot imagine paying the full $100 for the room.The room was spacious, the bed comfortable King, and the room clean. I felt like I walked into the early 1990s when I entered given the decor and CRT tv. The room was clean, and bathroom was adequately sized without issues with water heating. My major complaint has to do with the AC which was stuck on heat. The management's answer to my friend calling down to the desk was to open the window! Not something expected from a hotel in 2015. Hence two starsIt's obvious in the lobby and outside that the hotel is being renovated. I would not recommend staying there unless your stay is comped or the hotel completes its numerous renovations to modernize.Why 3 stars? Because it got the job done, but is in desperate need of updates.   ---   ---   ---I'm not picky when it comes to hotel rooms, but I don't think I'd stay here again.My only experience in a St. Regis was in Washington DC. I worked for the Tampa Bay Lightning at the time, and actually had the privilege of staying in the team hotel as they were in town to play the Capitals. To this day, that was easily the swankiest hotel I've ever stayed in. Everything was gold-plated. I did not feel worthy of being in my room.This St. Regis finds itself on the opposite end of the spectrum. The whole thing seems like a strong wind would just blow it over. From the elevator, to the base boards, to the bathrooms, to outdated electronics... it's all just kind of hanging on by one finger nail.But it gave me a place to lay my head at night, incident-free. I'll take it.I got to stay at the St. Regis Hotel this past weekend.  It was a great stay.  It is has an elegant feel to it.  Lots of history and charm to it.  The room itself was quite comfortable and pleasant.  The staff was pleasant and helpful. (There is valet parking.)  The hotel was conveniently located for me.  I will be sure to use this hotel again when I visit the Detroit area.would stay here again. the hotel was old but in a good way. the room was clean and for the price we paid it couldn't be beat. The front desk staff was very nice. we ate in the restaurant in the lobby and had a good experience there as well.I have to say it saddens me to say how disappointed I was in the food and the service.  You could see and feel the struggle that was taking place for the organization to properly serve and provide good value to the consumer.We all want Detroit to do well and of course the businesses in it.  But I don't know if somebody's old organizations can make the transition with the challenges of finding good help and qualified serving and cook staff.At any rate I wish them all well there and all future success in their endeavors to bring this restaurant back to its once great glory.The room is a feast for your eyes.This is probably one of the worst 3 star hotels I've visited... The room seems clean but that's about the best thing I can say about the place..... Bathroom is tiny... No amenities... A/C barely works... And an old school CRT TV... Just see the attached pictures... The wifi is so slow I can't even stream a show on my iPad.... They changed my room for me for the issue with the A/C but of course the other room was only slightly better and I was told that all the rooms had the same type of A/C unit... Sorry this is closer to a 1 star than a 3 star... I've been to better MOTELS!!!! Don't waste your money... Don't bother with this place.****update****Just took a shower..... Wow... The water doesn't drain... Once again don't waste your money... Don't come hereA Good hotel for the price and location. The hotel was centrally located, it was easy to take Lyft anywhere I wanted to go. There is a mandatory $20 valet parking fee but you have access to your car as often as you wish. No A/C which could be a problem for some, I called down to the front desk and they sent up a box fan. The hotel has a vibe of tattered elegance and historic charm, everything was slightly worn but clean. The WiFi did not work in the room but we were able to use an office space in the lobby and plug in. I needed a safe, clean room in Downtown Detroit and the St Regis was great.I will make this review nice and quick. My husband and I got married at The Hotel St. Regis a week ago and what an amazing experience it was!! Donna R. Was most helpful with the planning process. Front desk manager Robert was also awesome as far as accommodations go. Our food was delish as well! I had the grilled salmon in a creamy dill sauce and he had the champagne chicken. I would recommend The Hotel St. Regis for your next event. The only reason I gave 4 stars was because of the rude front desk worker (can't remember his name) but he was just a hassle to deal with.Clean rooms, tube TVs, shampoo/conditioner/lotion set was of much higher quality than the room rate would suggest. Would not hesitate staying here again.You get what you pay for. A two star hotel at best. The rooms were what you would expect from a 2 star hotel... Not the greatest but better than a motel. Tube tv in the room gave it a very old feeling. Two reasons for the the one star review.. One would be the rude service from the receptionist at the main desk in the morning. When asked for a copy of our bill we were told that she could not produce one (because we booked through a third party) in a very unprofessional manner. Second reason would be the rooms beside us turned into dorm rooms. A local college is using the hotel to facilitate students. Which is not a big deal, until it's 1am and the adjoining room is filled with people talking absurdly loud and preventing you from sleeping. Now I am in my late 20s so I am no grumpy old man, but I am here for work and would expect a good nights sleep at a hotel. Overall, it was not a good experience and would not stay again.I've traveled a lot this year.  So far this is the worst hotel I've been to in a while. The pictures on the website pale in comparison to how awful this place is. They recently upgraded their rooms but....1) AC barely worked from the built in wall unit, and the room was super small so it was seriously underpowered 2) valet was $20 and they park it in the open air lot next door. I had to retrieve something 15 minutes after check in but they sent their valet home. So I was given the key and walked the 12 feet to my car. I would have rather paid half to self park. Valet also greeted me with "VALET ONLY 20 DOLLARS" and then proceeded to tell me I had to hurry to check in and that she will give me just a few minutes to get back. (8pm, no line)3) the ironing board was rusted and burned. So much for my business meeting4) someone got into a fight in the hallway. 5) who is St Regis? Either way I'm sure he's pissed this is named after himWe got to our room and the AC was broken. They sent Marianne to fix it and we left and returned 6 hours later to it still being hot in our room. They said they couldn't do anything so they suggested to sleep with the window open and the brought us a fan. Then we were woken up to jackhammers doing work outside of our window at 6am. DISAPPOINTMENT doesn't even explain how bad this was.When I have to stay at a hotel, my biggest fear is to be placed in a room with a poorly functioning AC, or worse, a broken AC. This is what happened to me last night. It was awful and completely unacceptable. Also, the front desk girl rolled her eyes too much.The restaurant at the hotel was the worst experience you could imagine. Food was not as described, and the the service was incredibly slow. Do not go here!I'm quite disappointed with my recent stay at the St. Regis Hotel. I chose it because of its location, complimentary wifi in each room and then the price, in that order. While the location worked out okay, the rest of my stay made me regret my choice in hotel. I wished I had just stayed the Crowne Plaza or Westin downtown. Overall the level of customer service was uneven, inconsistent and more befitting of a roadside chain motel, not a supposed boutique hotel. In a nutshell, no wifi, old equipment in the rooms and tiny staff. The worst part of my stay was lack of wifi. The entire few days I stayed I had no wifi access. Neither my android phone or my two iOS devices could connect. The staff was absolutely of no help. And St. Regis really needs to fire their wifi provider. I'm sick of hotels claiming to provide wifi but they don't and the front desk could care less. Congratulations, you've just told the traveling business community that you don't want their business.The staffing at the front desk and valet service was meager. There was mostly one person working reception, and one person at valet. Valet also functioned as baggage porters. So you might have to wait a while for him/her to get back to get your car. Housekeeping staff spent mornings yelling down the hall to each other; they were much louder than the construction scene outside in front of the hotel. My room was handsome, clean and sizable. But it lacked attention to details, like the lack of an iPod station and a modern TV. On the desk was an old half-working desk radio. Instead of a flat screen TV, there's a small, old cathode-ray tube telly with some limited and broken cable channel access. The telephone worked half the time with no caller ID; I received two unexpected, mysterious early calls that the front desk couldn't help me identify. This is a 2-star hotel trying to masquerade as something more. It's really pathetic. Although the St. Regis' New Center location makes complete sense if you're working at the neighboring office buildings, going to Wayne State U.'s campus, or attending a play at Fisher Theatre, I chose it so that I didn't just spend my money downtown. There's not much to the area after hours, except for the Fisher, but it's a quick cab ride to downtown and it's easy to hop on and off the highway to get to another part of town. And while it has a rough past and present, the area is getting better as the city transitions.Allow me to start by saying, I've traveled all over the world. Literally. So I have reasonable expectations. However, I have NEVER been in a hotel with a more unprofessional, sticky fingered staff. I stayed at the St. Regis with 9 of my fellow group members, to do a show for Buick. Checked in on a Friday, and left the Monday after. Incident #1: My sister and I were sharing rooms, and had to call down to front desk on Friday night to request a new room because my sister had bugs in her bed. Bugs.... In her bed.... Security came up, saw the bugs, and helped us move to another room, at around 1am. In the midst of all the hustle and bustle, my sister left a blazer in the room, but once she realized it the next day, (Saturday) she called down to the front desk to ask them to check the room for the blazer. Security came, said he checked the room but found nothing. My sister requested that she accompany the security to help him look, but again, the blazer was no where to be found. Frustrated because this blazer was a part of her wardrobe for the show, she called the front desk again, and asked if housekeeping turned it in. They claimed to have looked everywhere, but there was no blazer to be found anywhere in the entire building. Sad. Welp, somehow the jacket reappeared Sunday before we left for our show. Odd right?! When we returned that night, I saw the security guy who helped my sister search for her blazer, I informed him the jacket magically reappeared. He responded with a cheeky grin. So then I asked him, "you called someone and told them to bring the jacket back, didn't you?" He responded, "I did!" WTH?!?! Incident #2: One of my group members couldn't find his watch in his room anywhere. Somehow, he thought to look at the TOP of the closet, and there it was. Hiding. Incident #3: Upon departure, another group member realized his Jordan sneakers were gone. GONE!!! Incident #4: I was styled for our show by a friend, which included clothes and jewelry. All the jewelry was in a bag inside my suitcase. Upon my return back home to Dallas, I gave my friend her items back, and by golly, some of the jewelry was gone. Seriously, their housekeeping staff can NOT be trusted. In an attempt to watch what the housekeepers were doing, one of my group members hit record on her computer, to record their behavior while we were away. Only to return, to get computer being closed down. Lolol! I'm sure their criminal behavior being recorded was less than ideal for them. Listen to me when I say, DO NOT STAY HERE!!!! Aside from the thievery, their AC doesn't work, so no matter what temp the unit is on, it'll only blow heat. The ONLY reason this hotel even gets a star from me is because of the food. Otherwise, this was a terrible experience. Horrible! Horrible!! HORRIBLE!!!This hotel is over priced for nothing they Dont have flat screens in any rooms. Furniture in the room are old and raggedy. The food Is not that good and over priced for nothing. They are very unprofessional. It look like a old funeral home. I spent suite money for three days and they gave me the worst room ever. I can to visit from Cali I very displeased with this hotel I will never go back.Pros: Pretty clean amenities with an antique French feel. The bed is extremely comfortable. Bath towels are soft. Room layout of the king studio is quite nice -- with a vanity that doubles as a coffee table. Cons: That said, the decor lacks attention to detail, e.g. tv is from 1990, outlets are insufficient, window curtains are torn, shower curtains are worn, staff are incompetent and rude (particularly receptionist named Georgette), breakfast is so so I stayed here for free as an interviewee of Henry Ford. Otherwise, I would not pay more than $100/night for these rooms. Go to Howard Johnson hotel and cab or uber to downtown instead
review_content_20: The hotel is not within walking distance to Comerica, Ford Field or Greektown.   There are five buildings connected to the hotel which offer a food court type of dining that closes around 5:00 PM midweek.  There is nothing walking distance to the hotel and the area is not good. The hotel is ok.  I made the mistake of looking behind the nightstand and observed old food and large quantities of hair.   The hotel rooms only receive a surface cleaning. The first night I called for room service for over an hour and no one answered.  The front desk wasn't too concerned when I told them about no one answering.  If you're traveling for business to one of the five buildings attached, then it's worth it to stay.  If you're traveling for fun, stay someplace else. The restaurant attached,  La Musique, is ok.  I was the only customer is the place and it took 30 minutes for french toast.I booked a block of rooms for my wedding.  I agreed to the terms that 3 days before the wedding date, the block rooms would be freed up (available for anyone to purchase).  That's no problem.  However, we negotiated a rate for my guests.  A few guests did book rooms after the block was freed, and were not given the negotiated rate (even though there were still rooms available within the block).  I found this out months after the wedding from my sister.  This I did not agree to.  So, after giving this hotel about 10-12 rooms worth of business (rooms which otherwise would not have been occupied), they welched on their end of the deal.  Bad business in my opinion.  They've certainly lost of customer.  I hope they lose more.EDIT: In response to Victor: You state that this dirty little trick is something that all hotels do.  This was not told to me.  I don't work for a hotel.  I feel mislead.  It is your prerogative to mislead customers, and it is my prerogative to write a negative review afterwards.If you're staying here it's because it's relatively cheap and because it's one of the few hotels this far north of downtown. It gets by of those two things, and does little otherwise to earn your money. The wifi is terrible (which, okay, hotel wifi is generally bad but don't promise "highspeed internet in every room"). I stayed in two different rooms and one didn't even have a thermostat to adjust the air conditioner. They gouge you on parking-- just add another $20 a night to your tab for that. It's ridiculous too because the valet literally drives your car to a mostly empty parking lot 20 feet from the building-- as if you couldn't do that yourself to save $20 a night. But hey, it's still almost half the price of the other midtown and downtown hotels, so you get what you pay for.Over Priced Rooms and under delivered service... Last night the room service showed up pretty quick but it was cold and I had to send it back. The second it took a little longer, and it came back slightly warmer - I guess the microwave was on the fritz. I didn't bother to send it back a third time, at that point I was tired and hungry from traveling that I just took it. Today when I came back from work, the only way that I could tell that they performed maid service was that the floor towel had been draped over the tub and I had fresh towels, I think. Maybe they just refolded the old ones and put them back, other than that the rest of the room wasn't touched. Now tonight I wanted to give them another chance and decided to stay in eat at their restaurant (because it is too damn cold outside and Detroit doesn't clean up snow like Chicago) in any event, the restaurant is supposed to be open until 11:00 PM - I was looking forward to a steak. It was closed, when asked, the front desk said "oh yeah since we have so few clients tonight we decided to close it down, but I have some take out menus if you like."I've had better experiences at Motel 6. The only reason I'm still here is that I leave Sunday - too much work to go to another place and, again, too cold.I hope this is not business as usual, because the main reason I'm is that I am working out of the  Detroit Regional office and and I can use the skywalks to get to the office without having to go outside. I'm sure I'll be - but only for work purposes. If I came to Detroit for pleasure I'd stay at the Holiday Inn.Oh yeah... I was given an complimentary breakfast - not steak.Now I am using the complimentary take out menu to order Chinese.Main problem was the noise and how staff dealt with the issue (not at all).  Around midnight, other patrons were screaming and throwing a party of some sort. Called the front desk numerous times and nothing was done.  My room was also uncomfortably warm (80).  When I mentioned this to the front desk they stated that the whole building only had heat and the AC was not turned on for the winter. Leaving the window open was the only way to cool the room.  Between hearing the traffic and others screaming down the hall, I did not get much sleep the day prior to an interview.  During breakfast, I asked for an english muffin and was given a bagel. This isn't a big deal, but just added to my frustrations.Had a little trouble w/ our first rooms AC. But overall the staff was friendly and helpful and the decor was vintage Detroit. Great location too. The burger from the restaurant was pretty good and room service was quick. I would definitely consider staying here again.I stayed here for a conference at Wayne State. Not impressed. Orange water came out of the faucet the first time I turned it on. Valet/bell desk did not greet me with a smile or help with bags. Very confused by the lack of costumer service. No real amenities.  The front desk attendants were nice and the building has some nice historic details. I would not rebook.While the reviews are mixed, we had a grand stay.  Newly renovated, this is a nice hotel.  Ate in the dining room and had excellent dinners.  The review that says "no wifi", they fixed that as well.I recently had one of the worst hotel experiences of my life at the St. Regis hotel in Detroit. They stole my laptop and wouldn't admit to it. The general manager even lied to me and tried to cover for his maid. Both employees should be fired.I stayed here for one night, and about 3 hours after checking out I realized I had left my laptop in my room. I called the hotel immediately to ask if they had found the laptop. I spoke to the general manager. He said he would call the head of housekeeping, who had already left for the day. He called me back about an hour later saying that they had cleaned the room but hadn't found anything, and that this meant I had not left the laptop there. I knew this wasn't true.I asked him to speak to the actual maid who had cleaned my room, which he said he would do the following day. I told him to tell her that I had a feature enabled on my laptop called "Find My Mac," and that the next day when my company's IT admins were available they were going to log in and see on a map where the laptop was located. I told him to let the maid know that if it turned out that he or she had the laptop, I had every intention of pressing charges.The next day I spoke to the general manager again, who said that the laptop miraculously appeared in the laundry room, and he assured me that it was a total mistake; that the laptop had gotten wrapped up in the linen, and that no one intended to steal it. He then promptly shipped the laptop back to me.I received the laptop in the mail, and I can confirm that someone had indeed tried to steal the laptop and was obviously spooked by my threat. Upon turning the laptop on, I saw that someone had tried to create a guest ID and succeeded in logging in with it -- which I've never done.Obviously it was irresponsible of me to leave my laptop in the hotel room. Shame on me. Beware though: not only are the maids at this hotel likely to steal anything you leave behind, but more importantly, the manager is going to cover for them. The latter is completely unacceptable. Both employees should be fired.Tags: steal, stealing, thief, theft, despicable :)Pros-Clean sheets moderately priced for quasi-downtown Detroit locationshower was cleanCons-Centipede upon entrance to the roomElevator service was poorIce machine only on the 3rd floorThere is a $20 per night mandatory valet charge for parkinghad to get a room key re activated 3 timesI've now stayed at the St. Regis 4 times for business since September. I can safely say that the customer service from the valet, the front desk and at the bar have all been excellent. The condition of the hotel on the other hand has not been as stellar. While it has been updated, I've found that the rooms have not been cleaned as well as I would expect and something has always been broken, so far it's been the lock to the bathroom, the security latch on the door and the TV remote. Also, twice now the hot water was not working... try taking a freezing cold show in Detroit's winter months, not pleasant! It's a good location if you are looking to hang out in Midtown or New Center, especially because there is almost nowhere else to stay in these areas.Room Tip: If you need wifi, ask for a room near the elevator on the lower floorsA fine hotel if you want something quiet and out of the way. I have a soft spot for formerly grand hotels, so keep that in mind. The staff is very friendly and accommodating, although they haven room key to someone else, who walked in on me in bed. That should have been avoided.Beautiful hotel which has long since seen its glory days. It's super cheap (we paid $100/night), and it shows. But it's also gorgeous, the staff are friendly, and there are always taxis in front to take you anywhere. Caveat emptor, of course, but we've been super happy with our stay and we would happily visit the St. Regis again.For a place that seems to be presenting itself as a luxury hotel, it was quite mediocre. Internet is pathetic, barely functioning, don't be expecting to use it for anything but refreshing your email once an hour. The cleaning service was very subpar, after the first night I was there they didn't even clean anything, the next day they... tried. No fresh towels. No changed sheets. It started to feel gross.It's not in a particularly good area, nothing nearby to do, and it's a bit of a ways to downtown. Felt a little sketch walking around and a few cab drivers even warned me to stay inside after dark. Speaking of cab drivers, the front desk was nice enough to call be a cab whenever I needed but I later realized that I was being charged an extra, imaginary fee incurred because the cabby was "the hotel's". Otherwise the staff and concierge were very cordial, and the restaurant attached to the hotel was nice.Please Read!!...This is the worst hotel ever...No Stars (zero)...You are better off staying at a $30.00 motel off the side of the expressway...If you spend your money to stay here you are going to be piss off to the highest level...Where should I start; (1) the water from the sink takes 30mins to get hot unless you turn on the tub then it's only 15mins, (2) the towels are dingy, (3) the carpet is dirty, (4) the room wasn't clean, so we changed rooms, (5) the TV is from the late 80's (yes a 1985 bubble screen tv), (6) old and out dated furniture...So please forget about any good reviews...I paid people, and employees to assume a different name to say great things about my restaurant, so they probably did the same...DO NOT STAY HERE!!..UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES...You have been warned...St Regis Hotel in Detroit moto..."It's better to be piss off than piss on"...You will definitely be piss off and probably piss on by some rude, unknowledgeable, uncaring employee...So please take heed to this and stay far, far away from this hotel...You have been warned...Ever had that wtf moment wondering how any of what just happened actually really truly happened?! Try a night at the saint Regis. Valet is an actual inconvenience as the staff was completely lost and took an hour to pull my car up. Then in order to save time I went to check in. Sigh, I can't because the front desk attendant is parking cars. Right. Fast forward to a dump of a room and a tired old building. No clue how they charge what they do.Stayed at this hotel to see the World Series and it was much better than the reviews. Recently they have done some renovation and the room was great. Especially for the price, $139 per night during the World Series; it was awesome.The one downside the shower head wasn't great...but the beds were super comfortable and the blackout curtains covered the window 100%.Valet parking was only $14 per day and it was $10 taxi to downtown.The staff was super nice! While this was a boy weekend, my wife would love this hotel as well. Normally, I stay downtown in most cities but my next trip to Detroit will include a stay here!My friends Hotwired 3 rooms here and it was an overall pleasant experience. Nestled in "Midtown" Detroit, near the Wayne State Campus, the location is a short hike from downtown attractions, but is very close to WSU and the DIA. From the outside it looks pretty grand and preserved well in its aged appearance. I liked that the location in Midtown translated to a budget friendly $7 valet charge on the late-March Saturday night.The lobby is well-kept and looks nice as some more upscale hotels. The staff is friendly, but definitely in a brief and to the point manner. The rooms are just a tad on the small side, but are comfortable and reminded me of some 3-star rooms I have stayed at in NYC because of the etiquette of their bare and aged furnishings. My group was listening to music and enjoying cocktails in the room relatively loudly and we got no complaints, which was nice. We also did request to be put away from other occupied rooms, which may have helped the cause. The beds were basic, not the most comfortable I've seen in hotels, but they fared way better than the worst beds I've seen offered to the public.Overall, a solid Midtown Detroit hotel, basic in their room furnishings, well-kept lobby, decent staff, and budget valet parking. The area feels safe and the clientele is mostly friendly. I would recommend snagging this place if you need a hotel in the area.I arrived on a Thursday night. The part of Detroit that the hotel is located at is pretty deserted and dark - at least after sunset. I had a hard time figuring out which way to drive in for the valet parking and there was no one in sight when i arrived. I called the hotel reception desk and they sent someone out to help me. The inside of the hotel was quiet, as well. I felt like the only guest there. Check in was basic. I got a room on the fourth floor facing away from the street. The room was a nice size, comfortable bed, working heater, etc. The room was clean. No complaints there. I really enjoyed the location. It was a short drive to all downtown attractions and it was very easy to find my way back to the hotel everytime i ventured off to different areas of detroit or michigan. My 2 complaints are:1. my room didn't get serviced one of the days i was there. it sucks coming back to an unmade bed when you have been out all day walking and sightseeing.  I was told by one of the staff that i would get my iron switched since it didn't work and this never happened. luckily it wasn't absolutely necessary, but it would have been extra nice to iron my clothes. 2. there were a few rowdy neighbors 2 of the nights i was there. the walls are thin and i kept being woken up throughout the night. Overall, the hotel has a vacant feeling. they charge $14 per day for valet, but its 24hrs. location is good. nice rooms. staff is friendly. would stay here again, but i would definitely look into other places if i ever return to detroit for a trip.With the exception of the front desk, service here is some of the worst I have ever seen at a hotel, especially in the restaurant/bar.  The staff couldn't care less.  And if you need internet in your room, check whether you can connect as soon as you check in.  The internet doesn't "reach" to certain rooms.
review_content_40: OK, i'm relatively new to the yelp experience but I now have the forum to tell it like it is. Before I start, it's fair to mention that I stayed at this " establishment " in 2009 so perhaps things have changed. The area in which this place is located is the equal to a demilitarized zone. If you walk the streets, even in daylight, be sure to wear a suit of armor and say your novenas. The hotel itself offered nothing special. The rooms were borderline motel 6 quality. I hope that in the years since our last visit, things have changed for the better. I'm rather suspect....especially since i'm reading the same complaints on a few other posts.Where to start? I stayed here last night... The whole night I felt as if I were transported back to 1999. The old carpet, old furniture, tube tv that barely worked. I also went to get ice and realized there was no ice machine on my floor. I called the front desk and they told me they have one machine on the third floor. Why? Any decent hotel has an ice machine on every floor. The worst part was, my room was FREEZING. I woke up a few times because of how cold it was. And I had the thermostat set to 90 degrees. No room service after 11 which was disappointing. Lastly when I was leaving the elevator was out of service and I had to take the stairs 5 stories down. You'd be better off staying anywhere else...I really wanted to like this hotel. For all the exterior grandeur, it should be good. But I ended up leaving it halfway through my trip in sheer frustration. Here is a play-by-play of my ill-fated two nights at St. Regis. 1) Of two elevators, one was broken. I waited for it to arrive for about 5 minutes with all my bags before I realized it was broken. The desk clerk could see me that whole time and did not mention it. She was playing with her cell phone instead. I have to pee very badly. I finally press the other elevator button. 2) On to my room, #619. But what's this--it has not been thoroughly cleaned! Uh-oh. Hair on the sink, on the back of the toilet, crumpled up paper trash on top of the TV, and NO TOILET PAPER.  I really really had to pee. I'd been waiting since the airport. I considered peeing in the sink and drying on a towel, but decided to just get another room.3) I call and asked to be transferred to another room. No apology.I asked someone to bring a new key up. Answer: no. I had to come down and get a new key card. Okay. Waiting on that one working elevator again...4) Room #625. This new room was clean... except for one long black hair in the tub. But as I unpacked, *black ants* swarmed over my stuff, into my bag of rice cakes, and under the keyboard of my laptop. They appear to live in the walls. A bit unsettling. But I was like, no big deal. Ants. I can hang. They're not rats! I like ants. This is an old building that has been recently renovated.5) I'm an ice-cruncher, so I was looking forward to filling up a bucket of ice after peeing and putting the suitcases away. I peek in on the vending room. Just wires sticking out of the wall. No vending machines, no ice machine. I call downstairs. "Where is the ice machine for the 6th floor, please?" "We don't have ice machines. You have to come downstairs and I'll give you some." Starting to feel like I'm in a bad movie. Not a $150 a night hotel.6) I slept through the night, and worked hard the next day. Come back to the hotel, take a nap, and get up around 8pm. I'm a teacher and was trying to prepare some conference presentation materials. I needed a pair of scissors. So I went to the front desk. "The last guests who borrowed scissors never returned them, so we don't have any available." "Really?" "Yes." Desk clerk would not lend me scissors or a stapler. She claimed that there was NO scissors or staplers in the entire hotel. None. I stood around in postures of disbelief for a while, explaining how public education depended on my using a pair of scissors. No sympathy. No scissors. By this time, no stores nearby were open, and the front desk staff suggested I take a cab to a convenience store to buy a pair. 7) The hotel boasts free internet access in the rooms--score! I hate paying for internet. But their internet only works sometimes. For about ten minutes at a time. Then it goes out. Then I call downstairs. And they say the engineer is looking into it. Repeat X 5 over the course of the evening. Fun! The desk clerk loves me! I'm an entitled white lady, apparently.8) Finally, bedtime! Ah--this hotel is adjacent to the Detroit Police Dept. headquarters. Good. I'm safe. But, sirens scream by all night long. 9) About 3 am, my next door neighbors get in, and start having a party. There were at least 10 people in the room, yelling, laughing, and blasting music. I knocked on their door bleary-eyed to ask them to please keep it down.A young white man opened the door, wearing a yellow thong. He said he was sorry.I tried to go back to sleep but the party continued past dawn.10) At 7:30am housekeeping called. "Did you want a service today?" a woman asked. "Yes," I replied. Um...don't expensive hotels always service your room unless you put Do Not Disturb on the doorknob?I told her about the ant problem. I asked her not to use any pesticides or spray chemicals as I have asthma. She said I would have to move rooms. No, I said, I've got all my stuff set up in that room and desk and the closet, moving would be too difficult to do a second time. Please just clean the room and clean up the ants you see, and I don't mind sharing the room with them.10) I get back from working at 4:30pm. I want to crawl into bed and nap. But... the room was dirty and bed unmade, as it was when I left it that morning. I called and asked for a housekeeper to come. Then I decided to take a long walk so they could do their work. When got back an hour later, no one had come. 11) I called downstairs again. "They're on the way up." Waited a while longer. Still no one. Then I decided to call and ask for the Manager. I waited on hold for about ten minutes. "There's no manager available right now, Ma'am."  "Where is the manager?" "He's in a meeting. But you can wait for him downstairs." I go down. I wait for two hours, checking in about every 20 minutes. Then, I take a cab to the Marriott.Oh I can't believe I forgot to write a review for this place! So back in October of last year I stayed here. Upon arriving I thought to myself "oh wow better than what I was expecting." That was just the first impression I got based on the exterior of the hotel. The lobby was nice but a bit shabbier than expected. The front desk clerk was helpful. So anyhow the first night was good...no complaints. The kicker and the reason why they are only getting one star is because my room was not cleaned!!! The morning I stepped out and had a full day of activities was looking forward to coming back to a clean room, take a nap and resume with the plans I had at night. But nope...got there and it was just like I left it. That had never happened to me...aren't hotels supposed to clean your room unless you specify that they don't??? I've stayed at plenty of Motel 6's, flea hole in the wall hotels and even they come in and clean up the room. So I was very displeased about that. To top it all off on the last night I was there, the fire alarm went off. We had to evacuate the building...not their fault I supposed but it still sucked! Note to whoever is running this place...YOU MUST CLEAN ALL THE ROOMS!! That's what customers are paying for...a nice clean room to sleep. Is that too much to ask for?A very nice little hotel.  Relaxing and a bit out of the way.  Great wait staff, nice comfortable rooms and a very good happy hour/bar.Whoa! The St. Regis! One would think top end, high-brow style. Which it is, but we didnt think that for Detroit we would actually get it for the bargain basement price of $67, includes taxes for 2 beds. This is and was a posh hotel in Detroit. Just because the city has seen better days means you cant get a fabulous deal on a great room! Well equipped, clean, updated rooms with super comfy beds. The bar was a little pricey for drinks, and they didnt serve breakfast, but well worth every penny. I cringe to think of the other places we "could" have stayed in the same price range. Good value.I specifically picked this hotel because it has good reviews on every website I check.  WORST HOTEL EXPERIENCE EVERAnd I work for a international travel association so trust me on this one.  The place looks like it WAS one of those trendy hotels but due to shear lack of care, maintenance, and cleanliness it has fallen on rough times - just like this god forsaken city.First thing - I pull up to the hotel and almost mistake it for an abandoned building.  No valet, no lights, and the main entrance has been permanently moved to a pair of double doors you might think lead to a 1970's condo lobby.  As I wait in line (one person in front for 30 minutes), the "driveway" becomes completely packed with new guests arriving and still no valet.Finally at the front desk - takes another 30 min to get checked in - the clerk never once looks me in the face or says hello.  She hands me my room key and I make my way up to the 4th floor.  Unlock the door to find someone else is already in the room!  I go back to elevator but the button to go down has been ripped out of the wall - have to wait, go up, and then back down.  Go to the front desk, advise of the situation, they apologized (sorta) and said, "Oh, this has never happened before."Head back up to new room, open door, lights are on and two guys are in this room!  They told me the same happened to them.  At the front desk I tell them I don't feel comfortable staying in a hotel that's going to give my key out to the next guest who walks in.  They say they're sorry and completely ignore me.  Furious, I call up Travelocity, with whom I originally booked the reservation and spend the next hour + on the phone trying to find a different hotel.  Not once did any of the hotel staff approach me or offer any help, suggestions, or apologizes while I was in the lobby.AWFUL SERVICE, AWFUL HOTEL.Oh, they did find the valet after three hours - he was in the back smoking a dooby, or so the police said as they took him away...The front desk staff told me about the discount for HFH employees and then didn't bother to give me the discount.We stayed here Memorial Day weekend 2013,the place was nice and remodeled.Pretty close to downtown with car (5-10min.), too far to walk in to town.Area was mostly office buildings so as expected it was empty.Nothing really to do around there besides Fisher Theater.Staff in the restaurant was really nice and the front desk staff were Ok.Elevator seemed to not work once when we were in it so we thankfully got out before being stuck dont know how many times these get stuck, but we were lucky to get out and take the stairs from 6th floor nothing too major. Last night we got in kinda late and tipsy only to see both our key cards didnt work kinda a drag to go down elevators again to tell staff that our keys didnt work.It wouldve been nice to have a quick apology from staff behind desk but ehh... whatvever we were tipsy so our fault no wait both our faults.Rooms were clean when we got there and we had new towels and sheets after we got back so Cleaning Staff get a high grade from us.The shower water was cold one morning but I waited a half hour then let run for awhile and wallah got STEAMING HOT!!!Its a nice Hotel so if you are looking at it on priceline or travelocity the Hotel is nice and what not worth 80-100 bucks a night.If you don't read it all, please read the LAST paragraph!! What a disaster! We booked the St. Regis for price and convience. We should have been less cheap and book elsewhere. As soon as we got out of the car we were 'greeted' by a man asking for money. I am a NYer so I am used to seeing homeless and poor. However there was no one to remove this man from the entrance to the hotel. We were told it was Valet ONLY at $14 overnight. The lot we would find out later is behind the building, where the parking lot is littered with broken glass from other car windows, and not secure at all.When I was checking in the clerk was polite and paged another person to see what room was free. She gave us our key and we went to the 4th floor. From first glance we thought the hotel wasn't "too bad for Detroit". When we got to the room there was NO soap & NO Towels. We let them know and went out to explore the town. When we returned to change for the concert we were heading to North of Detriot we found we still had no soap or towels. We also found out that on a Saturday night the Bar / Restaurant was closed. As well as no working ATM. 3 of us went to the concert and one person stayed in the room. They were able to hear NUMEROUS fights between other rooms. Once again he called to ask for towels and was told they would be sent right up. (They never were). The Coffee pot in the room had no coffee, mugs, or anything to make it work. The Alarm clock radio did not work and later that evening we would find out that the AC did not work either. The windows (that have no screens) opened. When we returned to the hotel at 1am after our concert, there was no valet, and I parked in the ONLY available parking that was the lot full of glass. Once we walked towards the lobby we were questioned by men sitting on top of cars in the front of the hotel of what was in our bags... Talking about feeling unsafe and uncomfortable... We were nervous and out numbered. We made it inside to ask once again for the towels / soap and about the AC. We over hear another customer trying to find another hotel to stay in, because of his disatisfaction with St. Regis. He was unable to find a room, so we knew then- we would have to stay for the night. THEN walks in the DAY Receptionist (who checked us in) in a BATH ROBE!!! She was staying there!! She needed towels also. When the clerk gave us the towels she did with a sigh and radioed to another person that they were "out of towels again"We slept for 4 hours and checked out. "Slept" is a word I use loosely... there was people screaming in the hotel, someone tried their key card in our door a few times, and the window having to be open because of the lack of AC made the room bright and loud. When we checked out the clerk had on her suit jacket... no visible top under it and PJ bottoms on.... FINALLY the end of this story is that the credit card I put on file for incidentals was USED 9 days later in the hotel!!! I called and they said I used it in the resturant the PRIOR day... I was not there!! I am in NY.... then they hung up on me. I had to cancel the card and file a report! DO NOT STAY HERE!I forgot to review this after my trip to Detroit last month.All in all, a really nice hotel, with friendly and attentive staff.  I think the place was recently remodeled - with very classy furniture and decor.  In other words, a nicer place than I am used to.  The bar looked pretty swank, but I didn't make it down, because I wanted to check out other Detroit spots.The hotel rooms were small, but comfy.  The beds were amazing - like sleeping on a cloud.  There was also an iPod deck, which was great for the impromptu hotel room dance parties.  Reasonably priced for the amenities.  Though the room service menu was incredibly expensive - +$7 for a bowl of cereal?  You can't be serious.  Good location in Detroit, within walking distance of good spots in the Midtown area and the lakefront.I stayed here last year and this place was way better than I expected.  It had just gone through a renovation and everything was modernized and fairly elegant.  The staff was very friendly and the valet service was quick.  The restaurant there had really good food, bar had great drinks and they even had a piano player serenading the listeners in the bar.  The rooms were very nice and clean, and the beds were good for a solid sleep.  I also really liked the iPod decks they had, which made it convenient to listen to my music in the comfort of my room. Would definitely recommend for anyone who visits Detroit and wants to be away from all the noise downtown; but still be close enough that they're only a five to ten minute cab ride away from anything in the city.I haven't had the opportunity to stay at the St.Regis but I brunch here often. Obviously if I'm going often, me likey!! The ambiance is beautiful. This hotel has had some recent renovations which has made it worth the pricey brunch. To start, you can have your OJ straight or with wine also known as a Mimosa. The brunch buffet is a free for all! You have a continental style breakfast table with croissants, danishes, fruit and bagels. The next table is for you carnivores, all the bacon, sausage patties and links, ham and turkey you want. There are two chefs that prepare fresh omelette's while you wait. You also have your choice of grits, oatmeal, pancakes, waffles, cold cereals and lots more. I often meet up here with friends whom I haven't seen in a while. The brunch will run you about $24.99 per person. Check Sunday's paper for $10 off coupons. The wait staff is usually pretty on point, the valet is always a plus and I recommend making reservations for parties larger than 6.
