Even though it's pricey for a brunch (especially without the coupon) I think it's worth it.I really wanted to like this place as I thought maybe it had some glamour back in the day but I got bed bug bites from my room! Stay away from room 410!

review_content: Just spent the weekend at Roberts Riverwalk hotel and we had a lovely time. We paid for a standard double but had two incredibly comfortable king sized beds. Plenty of hot water and good water pressure. We also happened to have lovely views of the river from our room on the fourth floor. Even though it was winter each night before dinner we enjoyed a stroll along the riverwalk with the sun setting and the moon rising. The staff was friendly and helpful and while check-in could have been faster the receptionist, was as nice as could be and was working by herself taking calls from potential guests while arranging our room. The lobby is beautiful and elegant with a 1940s charm- big windows overlooking the river which had large chunks of ice floating down it (January) and a massive marble fireplace. It was cold outside but we were cozy inside- and in our room the temperature was easy to modulate- unlike so many hotel rooms. We like it cool while we sleep but want it warm as we pad around in the morning drinking coffee.Friday night after a great evening out we went down to the hotel lounge. 8-10 people were line dancing to Motown music and they were amazing! They absolutely knew how to dance and it was a great pleasure to get to see them. We had been planning to just spend one night but we were so favorably impressed we bought tickets to the Detroit Opera House for Saturday and arranged a second night.The second night we tried the restaurant and while it was a bit of a wait to get our food the cook was very good- even the broccoli was al dente faintly touched by garlic and olive oil- delicious. Yes there were things that were not perfect- it was slightly down at the heels here and there - chip on the enamel bath tub, a drywall repair poorly done, but overall it is a Phoenix rising from the ashes. Fabulous!We absolutely plan on making a return visit in warmer weather so that we can tour the Riverwalk on our bikes- there is even a side path Dequindre Cut that goes to the Eastern Market the best for a Saturday morning.The positives: 1. A very big room! Which was great since we were traveling with our two kids (4 and 10mo). So they had room to run around a little bit. 2. Um...there's a chance you'll have a room that looks out over the river (we didn't have that luck - we had a view of the parking lot). 3. The breakfast was good. Slow but good. It's not included with the price of the room though.The negatives/could be betters: We had a leaky faucet in the bathroom. The sink had a crack in it and leaked on the floor. There were a handful of unfinished patched holes in some doors. The beds were really lumpy. No extra pillows (yes, I know, we could've asked but we were tired and didn't). When we came back one night, we got off the elevator and were greeted by a wave of pot smoke. My 4 year old looked at us and said, "woah! Where's the skunk?" We asked him to look for it. Made for a fun game. The maid staff didn't provide new soaps. This is petty but there wasn't a little guide to tell us which channels were which. Normally not an issue but when it's Saturday morning and your kids are antsy - it'd make life 30 seconds happier knowing where PBS kids might be. All in all, it didn't live up to the price tag paid for a couple nights there. The biggest surprise was the quality of the food!Julia was great at the front desk! Super friendly and helpful. Went out of her way to fix some things for us. Everyone else was great, too, actually, except for the rude ass older lady working the day shift on 12/30/15.We came to said lady, letting her know:-the room had no hot water -one sink faucet handle didn't work-the room was supplied with only the very end of a toilet paper roll-we needed a 'do not disturb' signShe treated us like the monsters we are and we had to wait for Julia to help us out later on. We'll visit again, but hopefully that lady cleans up her act.Horrible. Horrible. Horrible. Another guest walked in on us having sex. Holes in the ceiling. 30 minutes to check in. Hotel needs a serious upgrade. Hotel offers ten dollar champagne and breakfast and the restaurant knew nothing about it. Save your money. Don't book this place please.I checked in late that Thursday (11/26/15) night and off the bat I was nervous driving towards the parking lot because I saw the sign that said "park at your own risk". I have NEVER been to an establishment that had such an off putting sign ESPECIALLY since you OFFER no other options for parking. Where else was I supposed to park my car? Because it was late and I had my 2 year old in the car, I drove to the front and not only was there no bell man there were no closer parks. So I had to drive back around and fortunately I saw someone leave a park that was a little closer so I took it. Because it was so late, I was rushing to get in the hotel and I was happy to see a few people leave out so we weren't out there alone. As soon as I got inside, there was no one to great me or offer to help me with my luggage. Because there was no elevator, I had to drag my luggage and a cranky toddler up the stairs. Once in the lobby, the receptionist was pleasant enough, but when I got to my room, things began to change for the worst. After attempting to reach the front desk, I noticed that I had a the wrong phone in my room. I was in 205 and the phone said 203. I was trying to call down to ask for allergy free pillows, but because the phone did not work, I had to use my cell phone. I requested pillows and the lady said they would see if they had some, but she never came upstairs or returned my class. Secondly, housekeeping knocked on my door TWICE and opened the door while me and my son were sleeping between 9-10 am the next morning. I have NO idea why since check out was not until 11:00. Once he was up, he would not go back to sleep. Thirdly, when I returned to my car, not only was it broken into and suffered over 200.00 worth of exterior damage, money and a few valuables were stolen. When I called the front desk, no one came out to assist me at all. I had to go INSIDE to request a broom to clean up the glass. Additionally, I was not offered any type of compensation for my troubles. I asked where there cameras in the parking lot and I was told no even though there was BIG SIGN saying that you had CCTV. I was also told that security drives around nightly and I did not see anyone at all as I was coming from the parking lot. The manager NEVER came out to offer ANY assistance after my ordeal. Being from Chicago, I am not familiar with Detroit and it was very frustrating having to figure out what to do. It was only after my sister requested to see him that Mr. Evans (the manager on duty) appeared and needless to day he was MORE than unprofessional. He lied about when he found out about the incident, REFUSED to comp my room, and implied that if I was staying an extra day he might be willingly to comp me (when asked about it later, he lied that he did not say that even though my sister, brother and the front desk lady Shelia heard otherwise). He did offer to buy us lunch from the downstairs bar but that was only offered AFTER we talked about how unprofessional he was. Lastly, I called back to request the contact info from Sheila and as of today, I have NEVER heard back from your establishment.Roberts Riverwalk hotel is NOT only UNSAFE, they don't treat your customers well. Attached is pictures of the damage and FALSE advertising of CCTV'sI thought this place had some potential. Nicely decorated throughout, but the small things added up. Cold water didn't work in the sink. Hot water didn't work in the shower. Phone didn't work. Then there was a nice wake up call at 2:30am from a couple of guys trying to get into the room. Seems there was a mix up at the front desk and the room was double booked. Buyer beware. You do get what you pay for.I'll agree with everyone else, it's a really pretty hotel. Because it's Detroit and because of how things are going, I'm not going to be super critical. I reserved a large river view room with 2 queen beds. We came in late, around midnight and had no problem checking in. The room was exactly as pictured, which I feel never happens these days. I tried a few websites for the best price, but really wanted a river view and the price wasn't crazy. The room we were in (127) was situated on the corner of the hotel and gave us a pretty view of the Detroit river and Canada (which is across the river). That being said, cell phone service was really tricky, but manageable.We weren't around long enough to eat at the restaurant or order room service, but I will say there is orange juice served every early morning as well as fresh water with lemon at all times. The reception staff was on duty 24 hours a day, which was nice and the few times we called we were serviced promptly. The only downsides is that our room could have been tended to a little better. The tops of the curtains were super dusty and the faucet in the shower came off. The sink in the bathroom only had cold water, which someone said they were "waiting on a part"....when that will come, who knows. The televisions were large and we had 2 in the room. The channels were so so , but who comes to a hotel to watch tv?I'd come back and probably try to request a higher floor, although it did make everything manageable walking back and forth from the front of the hotel.Great room, great view, great location. The representative was really helpful, as I shared my concerns w her from reading other reviews. She was honest and made sure our stay was going to be comfortable as possible.Complaints from other reviews: water temperature, room temperature &TV reception I look at it like this. You get what you pay. This place was very reasonable compared to $150-$275 a night.Horrible customer service and the hotel and grounds are in disrepair. The security (who are in place due to numerous break-ins to cars which the hotel will do nothing about) was extremely rude and inappropriate. What a shame, amazing setting but it cannot make up for the poor management/ownership!Has to be the most unprofessional establishment I have ever been too.The place looks really nice on the inside, and that's about the only good thing I can say. Upon arriving to see other people waiting in a lobby, that has a bootleg check in desk. I didn't know what I had gotten myself into. I counted 5 guests that were overbooked that were already angry. Some like myself had been given keys to rooms only to find out that someone was already sleeping in the rooms. Talk about dangerous! Then they don't even want to take responsibility for their own mistakes. The management had no real answers for me or the steady stream of customers that continued to file in with their useless reservations. I will be posting again in a few days after I talk to the general manager. Driving from out of town, with kids and risking strangers coming in your room with a key is a no go for me.When using a groupon to dine here...warning print it first! They do not accept the phone scan! Handicap enter on front ramp to the left of doors. It was locked. I ran in, downstairs, to door to unlock the door. Service was outstanding!The gal was terrific with what limited menu she is given! View terrific! Potential for an outstanding restaurant. Steak bites were very good! Homemade mashed, fresh green beans. The lobby ladies could not be nicer! Good bones, great staff, listen to their needs for improvement !Shower temp bad, outlets not workingI kept trying to find the catch here because it was such a reasonable rate, but I couldn't find one. Everything was clean, and everyone was helpful. It was a little quirky, but that's more enjoyable to me than a cookie cutter Day's Inn. Unfortunately I didn't get to spend as much time here as I wanted to, since it was just a short trip. I would love to come back and check out the live music.An absolute nightmare. Security guard in parking lot is aggressive and psychotic. Front desk is indifferent and unconcerned. Ownership and management are liars. Hotels.com refunded my money but I was still out $300 for damage caused to my vehicle by their security guard.The could be a real Jewel in the heart of Detroit, under different management. If you read most of the reviews, you will realilze how little management cares about your stay or planned event. Front desk staff are very nice, but with little or very slow WIFI, check in takes about 30 minutes and most of the time, your room assignment will be incorrect. There is literally No staff around to ask for anything regarding your room. The room we booked was very nice, however, I heard several guests complaining about the air conditioning not working in their rooms.By all means, DO NOT book a wedding at Roberts. They will promise you the moon and cant possibly deliver. Unprofessional, inexperienced waitstaff, horrible food preparation (dont let the taste test fool you), no coffee service, bread plates, no ice or water service at dinner, just complete lack of professionalism. Even the hotel grounds have no landscaping. Weeds and cigarette butts were found everywhere around the hotel. They don't take any responsibility for under-estimating food count, losing the wedding cake, running out of liqour and beer...etc. My advice is to pick somewhere else in downtown Detroit. What it could be and what it is are Years apart unless management changes.Very pretty hotel, sort of vintage. It has a lot of potential but bad administration. Morales hours for check in. The hotel overlooks the river and next is Canada, nice view. We stayed in a king suite which was ok, my friends had a penthouse which obviously was nicer. TV cable sucked quality was bad . Do not order room service. The guy was extremely rude and asked to pay him cash cause " it's easier " and then said " your lucky because this is the last room service of the day " ( it was 10A) I paid almost $30 for many items from Which I only got half, missed a fruit bowl plus another OJ, and when I called to let re guy know he missed those he said first tried to tell meHow the continental breakfast was only oatmeal and OJ when the menu listed oatmeal, OJ or milk, fruits or granola, etc. then to avoid discussion he said ok I'll send it for $2.40, which then sent me toast which wasn't what I had ordered. When I complained to management they dismissed me quickly. It's supposed to run till 11p however I called at 9 and it "Was closed early today". I would recommend another hotel for the price.This hotel used to be nice...keywords...USED TO BE. I stayed here previously when this hotel was the Omni. From the moment we pulled up, we knew things had changed. Gone is the valet. Gone is the bellhop. There isn't even a sign to tell you where to park. In the parking lot, there was a Detroit Police car with a half-primer colored hood. Ummm...SKETCHY! The lobby was okay. The staff was nice. As soon as we got into the elevator, we knew things were going to go downhill. The walls in the elevator looked like plywood with no paint. The elevator was noisy and moved like a sloth! We got into our room and the smell was terrible! It smelled like someone poured a gallon of bleach in the room and then left. There were holes in the drop down ceiling when you walk in. The sheets were stained. The furniture was very damaged. The whole thing felt sketchy. Luckily, the friendly front desk staff let us checkout and get a full refund and we moved hotels. It's sad considering that this hotel is right by the river, in what used to be a beautiful building.The staff were friendly, rooms clean, and it is a great location. Unfortunately, we didn't have hot water in our room and had to take a cold shower. We didn't have time to call the front desk because we were in a hurry. We told them on our way out and they apologized. This hotel was a good deal with a beautiful view.Boutique hotel right on the river in a quiet section of town. Great location. The rooms have beautiful floor to ceiling windows, high ceilings and are well appointed. Parking is included in the rate. It is an older building that has been nicely renovated. We will stay there again. Booking.com reservation was under 100 a nightWhen i booked the room it was suppose to come with a pull out couch and a fridge but my room sidnt have eaither. There was hair on the bed. I left a few personal items in the room after i had checked out. I called shortly after leaving the hotel to let them know i left my belongings. The front desk said she would call me back when house keeper went to the room and she never called me back.
review_content_20: I highly suggest you stay elsewhere if possible. We had so many problems with this hotel. I arrived for a family reunion and came to find they would not allow early check in, which would have made sense however there were already about ten couples waiting, it was 2:45PM, and check in started at 3pm. Instead of being smart and checking in as they came, they let it back up. Then they were so slow it took an hour for us to even get to the check in desk once they finally started checking people in, only to be told we had no reservation. We called and confirmed our reservation twice, and this happened to three other families staying in our group as well. Thank god for Venus, part of hotel management, for working things out for us rather than the rude woman at the check in desk who told us it wasn't her problem. In fact, most of the employees are generally rude. We met about three who were nice (the cook in the restaurant, Venus, and a housekeeper). The rest were just nasty and obviously didn't value the fact that they had a job. We had to go get new keys every day because, as others have said, they stopped working. There is practically no air conditioning. The live jazz on the terrace was nice until it was past 10 and we wanted to go to sleep.The shower only had one temperature: boiling hot.If you're only looking for a pretty venue, this is a great place for pictures. Just as long as you don't stay the night, expect them to find your reservation, expect polite staff, air conditioning, or anything any other hotel, even a basic Motel 6, would have.They do not deserve even one star. Worst hotel EVER. No hot water, rude staff, disgusting conditions. Only phone that works is in bathroom. No vending machines. Despicable. Awful, awful, awful. Nasty. Run away. Wouldn't stay here for free or cash bonus.What is a hotel that cannot honor a reservation made a month ago? Not much of a hotel... No notice, just arrived at 2 am to have receptionist say reservation was cancelled by hotel due to overbooking and that no, no one tried to contact us about it. No room, no manager on duty, no arrangement with other hotel, nothing but "sorry for the inconvenience."I would not stay here again.Nice rooms, inept staff. They spent 5 hours checking me in after messing up their reservations. As I sat waiting in the lobby, they repeatedly asked how I could have messed up since it surely wasn't their fault.Later that night a different staff member asked me why I was never checked in properly, as they had an open room left vacant under my name.ProsNice location on the waterSoft bedsDecent water pressureGreat bar downstairs with friendly bartendersConsIncompetent reservation systems/staffLimited hot waterPhones won't connect to the front deskStrange building configuration - a neighboring room had a window looking straight into our roomHousekeeping service didn't pick up towels or refill the shampoo, they only made the bedTo sum up this review, Robert's Riverwalk is extremely mediocre. The room was good, but can give a "Scooby Doo" vibe because the lighting is very dim. If you have kids, this probably isn't the best place to stay because it is far away from everything, and you still have to walk through a not-so-nice neighborhood to even get to the Riverwalk. This hotel is also missing a lot of things that you would normally find at a big hotel, such as room service, a good television, and fast service. The front desk staff was slow, but they managed to get us a good cab to the airport at 4am. This surprised us because they seemed to be slow and kind of lazy when it came to everything else. Even the maid service made the bed while leaving things under the sheets, like the television remote, which just made the staff seem even more lazy. Also, the last night we stayed, the lady at the front desk thought it was too cold in the lobby, so she shut off the air conditioning in the WHOLE HOTEL. on a hot, humid summer day in Michigan, this was AWFUL. Next time I stay in Detroit I will definitely stay at the Double Tree or Marriott because my stay here was not up to par. If you are staying more than one or two nights, or plan on actually doing things in downtown, I suggest you stay elsewhere.The parking was a little confusing if you're coming from the back way so be careful with that. My time spent here was short but sweet. There was a beautiful view of the river from my room as well as the lobby which was also pretty gorgeous as well. The customer service was as helpful as could be. We called ahead of time about the shuttle and when we got there were told the shuttle wasn't running (on a Saturday) later in the evening come to find out the cleaning woman is also the shuttle driver and it was available that day only when she had free time though. Aside from that there was no problems with the employees. As for the rooms our phones didn't work and we were told someone was going to come up and fix it but never did, but I mean we had our cell phones so no big deal. The room did smell a little at first but they're remodeling so that was the cause, the air was acting weird but they have people working on that as I type. & there was paint chipping and wall paper coming off the walls but it wasn't really that noticeable. Other than all that I had a nice time I got to stay in My room and watch a nice flat screen and the restaurant in the basement was delicious(get the senior burger platter with everything it's delish). Little tip though if you are y'all be careful in the bathrooms cause the ceilings are a little lower. I'm 5'10 and hit my hand on the ceiling while changing and showering. So just be careful. I will return thoughShort story: Horrible customer service, I never even made it into my room. Do not stay here.Details: My colleague and I reserved rooms 2 months in advance of our stay. I called the hotel to confirm my reservation the day prior to check-in (based on some of the reviews here, I wanted to make sure everything was on track for a successful stay), and was told I was confirmed. I called later that day to ask if there is a shuttle from the hotel (there isn't), and upon arrival in Detroit the evening of my check-in I called a third time to try and set up a shuttle ride the next morning to a local destination (the shuttle doesn't start until 9am, which wasn't early enough for me).When we arrived at the hotel, we were told our rooms were not available due to a water main break that occurred over 24 hours ago. I asked why no one reached out to me with this news (they said they did but when I didn't pick up my phone, they didn't bother to leave a message). I asked why no one told me about this the THREE times I called prior to my arrival. They could not answer my questions.They made alternate reservations for us at a hotel 23 miles away - and they were not willing to pay for my taxi rides during my stay (I had no car). This was not an equivalent accommodation.I ended up getting a room at the Marriott (also located downtown, not 23 miles away) for roughly 5-times the price of this hotel. I asked The Roberts Riverwalk to pay for my Marriott hotel bill, and they, of course, declined to do so.SAVE YOUR TIME AND YOUR MONEY!!! HORRIBLE EXPERIENCE!Room key system didn't work. Had to have an employee walk us to our room and unlock the door.Water pressure was terrible. Could not take a decent shower. Water was still running in the tub. Room was FREEZING!Other guest were LOUD. No smoking hotel, yet guests were smoking. I'm asthmatic. Purchased "free breakfast" package, only to be told, "we don't serve breakfast no more"Please don't stay here. Only one star because the staff was nice/pleasant.Stayed here 3 to 4 years ago when in town for a Wings game... was nice then...very dingy dirty and smelly now. Got a refund from hotels.com and went to Motor City instead. NOT WORTH YOUR MONEYClean, spacious rooms; wonderful views of the river; great value overall. This family owned hotel is a comfortable place to stay in Detroit. We stayed at the Double Tree when we last visited, but I'd much rather give my money to a locally-owned establishment than a chain. We enjoyed a handful of bars and restaurants in walking distance, such as Atwater Brewery, Andrew's on the Corner, and They Say. Shuttle service is available, but we decided to walk or drive instead. Brunch smelled delicious but we opted for breakfast and Bloody Marys at the Grand Trunk on Woodward. The full bar in the basement includes a pool table and nice views of the river, but it was a bit pricier than I would have expected. We will definitely return to the Roberts next time we visit Detroit.Well, this is interesting. I think I have offended some minor deity and my stay here is penance.The Good: high ceilings, bay windows, a fairly decent Queen bed, good view of Windsor. And we paid for a King bed too. Windsor, as in Wndsor-across-the-river-in-another-country-where-I-wish-was. (side note: the maintenance man wears Fruit Of The Loom tightly whiteys, and I know this as his back end is currently waggling at me from the ceiling) some of the places I've stayed in Mexico with the bullet holes and the guard at the door with the handlebar mustache would be preferable to this place right now.Why? Well, first, there is the aforementioned maintenance man. We've been here two hours and he's just now starting to work on the AC in the room. I was a little miffed at them taking so long to sending someone up to fix it, after several calls and their EternaHold call avoidance methods to the front desk, so I decided to vist them personally. Kudos to the flamboyant guy at the front desk and rolling with every hit I gave him. Well played sir, I have met my match in trolling with you. Tis is how the conversation went, mostly."Hi! I'm in room 428, it's hot and getting hotter. We've called a couple of times about the AC and the leak in the ceiling. The good news is that the water has stopped pooling in the entrance to the room and is now going through the hole in the floor to the room below."Some bare excuse about how the maintenance guy got the call and he'd be there eventually.(maintenance man just told me the water is from the wounded AC unit)"Okay, I'm an engineer and I don't know anything about cooling systems, but I can takes a look at it if you're okay with that."Guy at the desk brightens up and agrees. Whoa... I need to step up my game."Sure, I'll see what I can do. There probably won't be any damage. Where are the fire extinguishers?"Guy at the desk tells me to go for it and there are extinguishers on each floor. This guy is good. Another guy walks up and has appranetly caught bits of the conversation. He has that I'm In Charge look and is much brainier than the Mister Oblivious guy at the desk. He reaches for a radio and we're on our way back to the room with Fruit Of The Loom guy, who is a rather pleasant person when he isn't waggling at you.This is a review in progress, so we'll see what the next stage of our adventure will be.I didn't stay at the hotel, this review is just for the bar area. I was here for a function and had wanted a drink. I love a good hotel bar. The people were great (bartenders, kitchen staff) -- I'll give them that. But the drinks are WAY overpriced. This is a bar in a hotel off the beaten path, nice view of the riverwalk from a basement point of view... nice lil patio, which has summertime potential. But I paid $8.48 for a short bloody mary. Really?That being said, I hung out and had some more drinks after the function I was attending was over. Good times with the folks behind the bar, good drinks and GREAT fries. There is live music on Weds nights, which would be great, except for the high prices of the drinks. NO internet service on my phone here :-(Stayed here for the Orion Fest 2013. From beginning to end everyone was very friendly and helpful, from the front desk to the shuttle driver. Room has tall ceilings and plenty of room. Room was very clean upon arrival. All new sheets and towels. Now there is no fridge, microwave, iron, or hair dryer. And the in room safe was unavailable, cable tv with no movie channels or any pay-per-views of any kind. We woke up late on Monday and checked out an hour late with no extra charge. Really appreciated this!!! All in all a really good experience for Detroit and this hotel, would return again. And the A/C was all kinds of cold throughout the stay. We were on the first floor near the lobby.We stayed here for a night on my first visit to Detroit, attending a wedding. We like to support locally owned businesses, so when I was able to reserve a room here for $115, I checked out some reviews and went for it.The hotel itself is gorgeous and historic, with vintage charm. Beautiful high ceilings and tall windows. I loved the dim lighting and classic furniture. It definitely brought some character I wouldn't have found at a chain. This aspect of it allowed me to forgive many of the shortcomings of the management and other parts of our stay.Parking was free for guests, but the valet lot (where we parked) was pretty tough to get to, and the pavement was cracked and filled with potholes. I didn't really mind, but my boyfriend was a little annoyed.The location is kind of out of the way, in a warehouse area that gets pretty dark and deserted at night. Nothing really walkable other than a brewpub a few blocks away, so we opted to stay in when we left the wedding reception.Check-in was a pretty slow process, but I'm guessing that's because of the big event that was apparently going on. It was inconvenient, but the staff was friendly and accommodating when they did serve us. Check-out was simple and quick.We stayed on the 4th floor and opted to take the stairs most of the time, because the elevator is pretty slow. The carpets were a bit stained, and the tub looked dirty. I don't think it actually *was* dirty, it was just old. The lobby was super hot and stuffy, which made me worried that the air conditioning wasn't working, as some reviewers had stated. But our room was cool and comfortable. The bed was clean, spacious, and comfy.Like I said, I appreciate charm, character, and history. Roberts Riverwalk Hotel has all three. If you are looking for a perfect stay, this probably isn't your place. Some of the poor reviews here do point out some justifiable issues. However, it was affordable, safe, and clean for an older hotel. I would stay here again.DO NOT STAY HEREI booked 15 rooms here while it being close to my wedding venue. I was curious why my venue did not recommend using this hotel, but I after my stay I can see why. I had such high hopes for this place and they were crushed as soon as I spoke to someone.Customer service- Robert's Riverwalk had the worst customer service I have ever experienced in a hotel. There were a few male employees that were very helpful, but for the most part it seemed like it was everyone's first job dealing with customers. I had about over 15 rooms booked at this hotel because of my wedding and any small request I had they couldn't promise me anything. They acted like even just checking me or any of my party in was a big deal to them. In fact, I had one employee named Talasha who put her hand in my maid of honors face when trying to help her locate a name on the paper in front of her. The staff here needs to be trained and managed better.Room Quality- 2 of the rooms used were not able to use the phone and call the front desk, my lamp was broken, I had wall paper peeling off the walls., my Maid of Honor's toliet and bathtub were busted, and the list could continue.Food- It would be good if someone's mother cooked it for me. I would never waste my money on their food again.Summary- This hotel has potenital. It's a great location but it needs to be better managed!I will begin with the pros:The hotel is clean. The bed is soft. The hotel has free parking and was easy to find. My hot water never ran out and the pressure of the shower head was relaxing. No one stole anything from my room or my car. Cons: Continental breakfast ends at 9AM? It's Sunday morning. For almost $150 a night I expected many more amenities. This wasn't a horrible experience by any means. I just feel like for the price I could have done waaaaaay more valuable things with my money. I ate at all these nice restaurants and wasted all my leftovers because there is no refrigerator (as advertised). There's a safe (as advertised) in the room but no key. Allegedly you can receive all these features according to the website when I booked but when I peek around, I can't any of said amenities. Check-in time is ??????? Check out time is ??????? I prefer to stay hotels like this with some personality instead of Holiday Inns usually. The staff was friendly but the check-in process was confusing. No mention of the continental breakfast - when it was served and where. There is no literature in the rooms to inform the guests where to locate these services. The staff was friendly and personable. Under any other circumstances I would have found them enjoyable company, but I'm paying $150 a night and I can't figure out where anything is and when to expect it. Also, there are two phones in the room and neither of them work. Cable has channels but it's so basic, after surfing through a few times, I gave up and went to bed only to wake up completely disappointed that my leftovers from Slow's BBQ are now expired (because there is no fridge, as advertised). Summary: In downtown Detroit, either go big or go home. Basically $200/night will give your an impressive experience or $60-$70 will give you a minimal/scary stay. I guess $150 is the "Goldilocks Zone." No one will steal your car, your bed will be soft, but don't expect breakfast or any volunteered information about what you are paying for at the Roberts Riverwalk. Not bad, just meh. In the time it took me to write this, my coffee is now cold. I'll just heat it in the invisible microwave that was advertised in the Expedia ad.If ur lukn for a mozy wozy place and a trip bac to 1950, the bthrm is lik somethg from a bad verison of harlem nghts ,thn this is ur place ,it sucks big time ,if wnt to jus lay ur head and go n the morning this is ur place .....other than tht donot go thr. This place has the essence to be grt ,but much needed renovating is needed ,nice view of the river ....The Roberts Riverwalk hotel is staffed with unprofessional, untrained and uncaring personnel. A recent stay at this hotel almost ruined my vacation. It seemed the staff went out of their way to be incompetent. They never seemed to know anything about anything. I decided to to talk to the hotel dotcom which I had used to reserve my hotel room to settle a problem with the hotel, a rocking party was going on underneath my room, and the hotel management intentionally hung up on the travel agency representative twice. Incredible they would screw with the service that brings them hotel guests. When I was checking in, the hotel staff had a serious attitude problem - for absolutely no reason. Every question was received with rolled eyes and a sneer. When I was checking out, the hotel staff couldn't figure out the procedure for pre-paid hotel guests. That situation seems to be so uncomplicated everywhere else I've stayed. The owners should be ashamed.I'll never stay here again.I recently stayed here for a Lions game and after reading all the reviews here on Yelp I really wanted to give this hotel some much needed credit. The hotel is located a little outside of the downtown hussle and bussle but it was a quick shuttle ride to the game! The shuttle is also FREE from the hotel. I will warn you make sure you are downstairs waiting for it and plan to have a few loads before you. We did take a cab back to the hotel and it was less than $10. Room was nice and clean, the staff was pleasent and helpful. Overall I would recommend this hotel to others and it was a great value since all we really wanted was a bed to sleep in. I will say don't bother with the food-bar area downstairs. They seemed to be over worked and nothing like the service we received at the reception desk.If you like historic vintage charm with lack of cleanliness and actual amenities, then this is your place. The staff was actually amazing! My wife calls this place janky, and I'm pretty sure there was poop or mud on the wall in the first room we had before we moved for that and lack of water that could be regulated in the shower... Then we were moved to a deluxe room where we got 3 pillows instead of 2, a makeup mirror that broke off as well as a shower head that was supposed to be a wand but wouldn't move off its mount! Oh and the tub leaked so we then had a water park in the bathroom. It had a big cheap flat screen though and a view of our car in the parking lot! All in all I say it wasn't bad LOL! The actual riverwalk and patio part was very pretty though!
review_content_40: I photographed a wedding reception that was held here in their banquet room. Loved how they had access to the river from the private room. The banquet room was also very nice and quaint. And I photographed the couple in the lobby which was absolutely stunning. Overall I give them an A - parking is valet or street. And the rooms are decorated kinda old school but I loved it.Came here for my wedding (along with a thankfully small block of our friends who had booked here as well) and am appalled by the 'service' we received. First of all, the rack rate for our room, 'the honeymoon suite', was $499. Due to what I assume was a temporary issue on their website, we got it for the discounted AAA rate of $149 (when we looked to book another room the next week, it was back to $449, the normal 10% off AAA rate). If we had paid any more than $149 I would have been horrified. The air conditioner wasn't working and there were no windows in the three level 'suite'. 'Suite' is in quotes just because it so woefully underdelivered on the expectations we had after reading the description on the website. It was dingy and didn't feel clean, not to mention we were sweating all night due to the stuffy air that all my friends reported feeling in their rooms too. It was impossible to sleep. But the worst part was checking in. We had called earlier in the week to see if we would be able to get into our room before the 3 p.m. check-in so I could put on my wedding dress for pictures before our 5 p.m. wedding. They were unable to guarantee an early check-in, which I understand. However we called twice more on the day of the wedding to say that we really needed to be in our room at 3 p.m. (called twice instead of once because of the noncommittal response to the first request). We arrive at 2:59 p.m. I am in full make-up with a veil and carrying a huge wedding dress. My maid-of-honor, an extremely sweet and polite person, asked the woman at the desk how long it would be before we could check in (she was just chatting with the man she had just checked in). She rolled her eyes and said 'Ma'am, I'll get to you when we can'. My friend reiterated that we were on a tight schedule (which should've been obvious, I had a freaking VEIL on) and the woman just sighed really loudly and picked up the phone and told whoever was on the other end 'Um yes, these people are apparently in some kind of rush, could you get room 102 ready?' We got into the room by 3:15, and nothing was going to ruin my day at that point, but damn if they didn't try. The only reasons to stay here are if you have an event at this hotel, or at the Rattlesnake Club next door.I booked this hotel on Hotwire (~100 with taxes for one night). I was quite worried about it after reading the reviews on here, but really, I needn't have worried. I wouldn't say that this was the best hotel I've ever stayed at, but everything was just fine. Which, when you are just crashing for a night after some heavy duty shopping, is really all you are looking for. It IS a little far from the downtown core. Not walkable. They do offer a shuttle bus service, but we waited over 30 minutes to catch it. It's also hard to find a taxi in Detroit, so getting back to the hotel is difficult, especially since the shuttle stops running at 10:30. We did call the shuttle to pick us up at about 10pm, but the cell phone was off, and the answering machine was full.It is an older hotel, but I sort of enjoyed the vintage feel. The staff were friendly, as were the other hotel guests. Parking was free and wifi was free. Essential when Canadians travel to the US.In the end it was a good option for me. I would stay there again.Detroit's motto should be: "It COULD be great, but..."Like much of Detroit, Roberts Riverwalk Hotel COULD be great, but, simply put, it's not. Maybe it's fine in the off-season. Maybe it's fine in the winter, when it's not 90 degrees in the room. Maybe it's fine when there isn't a huge event going on, but maybes don't cut it when you're talking about hotels. Guests have minimum expectations when paying to stay at a hotel, and this hotel does not meet the minimums.The hotel itself has an old charm to it; insanely high ceilings in the rooms on the 4th floor, spacious bathrooms, expansive windows in the room that offer views of the riverfront (if you're lucky; my reservation said I had one but I didn't get one...). It has character. But then, the room is 90 degrees, the air conditioning doesn't work, you're promised a king-sized bed and get a king-sized headboard with a queen mattress tacked onto it, there's a puddle on the carpet when you enter the room and a constant drip from the ceiling above it, the front desk staff is frazzled and harried and promises a visit from housekeeping (for extra pillows) and maintenance (for fixing the leak and a/c) and these things don't happen. Come on, Roberts, get your act together! You're going to lose money and loyalty and go the way of so much of this beautiful city: ruin.Very disappointed.EDIT: When someone apologizes and makes things right, I am willing to re-think my original feelings and sometimes change my mind. Well, this is one of those times. The management at Roberts Riverwalk Hotel was sympathetic to our situation and, upon learning that we were heading home without staying the night, somehow managed to find a beautifully freezing king bed room on the first floor. They even had to let us back in to the room each time we left because they didn't have a key for it (Huh?) and did so graciously and quickly each time. The manager even came outside where we were enjoying the BBQ and live music, found us, and made sure that the accommodations were now to our standards. I really appreciate all the effort and hospitality we experienced for the remainder of our stay. I'd think twice before staying here again, but it will be an option. It turned out to be nice for the Detroit fireworks and it was worth it to stay downtown to avoid the crowds and fake shootings and non-existent bomb scares that got everyone in a panic closer to the action. Still, I stand by my original opinion that this hotel has some issues that should be resolved before it could be considered anything above three stars.I really like the character of this hotel....I have stayed here twice while in Detroit. First time was a year ago...the room had a broken AC unit and had to switch rooms. Was given a very nice room with huge windows overlooking the river because of the inconvenience. Returned again a couple weeks ago...everything was great this time around as well. Definitely worth the price. There is a bar downstairs that also serves food. The only reason they don't get 5 stars is the location is near a lot of vacant industrial buildings and the back parking lot is dark at night....seems a bit shady. However I did see multiple security guards patrolling on foot and in vehicles around the property which is good. Check in was quick and they have free Wifi and parking is also free. I will be backGood to know:Hotel is not in downtown Detroit, its two miles away in a not-so-good area.Rooms are cheaper if you book through the hotel itself, we booked through hotels.com and paid $40 more and got overbooked.Free parking if you trust to leave your car there.The only positive thing about this hotel is that the place is nice overall, the lobby is pretty fancy and it looks like it has some history.On the other hand, the staff was pretty rude and service was slow. The rooms got overbooked and the lady treated it like it was my fault for expecting what I paid for (a view of the river). On that alone I would never come here again or recommend anyone else stay here either. The hallway reeked of pot smoke all night and the next day (but if your room smells like smoke they will charge you $250, of course). The room was comfortable in size and amenities but it was not the most clean place ever. The bath mat was so ragged that if I worked there I would be embarrassed to leave it in the room. The worst part was the "continental" breakfast, so crappy was this breakfast that they put a menu to the restaurant on the table. Seriously, there were 4 mini muffins and 2 danish, OJ and coffee. Ugh. We were happy to leave in the morning. Oh forgot to mention in the good to know department, they charge a $50 refundable key deposit for a PLASTIC key. A cheap plastic key. I'm sure they don't know that a key deposit is for an actual key.Me and a big group of friend had a memorable "get together, eat, drink, go out, come back late and crash" type of a night in one of the Omni's $450 suites. It was a great experience. The suite was multi-level, with a nice bathroom on the main floor, living space with sofa (pullout bed in it), a TV, and a bar/sink area. Go up the stairs and you have a window view with a loungy circular seating area, along with yet another bathroom and a king size bed and another TV up there. So yes, it felt like having a nice condo, or 1 bedroom apartment in the city for the night. We split the $450 cost among 6-7 of us so the dent in the wallet was minimized.Overall the hotel has great service, and it has an antique European feeling to it. Some would call it outdated, but the olden-style is preserved so well and kept classy enough to be called antique, rather than outdated. Well, the perfectly preserved cordless phone from the 90s was probably more so outdated than antique, but hey, when in Rome! This is a diamond in the rough, bordering on some nearby rough Detroit neighborhoods, but as long as you are navigating yourself wisely, no problem! When my group and I were enjoying music and drinking in the suite, the staff made sure to never bother us and they made sure to leave the neighboring suite empty so that we wouldn't bother anyone else, and for regards to our privacy.Basic single/double occupancy rooms here can be had for sub-$100 rates via Hotwire & Priceline, and the suites are some of the comfiest in the D. They are also very kind to late checkouts at 1PM, which guys like me who party hard on Saturday nights can appreciate on a detox Sunday afternoon. This is a good hotel, and the only reason I feel compelled to take a star away, is because the location is a few blocks further from downtown than I'd like to be, and also the pricing is a tad steep when you go directly through the hotel, the value is FAR better via Hotwire or Priceline.Very nice...no...superb.I must say that I have never had a more accommodating nor helpful hotel staff experience. The manager was too helpful and the associates were all about giving me great service. The manager personally helped me unload my suitcases and wouldn't let me do anything with them. Really? I have never seen such a thing and was completely amazed. I did have to move rooms, but I was warned ahead of time that space was sporadic due to several wedding parties and the Halloween weekend. This did not bother me and I told her to put me where she had space. I will be returning and I will be staying again. Yes, it is a little pricey, but you get service that far exceeds the price.Wonderful hotel. I'd absolutely stay here again if I ever head back to the area.I loved the look of the hotel. I read it used to be a brewery, which certainly contributed to it's unique character. The rooms were huge, had a river view (though we booked a standard room), and we're extremely comfortable. The services they provide were first class and well done. I really felt pampered without having to ask for things. The staff was super friendly and genuinely made us feel welcome. The river walk out back is beautiful and sadly underused. The immediate area around the hotel is very nice, safe, and well taken care of, but the main drag (Jefferson, I think) looked to be a bit on the shady side. I'd probably stick to the grounds or convenient hotel provided transportation.One downside; the hotel restaurant was a bit of a disappointment, especially because we booked a room that came with a $40 per day food and beverage credit. The food wasn't horrendous, but it was something along the lines of "Denny's" quality. Pretty sub par for an Omni hotel. Also, it's a slight rip off, because if you use your $40 credit for $8 worth of coffee and bagels you don't get any change.That aside...tops for Detroit. Check it out if you are in the area.Arrived around 5 called twice to confirm 1st floor room because I am on crutches. Assured twice room would be available, no first floor room. Check in lady though friendly could not come up with any excuse. Managed to get me on next floor after telling me the only available was on 4th. Seemed apologetic made sure to confirm shuttle service for 6 arrived in lobby 5 minutes to 6 and shuttle had left, check in lady again apologetic claimed she thought she saw us get on, I was on crutches, I stuck out. Made it a point to get shuttle back on time for us, that was nice. Shuttle driver hilarious and room was very clean. Asked for a cart to carry in luggage, was told matience man was on break, only one to have access, again I'm slightly handicapped my friend had to truck everything in from parking lot. Loved the ambiance, didn't have time to check out bar but would stay again when I don't need specific details fulfilled.This is a great, black-owned, family-run, beautiful old school hotel located right on the river. We had a great conference hosted here, you will be treated wonderfully. Everyone has a smile and asks how you're doin, seems like the whole staff honestly enjoys working there. It's not the Ritz-Carlton in terms of fancy pants, but that's not what this place is about. Free wi-fi, free muffins and coffee in the morning, a beautiful outdoor fire pit area to hang in the summer, wonderful old-fashioned bar and pool table. Can't say enough, this place is great!I stayed here last weekend on the tenth of September with my three closest friends, for my birthday. Upon walking in my room, I was pleasantly surprised by the high ceilings and antique furnishings. We had the most perfect view of th Detroit River and Canada. Buuut this place definitely had its shortcomings as well. Like I said, it was my birthday and the concierge offered to keep my cake in the hotels kitchen refrigerator since a personal one would cost extra. I agreed and thanked him. Later that night, when my friends and I were ready to cut my cake and begin the festivities, the front desk clerk told me the kitchen was locked and that I wouldn't be able to get it that night. Imagine my surprise and dismay! I wasn't happy at all and made sure he knew it. They also don't serve breakfast and for some reason the phones in the room don't work. Whenever we tried to call room service or the front desk, there was a busy signal. I had to physically go down to the front desk every time I needed something. Like I said, its a great- looking establishment with amazing views, but the customer care was quite atrocious.Tucked away off the beaten path, this hotel provides top-notch service. Our room was beautiful, and the location is quite soothing, as you have the Riverwalk directly behind the hotel. The Omni provides free shuttle service to and from downtown, which was super quick and efficient. The staff here are really second to none, we saw these guys take care of a totally filled hotel (Frozen Four was in town), and making it look easy. To me, that's a sign of a well oiled machine.Why did this place close?!?!We chose this hotel because my daughter wanted to get married and in the D. Reservations were made for 10 rooms in January for a July wedding. The sales lady was very nice and accommodating and made lots of promises including a shuttle bus before and after the wedding for our guests. We ultimately booked over 20 rooms and added a morning brunch for 50 guests. Everything went downhill from here. Upon check-in we found the lines long because there was only one lady at the front desk. The carpet was dirty, the elevator didn't work correctly, the rooms were disheveled, parts of the bathtub and sink were broken. All this was added to the maintenance list, however maintenance never showed up. The parking lot was a joke, gravel with potholes and very small. Valet parking was supposed to be included to our guests however each one of them was charged $7. The next morning several of our guests could not find their cars. The keys were just thrown in a pile at the front desk. The shuttle bus driver who was also the assistant manager was almost nonexistent. Many of the wedding guests had to hire their own taxis to return them to the hotel. I hired the limo for an additional two hours to return the wedding party. The morning after caused problems when the elevator was broken for three and half hours. The brunch for 50 guests was tasty but we had to continually ask for more coffee more eggs more bacon more of everything. The two servers seemed indifferent and we're not accommodating to our needs. I was shocked when I received my bill for the brunch and noticed a 21% gratuity. We ultimately spoke to the sales lady who suggested we write a letter to the assistant vice president. We wrote the letter detailing all the problems and have not received any reply. We followed up several times with no reply. It has now been two monthsFor your own peace of mind go elsewhere, DO NOT frequent place.I gave it at one star review so I could post this even though it deserved none.I stayed here last weekend with hotwire rate. The hotel itself looked and felt like a dated holiday inn. I appreciate that it is now independent, but I they need to make the little updates to make it worth staying 2 miles north of downtown. Maybe I'd feel different with a river view room, but I don't think I'll be trying it out again.DO NOT GO HERE and USE your CREDIT CARD at the BAR!! We recently had a Holiday party here in December 2011 and a fellow co-worker used her credit card to purchase some drinks. The bartender stole the numbers off the credit card and in a matter of minutes $900 was racked up on the co-workers credit card!!! Luckily her bank called her and canceled the card;she was not responsible for the charges! The FOOD was terrible as well, all dried out and some more co-workers threw-up on their way home after eating at this establishment!!! BEWARE!!Terrible service.. What hotel doesnt change your sheets/towels?First off, it is located wrong on the map here. Its northeast of downtown along the riverwalk. There is something about this hotel that is a little creepy. Former mental hospital? I don't know. This place is a ghost town of a hotel. I never saw one other customer here in two days. Not in the lobby, restaurant, bar or hallway. Very strange. And there were only three staff people from what I saw. Front Desk, and two in the kitchen. Decent bar but no one there. Rooms were nice though, make no mistake. Very clean and good view of the river. But just too far from downtown and not enough going on in the building to be self contained. If you are writing a novel (think Jack Nicholson) and need some solitude, then this is your place. Otherwise, get in the cab and trek back downtown...Staying in room 123. A/c works great and a view of the river. Lots of high end finishes. Some minor details need addressing, but very nice overall. Easy access out the back door to the river walk. I would come back.
review_content_60: Please DO NOT stay at this hotel. Stayed there over the Labor Day weekend 2012 and the service was EXTREMELY slow. Couldn't check into my room until 6:00 PM. The staff working that day were nice, but that doesn't make up for slow service. Also, one week later, my boyfriend and I learned we contracted bed bugs. We called the hotel to notify them that it had to have come from their hotel as we didn't stay anywhere else and there weren't bed bugs at home. We each at bites on our arms and backs. The hotel was SUPPOSE to follow up with us and now...one month later...we still haven't heard back. We have left messages with three different managers and still nothing. Finally, our stay was purchased in advanced on HOTWIRE. The hotel still charged my card and blamed HOTWIRE for not forwarding the credit for the room. I'm still waiting for the hotel to credit my card back...yes, one month later!I wish I would have paid the additional cost and stayed somewhere else. LESSON LEARNED. STAY AT YOUR OWN RISK AND EXPENSE!DON'T STAY AT THIS HOTEL. The only reason I'm giving it one star is because of the location. If I could give it a negative rating I would. They didn't change our linen or empty our trash. They gave us a broken unopertive hair dryer after not having one in our room. The latch on the door was broke. There was no wifi as advertised. You might as well walk your bags to the room, because you can't use the cart due to the stairs to get through the door. You'll have a better stay at a roadside motel than staying here.Bistro staff was friendly, but breakfast staff overwhelmed by 3 tables. Front desk checkout staff need training in customer service and how to listen to guests before interrupting -- easy fix but management needs to expect quality and set standards. Room was clean but needed better maintenance. Phone did not work. Security latch was torn off. Holes in desk chair fabric and in carpet. Dust on curtain toppers. Cable reception was fuzzy. Heating/Cooling thermostat battery was broken so could not regulate room temperature effectively. If you get Room 113 take a look before accepting. As the one night stay wore on we wished we were in a different room. Not sure we will return.So here's the thing - we got this as a deal on priceline. One of my best friends was in town from NYC and I'm in A2 now and have gotten tired of sleeping on people's couches and of driving home to Ann Arbor at 3 am. And when my girl comes in from New York, we're going out in Detroit. Okay, maybe Hamtramck, but still. So, went on priceline, put in a fairly low price (and just b/c they were so nice at this hotel I won't say exactly how low, but suffice to say equal to or greater than $100). And oh it was SO worth it. First of all - the service. They are fabulously friendly from the moment you valet - and you do have to valet, and it is $18. And you sit down at a little desk while they check you in, no mass torture of waiting in line. And the room itself is fine. It's not glorious. But I've stayed in worse Hilton's that I (or actually my company) has payed close to $300 for. Decent bath products, I forgot which kind. Coffee maker and mini-bar, though you do have to ask for the key (which I did - at 3 am - FYI I think Doritos and peanuts come out to approx $5, which isn't horrible by mini-bar standards).Also, they have this fabulous shuttle service that's FREE! And will take you anywhere within approx 5 mile (basically anywhere in downtown Detroit) and pick you up when you call them until 11 pm. So, while I waited for my friend to be finish up a wedding she was attending, I took the shuttle to Slow's for some BBQ and discussed Detroit with the shuttle drivers.Everyone at the hotel was super-nice. I would never have known about this hotel if it hadn't been for priceline (and this was my first time). It was like a little vacation in Detroit. Perfect.This is a positive review, although it may not seem so at first.I stayed here with a conference of educators from around the U.S.. I'd read reviews that indicated a range of experiences, from fab to not ready for prime time, so I was ready for some glitches and for the staff to be on the inexperienced side.Our room was very nice, with great beds and comfy pillows. The climate control worked well, and the bath was fine, except for a bit of peeling wallpaper and a missing soap dish in the shower that left a rusty bracket exposed. The room was very clean, except for the phone, which was so dusty it appeared to have been in storage. There were no tissues, no wastebasket in the bath, and the television remote needed batteries. The room next door had a broken electronic lock, so the people assigned there couldn't get in. We'd arrived very late due to a a plane delay, so there was scant staff to help address maintenance issues. The hotel was sold out and the lock repair person wasn't on site, so our colleagues had to wait a long time to get into a room, and then had to share a bed. This was only possible because one person had not made the trip and his room was empty.Since I could see that there were a number of similar issues going on that evening, I made my way to the front desk and asked to pick up the missing wastebasket, tissues and remote batteries, in order to make it easier on the man at the front desk, who suddenly had 275 guests. He was already on his way, although there were no tissues to be had.Early the next morning, the hotel fire alarm began to sound, and kept on for about 45 minutes. That got us all up, even though we would have liked to sleep a bit longer. The staff were a bit late getting the breakfast buffet set up, and only had vacuum pitchers from which to serve coffee, which meant refilling frequently as people lined up waiting. As a result, our conference schedule was set back by 30 minutes or so.Now, this is a lot of teething trouble for a hotel. Had we been a different bunch of people, there might have been quite an uproar and a lot of complaining, demanding guests. However, the conference organizers and hotel staff promptly put their heads together and made adjustments. A hot room with too few chairs was cooled down and used for small breakout groups instead of whole-group meetings. Our conference organizers asked us to help bus our tables so that they could be cleared and reset quickly, to enable us to meet in the large dining space. Everyone on the staff was pleasant, accommodating and helpful, and our three day meeting was a success. We plan to return next year.Overall, it was a wonderful example of how people can come together to ensure that things go smoothly. I don't doubt that the hotel staff had a huge learning experience. Some things need attention. Not everyone got a hot shower in the morning. The shuttle was down. Some phones did not work. If the Riverwalk is full more often, they will likely staff up to meet the demands of a larger guest load. If they are fully booked more, they will have housekeeping examining the rooms more often, and can keep maintenance staff on site.This is a family owned, black owned hotel, and Detroit needs well-run, successful enterprises owned and run by people of color. We all need more independent hotel operators, unless we all want to be at the mercy of huge corporate chains. We were so impressed by how hard the Riverwalk staff worked, and how cheerful and warm they were - they deserve to do well.Some friends and I stayed here for my birthday. It was a great hotel experience. The concierge/front desk are extremely friendly and accomidating. We got a sweet deal for this hotel on priceline.com and even recieved a free room upgrade from the front desk for simply inquiring about the nicer rooms. The room we got had a river front view which was amazing. The rooms are very nice, and clean for a hotel. The beds are super comfy too. Also they gave us extended checkout at no extra charge. I would absolutely stay here again!What a gem in Detroit... I have stayed in the rooms once and they were middle of the road, but the surrounding area (riverfront) is special. I would strongly encourage taking your Boo here and letting yourself go! The Ron Mimms Day Party only made it an even better destination.This is one of those hotels in Detroit that flies under the radar. This hotel is exquisite. It is beautifully designed, reminding me of the sophistication of a European classic. I surprised my husband with a weekend stay here for his birthday. I absolutely fell in love with the view of the river from the rear of the hotel. Our room was nicely decorated and a nice size. I went all out and got the Governor's Suite. Room service was prompt and front desk check in was easy. The front desk coordinator worked with me because she knew I was planning something special. I definitely recommend this place as a cozy get away for any occasion or just because. You really feel special when you stay here. Feels as if you're miles away from the everyday.Whenever I get a "boutique" hotel with a Priceline bid, I'm pretty sure it will be a property with great promise that is past its prime. No surprises here, except the terrific service made up for the musty, outdated furnishings and shady location. The hotel was booked solid for a Detroit Lions game. Mostly drunk, obnoxious football fans (many Canadians) and maybe one wedding party filled the hotel. Check in was a breeze and we were pleasantly surprised by two gigantic rooms (one river view and one parking lot view) for $80 each. The best deal was a free shuttle service to the game, with a promise for a ride back if we called before midnight and met the driver a few blocks from Ford Field. Front desk agent and former cab driver Walter subbed as our entertaining shuttle driver for the evening. He adeptly got us through the city and handled the drunks in our van beautifully. Although the kitchen was closed when we returned from the game, Walter encouraged us to visit the bar and we weren't disappointed. A pool table, piano, a few TVs, plenty of seats and piped in dance music provided a great place to relax with a few drinks. Tasty Michigan craft beers ($4) and strong well drinks ($6) were our choices. Our attentive server (the only one on duty) took care of us well even when the bar filled with late-night patrons. Back in the room, newer bedding (maybe a response to a bedbug complaint?) welcomed us for a good rest in spite of being able to hear noises from throughout the hotel. The lowlight in the morning was a mildewed shower curtain with hair stuck on it from previous guests, a slow-draining shower tub and sparse towels. Our rooms were impressively spacious, but the curtains and carpets need a thorough steaming. All furniture but the beds were pretty run down and should also be spruced up. However, you get what you pay for and because of the great service and convenience to get to and from the game, I feel like this was still a good deal.I recently stayed at the Riverwalk Hotel April 19-22, 2012. I stayed in a suite on the second floor. I was walking barefoot around in my room the evening of check-in and noticed that there were numerous little items all over the carpet - it seemed like it hadn't been swept in days. The next morning in making in-room coffee, one of the coffee cups hadn't been cleaned at the bottom of the cup was someone's old coffee - UGH! In leaving for the day, I notified the front desk of the cup situation and requested that the carpet be swept (that didn't happen until my next day. Also both days upon returning from being out all day I had no maid service, the room was as I'd left it. I had to call down to the front desk both evenings for maid service, both times I'd been given the situation that the hotel was completely booked and they were still cleaning rooms (this was at about 4:00 p.m. each afternoon). On check out I mentioned to the front desk receptionist that I could only assume that when coming up on such situations, they would hire more staff on an on-call basis, they're plenty folks out on the streets who'd love to work.Very distressing for the cost of the rooms, it's not like this is a Motel 6!We knew we were going to have to get a hotel room block for our out of town guests. Most are not familar with downtown Detroit and to be honest are scared of it, so we did a lot of research to make sure we picked a spot that was safe and close to our venues. We contacted the Omni and once we took the tour of the building, we knew it would be perfect for our guests. It is in a quiet, quaint part of Detroit, halfway between our reception and ceremony AND the selling point, they have a shuttle to and from downtown and since we had so many rooms booked, scheduled pick-ups and drop-offs to our reception. The only complaints we had were that our guests kept running into problems booking under our block once a certain room type was no longer available. The staff at the 1 800 number we were told to use were telling them there was no block, so our guests would call us asking what was up. Once that issue was resolved, it was smooth sailing for reservations. My other beef was the welcome bags. They didn't give them to everyone upon check in. I had to keep asking if they were giving them out. I know there was another block and wedding that night in the hotel, but they didn't have bags. I wish they would have been able to put them in people's rooms, but oh well. Nearly everyone got one, one way or another. I know people were not crazy about having to valet park their cars and pay for parking everynight, but it is a "city" hotel and it is the norm for most hotels in Detroit.Other than that, it was fantastic. The rooms were spacious and clean and the staff was so nice and accomodating to our guests. I stayed in a suite the night before the weddding so the girls could all get ready in the room and it was so huge and perfect for us. Also, Steve and I stayed there the night of the wedding and they gave us a late check out of 2PM. An added bonus was that we stayed our wedding night for free because we had so many rooms booked! Woo hoo!I put friends and family up here when they come to visit. The proximity to the downtown area (and prox. to me), riverwalk, gorgeous rooms, views and patio make this a great choice even if it is a bit under the radar (as another reviewer mentioned.) The website makes booking and viewing details easy. And even if your internet connection at home fails and you end up buying the room twice (as I did) the helpful staff will assist your needs, even at 430am. I have been impressed as have all my guests.This place was odd, not in bad way. The bathroom was huge (along with a phone from the late 90s). The bathroom took up almost 1/4 of the room. The windows were quite small which kept the room pretty dark. The cable went out a few times while I was there. Parking was valet, which is sort of funny considering the parked the car only a few feet from where we pulled in ($18 total so I think it might have come out to 50 cents were feet, not a bad racket). Those were some of the negatives, the positives were the hotel offered a free shuttle downtown (I was there with a group for the Pizza Pizza Bowl). They also offered free pickup until 10:30 which saved us from a cab ride (and the fare). The hotel is right on the river which was one of the few beautiful areas I saw in Detroit. The staff was pretty friendly. The best was the hotel bar which had few customers but was really inviting. The bartender was extremely friendly and give a great pour on my whiskey and cokes. Also ordered some food from the bar and after a day of drinking and football it all really hit the spot, french onion soup and the spinach artichoke dip was great. Not a ton of bars or restaurant's in the neighborhood, but its also slightly outside of downtown. There were a few bars within walking distance that weren't bad (though make sure you walk there in a group) Overall we got this place off priceline for $50 which I would say is just about right. I'd stay here again (as long as I'm getting a priceline discount).

review_content: I've stayed here multiple times and it continues to be toward the top of my list of places to stay downtown. It seems like the prices of the rooms vary quite a bit depending on what's going on downtown. That being said, the Hilton Garden Inn is generally more reasonable that the casinos or other downtown hotels. I really like the location - walking distance to Greektown, Ford Field/Comerica, The Fillmore, etc. There is a ton to do within a short walk. Corktown and Midtown are short cab/Uber rides away. Really, I just feel like this place is the most bang for your buck when it comes to downtown hotels. As I said before, the rates can vary quite a bit at the downtown hotels depending on which hotel is offering a good deal, but this place is generally where I end up.I didnt actually get a room here, so I cant speak to the conditions or services related to an overnite stay. But I want to thank the staff for allowing me to use the restroom and warm up in the lobby between trying to reprogram a replacement car key (my car was parked in a lot nearby). I was already cold and frustrated, I guess it was written on my face because the desk clerk was really polite, even allowing me to purchase a few snacks. Im sorry I dont remember her name so she can be recognized! I may go back and see if I can catch her, and let her superiors know how nice she was to me, and I wasnt even a customer! It probably didnt seem like much to her but she was truely an angel in disguise :-)I made reservations for me & my sweetheart on Valentine's Day, thinking it'd be a nice place to spend a romantic evening ($182). I was wrong!! I ordered a bottle of champagne (an additional $90) to be delivered & waiting for us upon arrival, but that didn't happen! There wasn't champagne, & the compensation that the manager offered didn't come through either (she offered some dinner coupons). The staff is rude & the place reeked of marijuana. No wonder people don't like coming to Detroit...Hilton continues to be my go-to hotel property, and Detroit is no exception. I found nearly all of the staff to be genuinely friendly, helpful and accomodating.  The property is beautiful and very well kept.  Anything I needed, they were available.  The fitness room, while tiny, is well equipped with med balls, elipticals, treadmills, and a tv that works.  The way they have breakfasts set up is perfect..tons to choose from if you have a minute or an hour.Upon arrival had to wait about 10-15 minutes to get in the parking lot. Valet seemed very overwhelmed as there were alot of people checking in and leaving cars to be parked. Room was ok, nothing special. Upon checkout when we got our car back, had items missing. Filed a complaint with the hotel and valet company, police report also. Turns out I'm the liar valet did nothing wrong and hotel is not responsible. Be very careful what you leave in your vehicle as the ticket stub basically states the valet can take whatever they find and it's your responsibility not theirs!! Hotel management did nothing.There seems to be construction going on judging by the scaffolding setup near the entrance.  The pathway to the entrance was riddled with puddles.  The room I stayed at this hotel is pretty run down.  The bathtub didn't drain well so I had to stand in dirty water.  Ew.  There were a few tiles with cracks on the floor also a crack in the sink hardware.  The wall papers are outdated and the heater was loud.  The lady at the front desk was nice.  If you have gold or diamond status, you can ask for bottled water when you check in.  There's a complimentary business center past the front desk where you can use the printer if needed.   Getting into the room is the half the fun since the card reader doesn't do a very good job at reading the room card.  It's best to put something on a usb drive and stick it into the monitor to have it printed.  I wasn't able to get to any non-hotel websites using the computers in the room.  The convenience store section across from the front desk was well stocked, but some of the items were expired by a month or so.  I guess the tuna snack packs aren't very popular with the guests that stay here.This location is about 10 minutes from Amtrak and is under $10 for a taxi ride there.SummaryThe Good+Convenient store section+Free bottled water for gold/diamond status+24 hour fitness center+Hot Tub+Free Wifi+Free business center+Restaurant inside+Complimentary in-room K-cup coffee and tea+Movie channels+Good location downtownThe Bad-Rooms are old-Puddles obstacles by the entrance-Expired items in the convenient store sectionClean and relatively new hotel.Spent four nights here recently. The room was big enough and had a microwave and refrigerator in it. Also free wifi, which worked fine.The fitness center only had three machines and some dumbbells. The indoor pool looked on the small side and we didn't use it.The business center has two computers and a printer.The lose one star because on two days, when we came back to the room in the early afternoon (say 1:30pm ish), housekeeping had still not arrived to tidy up.I was prepared for a *meh* feeling, but overall this place was ideal. Clean and updated, free wifi, incomparably friendly staff all combined with this awesome location for exploring downtown Detroit make this the best stay imaginable! The Chrome Bar and Grille staff was hardworking and a bit understaffed, struggling with an awkward shared kitchen and no food / snacks behind the bar. Area for improvement. Lobby was neat and updated, and cozy!The Hilton Garden Inn Downtown Detroit is walking distance to both Comerica Park and Ford Field and I found the staff to be very friendly and accommodating. I highly recommend eating breakfast at the hotel restaurant. The kitchen staff cooks with love and this was one of the best omelets I have had in years.This is one of those case where the hotel chain sets a silly high price and then they don't support the facility to actually deliver any sort of support. The air conditioner just keeps shutting itself off  The shower is clearly sparing water into the wall and maintenance can't really do anything until after we are gone. This is not true. Go grab me some Teflon tape and I'll fix ya right up in a jiffy. The restaurant attached is sub par. Poorly staffed and confused at minimum.I try very hard to stay within the Hilton chain as a Diamond level member the perks are worth the effort and this was the best I could find from Hilton close to where I needed to be for my first time in Detroit.
