The lower tier is the Bed and it's own TV and both tier is open so it just feels like a one big room.  The room service is excellent and they give you free news paper in the morning.The prices are decent and the customer service is always fabulous.The location is the key for this Hotel.  It's connected to a great restaurant Fishbone's and you can walk to the Greektown Casino without going outside. (except to cross the street between two buidlings).  It's a block away from Greektown itself and few blocks away from Comerica Park and Ford Field to watch the Tigers or the Lions.  About 4 blocks away from Renaissance Center and Hart Plaza.If you're coming into town and need a place to stay, I would recommend Atheneum.  It's even good for a night for locals to enjoy Detroit without having to drive home late night.Love this hotel, $120 - shared a room with my friend, we had a blast, very spacious, comfy beds and large bathroom.  The previous occupant had filled most of the mini bar bottles with water, the manager came up and comped us some free vodka and wine - this was above and beyond - and went great with our oysters and shrimp while we worked.  Frankly we felt like rock stars the whole time we were there.  Great location in Greek Town near food and casino.Beautiful and comfortable rooms, but the walls are thin.  The people in the rooms next to us woke us up both nights of our stay.  We even heard the traffic and the people mover despite being on the 5th floor.  The location of the hotel was also very good.This was a great hotel! My cousin had her wedding here, so I stayed here for 2 nights, and it was wonderful! The suites are quite large, and very clean. Service was great and beds were very comfortable! The hall where the wedding was held was great! Big space and the service there was phenomenal! It's a beautiful hotel and rich in history! I loved my stay here, and I can't wait to come back whenever I need somewhere to stay in Detroit.Large rooms and comfortable bed are the major pros for this place. The other being its location in greektown and all the attractions that offers. A few things really annoyed me about this hotel. The Wifi is terrible! I wouldn't even call it highspeed. If you are planning on doing any web browsing beyond checking email prepare for a frustratingly slow experience. Actually impossible to watch any video such as a movie trailer.  Someone mentioned the A/C being terrible. I stayed in winter and noticed the heat was not great either. Had to turn it up to 80 to get some level of comfort. My wife and I both noticed the smell of smoke even though it is supposed to be a non-smoking room. They have a fascist mini-bar policy that apparently weighs anything you put in and take out so you can't actually use the fridge to keep your left over food cold. If you can get past all that you will have a comfortable place to stay with friendly staff in a nice neighborhood which is why I am giving it three stars.I have had better service at MOTEL 6....lol They were out of ICE all night (we got there at 5:00pm), housekeeping was closed also?? so no extra nothing!! The staff was unconcerned and a bit nasty acting. I will be staying at MOTOR CITY next time!! THIS PLACE SUCKS (we had the Penthouse $800) never again!!
review_content_60: All of the times I've stayed at the Atheneum, I've hoped for more. I think I'll have to look elsewhere after this time, because apparently some things don't change.This last stay, I booked a premium suite, thinking it would be nice to take a soak in a whirlpool tub after dinner. The total charge (before room service) was $228.85.... A price I didn't mind paying until I saw what I actually got. First of all, how is valet parking not included for this price?!?! $20 dollars a day? For a sometimes very slow experience?!? No thanks, I'll walk the two blocks for free parking, I think.The marble counter tops and border around the whirlpool tub we all discolored and water stained. Has this place not heard of a good sealant? The carpet was a bit bubbly and warped on the opposite side of the hot tub, making me think that perhaps someone got a bit overzealous with  the water levels, or that there had been a leak at some point. The wall paper was discolored and small peel-y spots could be seen throughout the room. The flat screen tv's look nice, but the reception on almost every channel was fuzzy and grainy. I tried adjusting the cords, thinking maybe something had come loose, but it was to no avail. The complimentary wi-fi was nice (and with what your paying, it SHOULD be complimentary) but slow, slow, slow. I opened the bedside table to find a pen and paper and found (what was clearly given away by the smell and residue) a "Guest Survey" form folded up with remnants of weed all over it. Once I opened that drawer and let the smell out, the whole room reeked for an hour.( I'm not against those that do indulge, btw. It's just not for me. And for housekeeping not to clean the room thoroughly at such a "reputable" hotel, that's just disappointing. )The bed was actually the worst part. It has to be the least comfortable bed I've slept in ever. I woke up feeling like the day after you've been in a car accident; stiff and sore. The walls also seem incredibly thin. All night long, I kept hearing laughing and talking from the room next to mine, along with any and all conversation from people going down the hall.The neighborhood isn't bad at all (It cracks me up when people say it is!) though, admittedly, there were some questionable-looking people hanging around out front. Room service was remarkably quick, though it's a bit pricey for what you're actually getting. Funnily enough, I ended up staying at the Embassy Suites off of 275 not terribly long after my last visit to the Atheneum, and got a cleaner, nicer room for almost half the price with a FULL COMPLIMENTARY BREAKFAST including an omelete station, fresh fruit bar, coffee, soft drinks, cereal, donuts, etc.I recently stayed at the Atheneum for one night. That was all the time necessary for me to know that I was in... a convention hotel.The hotel was recently remodeled (in the last 5 years I think) and the rooms are very nice. My room had a living room with flat-panel TV right when you walk in, and then a large bathroom with soaking tub. Down some steps (within the room) was the bedroom with two queen beds and another flat-panel TV. The view out the floor-to-ceiling windows was nice, but remember that you're in Detroit. Its not some architectural marvel.The real issue I faced with giving this hotel a better rating was the cleanliness. While in the hotel, every ledge and surface seemed to have a thick layer of dust on it. As I took the glass elevator up, I could see the edge of each floor as I went up, and every one of the ledges had a thick layer of dust. If they were paying any attention to detail at all, they should have caught this. Additionally, the windows in the room had fingerprints all over them which tells me the housekeeping hadn't cleaned the windows between guests.I don't think many people stay at the Atheneum for the hotel itself. I got the distinct impression that people stayed there for class reunions and small conferences. One more thing, the "continental breakfast" included all of the following: Orange Juice, Apple Juice, Coffee, Tea, one type of muffin, and a tiny plate of pineapple chunks. A joke, to be honest.The reviewers who gave this hotel 3 stars or fewer have an accurate assessment of the hotel environment.  Let me outline the positives and negatives about the hotel.Negatives:1. The noise.  THE NOISE.  This is not a hotel where someone can experience a romantic getaway or experience calm surroundings.  Our room was positioned on Lafayette Street which is an incredibly noisy area of the hotel.  There is a adult entertainment bar on Lafayette Street on the second floor that plays very loud music into the wee hours of the night.  It is constant and throbbing.  There is no escape.In addition to the outside noise, I could not escape the noise from fellow guests.  It seemed to me that most of the people I encountered in the halls were interested in this hotel because they wanted suites in which to party.  On either side of us we had very large groups of people in rooms and the people were screaming and squealing throughout the night.  I was awakened in the middle of the night by one room of young women who were really loud.In my opinion, the noise issue is so bad that the hotel is unsuitable.2. While the decor and furniture has been updated, there is obvious wear and tear on the building itself.  There are streak marks on the walls, the grout, tile, wall paint and hot tub fixtures look worn.  In the size suite we stayed in, the hot tub was in the central living area, and not enclosed in the bathroom, which seems like an odd structural choice and definitely lacks privacy if those staying do not all want to go in the hot tub together.3. The staff were all polite, but except for one person, were not friendly at all.  I have stayed in all kinds of hotels from Motel 6s to Westins in Chicago, and at almost all of these places, the staff, upon checking out, ask me if I enjoyed my stay.  Not here.  The room service person was rumpled and unkempt.  It is true (like others have noted) that the ice machines are not fully stocked.  I had to go to multiple floors to attempt to get ice.4. Although there is room service (from the restaurant in the same building), there isn't a gift shop, and the convenience store near the restaurant is opened limited hours.5. The wifi is poor.  My phone and computer kept dropping the connection and I had to login frequently.  In addition, the wifi connection was slow.  I turned off wifi on my phone and used my 3G data plan because it was quicker for me to do so for anything more data intensive than web surfing.  So the wifi along with the gift shop aren't deal breakers, but they just add to the negative experiences.Positives:1. I did like the updated furniture and bed linens2. The valet service was prompt so we could get the heck out of thereGiven the amount of money this hotel costs, I think there likely are other, more competitive options in Downtown Detroit that would end up being quieter and having better, more friendly staff.  If I go to downtown Detroit again, I will not stay here.What a lovely hotel. We were in Detroit for a US Fencing tournament and we decided to stay at the Atheneum because it was by the people mover (an elevated train that goes to spots downtown, including the convention center).  We loved the large suite and the great tub and nice large bathroom. The hotel was very clean and the staff was extremely nice. Brenda was especially nice when we checked in and even remembered us the next day! She took time to ask my son how he did at the tournament!  The restaurant is good in the hotel but Greektown was great. My only complaint about Detroit is that cabs are difficult to find outside of the main downtown.I just returned home from a stay in very chilly Detroit. The high point of this trip was this hotel. My company had booked to hold an evening reception here thus we stayed here for two nights. Our rooms were $249 per night and were gigantic suites with large sitting area, marble bath with soaking tub, 2 flat screen TVs and comfy beds.The staff here is the most unbelievably friendly and amazing I have ever experienced as ANY price point. I have travelled all over the world and logged hundreds of nights in hotel rooms. Never have I had such unbelievably excellent service from EVERYONE - the valet, registration, security, concierge, housekeeping and the catering staff. No request was too much and all were fulfilled in less than a fraction of the time I would have expected.The location is also great - right on the people mover - easy access to Cobo Hall, Joe Louis Arena and the stadiums. It also s across the street from one of the casinos and smack dab in the middle of Greektown - a wonderful neighborhood of great restaurants and bars.Take my advice - don't stay anywhere else!This is Detroit's only 4-star hotel.  Considering this hotel is located in the middle of a sad, dumpy area, that's not saying much about Detroit.I had to stay here overnight for a business trip and I cannot imagine why they suggested this place for 2 young women to stay at (our meetings were an hour north of the city).   The location is seedy.  I'm no suburban princess or anything, heck I don't bat in eye in SE D.C. or even in downtown Baltimore, but this place was no joke.  I didn't leave the hotel alone at night.The upsides:  The room was really nice.  I got a junior King suite, which had a nice huge TV and a really nice bathroom with soaking tub.  The continental breakfast was actually decent, aside from the coffee and juice, there was fresh pineapple and strawberries, muffins, and a good assortment of pastries.   The pastries weren't fresh or anything, but they were good enough.Stayed here with my family while in town for a Wings game and trip to the Ford Museum.  The staff was very friendly and helpful.  Anything we needed, they were all over it.  We had a deluxe suite and it was very spacious for us.  Beds were nice but we were under the impression the living room had a sofa sleeper, and it was just sofa (pretty stiff and not too comfy).  You can request a mini fridge when you check in.  Walls are a bit thin, can get loud at night and outside.  Good size bathroom with big shower.  No overnight parking in the area that we could find, so had to pay $20 to valet.  The shuttle was a great amenity, but we did have a rough time finding the shuttle after the game.  There really wasn't a designated spot and it was a blizzard outside, after calling about 7 times we managed to find it (no help from the direction of the driver) - just got lucky. Fishbones restaurant is downstairs so that's nice/convenient.  Overall, good stay and reasonably priced.We got a great price for this hotel on Priceline. However, I don't think I'd recommend staying here, especially if you are paying full price. Both nights we stayed were super noisy. I am all for having events at a hotel but someone needs to make sure that the party in the lobby can't be heard on the 3rd floor.  Checking in took forever. The valet costs $20 a day and it sometimes took a really long time to retrieve our car. I liked the location and that it's connected to Fishbones but I think there are probably better options downtown.Clean joint. Spacious sweets. Comfortable beds. I say yes.We stayed here for DEMF weekend.   We'd originally booked a double suite, but upon arrival, the manager was summoned by the front desk clerk and we were then told that there were some kids in that room the night prior that "were partying too hard and trashed the room."  She offered us a room w/ a king bed and pull out couch.  We conjured that she was afraid we would be those kids and trash the room, so she offered us a downgrade.  I guess I don't blame her given it was the weekend of DEMF, however, we didn't have glow sticks in hand, raver pants on, or pacifiers in our mouths.  on to the room!  It was a smoking room...w/ no windows that could be opened or vents either!  Not even an exhaust fan in the bathroom.  How could something like this happen, you ask??  B/c we were in detroit, that's how!!!  The sound transfer between rooms was very good...this being a BAD thing.  We could hear the couple next to us fighting and we even heard a glass being thrown.  Apparently, from what we've heard, the Atheneum is one of the nicer hotels in Detroit.   yikes!!!!Those that come to Atheneum must understand upfront that it is always busy with something. This is one of the hotels in Detroit that hosts a lot of patrons for various annual events, as well as high school homecomings and proms. Therefore, I suggest checking with the reservation staff before booking your room, if you wanted to perhaps have a quiet weekend. The Atheneum is actually a nice hotel and appears to be getting better with upcoming renovations. It is right in the heart of the city (located across from the Casino), so you are definitely in walking distance to fun activities.Hotel overbooked, so we were moved to a smaller suite. It still was nice and they compensated me nicely. Only complaints are not enough towels in the bathroom and the bathroom wasn't as clean as it should've been. Pay in advance and room will be under $150.This was surprisingly a decent hotel?  They let us check in a couple hours early (as we were camping out in the business center).  The rooms were pretty big suites, clean, and comfortable.  I think the bathroom was bigger than my first NYC apartment.  I have no complaints.  It's in a bit of a random location but I didn't feel unsafe or far from where I needed to be (a few blocks away).  For $129/night I thought it was very good value.I cannot say enough about my time at Atheneum. It honestly was my best experience at hotel, ever. I stayed here the weekend of June 19th for my wedding. They were unbelievably accommodating. I had already enjoyed my first night in a deluxe suite by taking a bath in their  amazing bathtub and relaxing with friends in the spacious living room area. The next day I needed to be moved into the Premium suite I'd booked for my honeymoon night with my husband, early, so I didn't have to worry about how long I took getting ready for my wedding. Not only did they allow me to check in early but they upgraded me to a Senators suite that impressed everyone that was helping me get ready for my wedding that day! The room, or should I say apartment, was amazing! Curtis, the concierge there told me and a bridesmaid were we could get a great deal on beautiful flowers for my bouquet as well as the bouquets for my bridesmaids. Andre, another concierge was always there to help as well.  Valet, the front desk, and management were beyond reproach! I felt well taking care of and valued as a customer! By the time I left I felt like I knew everyone and they knew my husband and I. I highly recommend the Atheneum for your special occasion!It appeared to be an older hotel with modern decor. The walls were a bit thin. I had a hard time sleeping because there is a night club next to it and I could hear the loud music till about 3am or so. This is the one thing that made me never want to go back. It wasn't worth the money, but the rooms were decorated nicely and were quite large.for the money not a bad deal.  wifi, coffee maker, flat screen tv's.  clean, clean, clean!!!  i will definitely be returning to this place in the future.I had a wonderful experience at the Atheneum Suite Hotel. I stayed there just to get away one weekend. My room had a jacuzzi per my request. I didn't have a major event or any thing like that happening so I wasn't rushing around or in a panic. Room service when ordered was timely, check in was swift and my time spent in the bar and restaurant were enjoyable. My room was also clean and the concierge was hospitable. Overall, I had the weekend I needed.

review_content: This is my go to for a hotel in downtown Detroit! You can never go wrong with a Westin but the Book Cadillac is everything you want out of a downtown hotel. The rooms are quiet and clean. The service is attentive and helpful. The lounge area and roast are my favorite.Got a room for New Year's Eve to hang downtown and have a blast, decided on the Book Cadillac, and we all stayed there...I want to say there were six rooms, if I recall correctly.Lobby's great, valet service while dropping my car off was fast and attentive, check in was smooth and easy, and the bar on the 2nd floor was the perfect place for the guys to hang and have a few drinks while we were waiting for the ladies to finish getting ready for the night.Bed was super comfy......okay, look, here's the negative.  Upon throwing open the drapes the next morning (hey, 11am is still morning...lol...), discovering that housekeeping had somehow managed to miss the half-eaten bag of pita bread and open thing of hummus sitting on the window ledge kinda skeeved me out a bit and made me question their housekeeping practices...which made me worry about what was lurking in that super comfy bed and....:shudder:I'd probably go back....but I'll definitely check the window ledges as soon as I get in the room :)This Westin is fantastic.  Staying here for the marathon it was super close to the start and the amenities are fantastic.  I forgot my running shorts and thank god they have a gear rental program because it saved my race!  I suppose I could have run in my boxers but I would probably end up accidentally flashing the border guards and end up in federal prison.  Being a Starwood member I was placed on the top floor which was great because at 23 floors you're above the street noise down below.  The gym is nicely appointed and their pool looked tempting but I forgot my swimming trunks.  Really enjoyed the executive lounge and the rooms themselves were great.  Super spacious. comfortable linens (although probably overboard with the amount of sheets/blankets.  The shower was nice with the rain shower head.I'll stay at this Westin again if I'm ever in Detroit again that's for sure.Beautiful hotel that located in a 1924 ItalianRenaissance style high rise. Located in a great area in Downtown Detroit.  This place comes with great views, indoor pool, whirlpools tubs, and fine dining. We stayed here during the Movement festival Memorial day weekend.  Best experience ever. I will come back anytime I am in Detroit.I have stayed here a couple times and always had good service. This time however, the room my girl and I were given was dirty and had cheerios on the chair. It was also extremely small with a wonderful view of a building wall. The person who checked us in even asked us if we would like a view and of course we said yes...who wouldn't? Not a great start to our Valentine's weekend together.Nicest Westin I've ever stayed at!  And I'm pretty loyal to Starwood, so that says a lot.The hotel is gorgeous, large spacious lobbies, hallways, elevators, and rooms.  The building itself was the prettiest on the block.From the moment we pulled up, service was superb:  3 bellmen descended to help with bags, check-in was easy, arranging for "green choice" and late checkout was easy, getting to / from the room (bellman showed up quickly), in/out privileges with self-park was seamlessly validated, and everyone was smiling!Location was perfect for a downtown stay.  You can easily walk to all the tourist attractions without an trouble or need for public transportation.  Great coffee option two blocks away:  urban bean company!I've heard great things about the steakhouse at the restaurant but did not have a chance to try it - saving it for next time!I had wanted to stay at the Book Cadillac for years!  I finally got the chance to make a reservation when we booked a room for the night of the Zac Brown Band concert.  The hotel is in a great area with a lot of restaurants/people movers near by and valet parking as well as a parking structure available.Despite the hotel being busy with the ZBB concert, the Motorhead concert, and a wedding reception in the hotel, the front desk staff quickly greeted us and checked us in.The hotel is pretty big and has a couple of restaurants (Roast and 24 Grille), a coffee shop, spa and gift shop.  If you are lucky enough to stay in the top floors of the hotel and get to use the VIP suite, you can partake in wonderful appetizers in the evening.  At the time of this review they offered caprese salad, field greens, custard with blackberries, cheeses and meats, grilled veggies, and olives.  Breakfast on Sunday consisted of bacon, egg dishes fruit, breads, yogurt, fresh ground coffee, etc. Not to mention a wonderful view!The beds were really comfy.  The bathrooms were spacious with wonderful soaps, shampoos, etc.  The water pressure was great.  If you like to work out, they offer the option of renting work out clothing....It's in close proximity to Ford Field, Comerica Park, The Joe, The Fox Theatre, The Fillmore, The Detroit Opera House, The People Movers, and more.... I highly reccomend!This place met all expectations-- clean, prompt service, the joint is really, really nice.Having said that, five stars are reserved for perhaps exceeding expectations, and there're only two small facets that stood out to prevent a superlative rating:1. The crew runnin' cars and bags out front were on point and aware of the needs of folks around them, but when folks ain't in need, they were talkin' about some beef simmerin' in the ranks with so-and-so who did something messed up and everyone should say something about it.  It's just always weird to have the curtain drawn back, you know, even though we know every spot has that mild drama.2. No hooks or towel racks on the bathroom walls. One on the door.  None on the walls. Tha's just weird, yo.I'd stay here again, though, no questions asked.Having planned ahead, my boyfriend booked a room through Expedia for Valentine's Day weekend in an effort to do something special this Halmark holiday. He was very happy about the deal he received. Upon arrival and check in, we were asked if we wanted a room with a view...um yeah, then asked if we wanted to upgrade to a suite for $50 more dollars, no thank you. So we were sent to room 1406. We've stayed in this hotel before, so when we walked in and saw the size, we knew we were getting jipped. This room was about a third smaller than any other standard room we've ever stayed in here, and the view he specifically asked us about consisted of the theee stone walls of the connected condos where we could see right in, "Hi Gro6ege, Hi Weezy!" Within moments we both saw the smooshed cheerios in the chair and on the floor near the bed. Right there in plain sight! It was obvious this room was not cleaned properly. We called the front desk and they moved us to a clean, larger sized room on a differnt floor. Not a great start to our romantic night...Negative reviews about Detroit usually come from people who have never been here. That being said, I listened to all the outsiders tell me how "dangerous" Detroit is. My grandpa was from Detroit, but that was probably before Detroit took a wrong turn, so even though I heard great stories of Detroit's past, I am a visitor in 2015, and I don't want to take any chances. I booked the Westin because I believed that at $300 a night, the least I would get is safety. What I didn't expect was the "snobbery." I'm sorry to say but I did not feel welcome ONE BIT at this hotel. I am a HUGE Detroit sports fan, so I showed up wearing my Lions jacket and was looked at as if I wandered in to use the bathroom. After I checked in (the most uncomfortable check-in of my life), I wandered over to fumble with the elevator. Thank God another guest was there to help me. I didn't learn anything about any amenities in this hotel. Not one employee told me anything. Anyways, later that night I was dressed in Tigers gear to go to the baseball game and an employee actually looked at me and laughed!I will be honest, I hate this hotel. I stayed here because I love history and I heard it was really old (refurbished now), and a friend of mine had stayed here with his family and he thought it was nice. I thought it would be safer than the Holiday Inn a block away, but after this experience, I would take my chances on a bench outside the Riverwalk (no offence)!I love Detroit, but the one thing that Detroit does not need is snobs! And this hotel is full of them! I gave crackers to a homeless lady, and a valet guy yelled to me, "What are you selling out of that bag?" Seriously? I'm giving a lady some food, you big dorf! If you are in Detroit just to sleep then stay here because the bed was comfortable. Also, if you are afraid to interact with real people then you might like it here. This hotel is "so L.A." which is exactly what I didn't want. Shame.Valet & security when we were leaving..very rude...no customer service skills! Westin is paying valet & security guy to just chat it up while the customer just waits!Wow. Where do I even begin? At the beginning I suppose...I had such high hopes for this stay. So many wonderful reviews, such a beautiful building in the city I love most. Check in was problem free. The gentlemen who checked us in was polite, professional and friendly. Then we entered our room. This is where the stay went to hell in a hand basket. The carpet had not been vacuumed well at all. There was a huge piece of wallpaper coming off the wall under the window. Hair all over the bathroom floor. The toilet leaked. My heart sank. I opened to dresser to put some items away and there as a very long dark hair in it...my heart broke. For such an upscale and expensive hotel it felt like a Motel 6. The room itself was large and nicely decorated. The shower was heavenly, after we rinsed the long black hair out of it. We went for a late night drink at the Grill. For all of the Westin's flaws, the staff we encountered wasn't one of them. Top notch, above and beyond from the doorman to the bartender. Great drinks, tasty nosh. I'll go back the Grill. After drinks we headed to the elevator to turn in for the evening only to encounter an overflowing trash with someone's braid hanging out of it!!! For the love of cleanliness Westin, WTH is going on with your housekeeping???Needless to say. I'll not be back. The Atheneum has earned my trust after several stays there I've never had an unpleasant experience.Dammit Westin. You're a bummer.We were very happy with our stay here.  We didn't take advantage of many of the amenities, but it served us well for our 1 night stay.  The location was great, plenty of places are walkable from there.  The view from our room was very nice, we could see the Detroit River and lots of interesting downtown buildings.  The room itself was beautiful and roomy, including the nice spacious bathroom and shower.  Drinks at the Grille 47 Bar were very good and we had good service.  The bed was comfy but I must say the layers upon layers of soft comfy sheets and comforters was a little annoying to me, but my boyfriend loved them.  My only "would-be complaint" is that I thought there would be a Bar in the room with little liquor bottles and snacks.  There is a locked fridge, and I had to call downstairs for a key to open it, and to my surprise it was empty, just a fridge!  So we did put it to use with our water bottles, and I'm actually glad there wasn't a bar in the room because otherwise we might not have got out and about when we did. The restaurant menus are a bit pricey but there is a lot of variety in the price points with the bar menus to choose from too, and so much within walking distance.  In the morning they opened a Coffee/Danish shop in the Lobby where we got ourselves some nice Starbucks Coffees.  The staff, particularly Ann Marie I believe her name is, was very professional and helpful and friendly.  We would definitely go back here!This is an update to my previous review of the Westin Book Cadillac in Detroit from 12/6/2015.I came back for the 49er-Lions game.Westin Book Cadillac gets 5 Stars for the quick check in - I was 6th in line, served very fast and was placed in a great room.The Westin is NOT the problem.The problem is the 24 Grill restaurant downstairs in the Westin Book Cadillac.Hostess seated me promptly. Station attendant brought a menu, water and had the bartender bring me a beer.I sat there for 20 minutes waiting for a server to come take my order. The station attendant apologized. I waved my hands, waved the menu and tried to get the attention of the restaurant staff that was congregated at the bar area.After watching and listening an additional 7 minutes of the laughter and talking without being helped, I decided to leave.I asked for the bill to pay for my beer. The bill never came. As I walked over to the hostess station to ask if I could pay the bill, I heard one of the waiters ask her peers if I was going to pay for my beer. Well, of course I was going to pay for my beer. The staff didn't show concern for me when I sat there, but was very concerned when I was walking out. The bill appeared, I paid in full and left.I recommend staying at the Westin Book Cadillac, but stay away from the 24 Grill located on the 1st floor. There are too many other places to eat in the vicinity. I was dressed nicely, I was polite. The reason I was given for not being attended to was a "Shift Change." (Not likely, others around me were being assisted).Clean hotel. Has everything you need. Awesome historical building. Nice staff members.The worst hotel experience in the history of hotels. At different points people (staff?) entered my room, used my bed (yep, for that) and used the shower. Happened to another in my group too. Also they lost my luggage, laptop (at different times). And the staff and mamagement don't really care.I travel a lot and host meetings in my work. This is the worst experience ever. Don't do it.This hotel was amazing. When checking in the front desk asked what my plans were this weekend. I told her it was my birthday. She upgraded everything for free! She insisted on giving us a room with view. 22 floors up and we enter the room which was stunning. The hotel room was very spacious. The view was perfect. You could see the bridge and the river. The bathroom was huge. The shower was like a waterfall. The room was extra clean, no hairs anywhere.  The room was stocked with a mini bar which we didn't touch! The front desk gave us free Continental breakfast card at The Boulevard. You get your typical continental breakfast but you can upgrade for $5.00 and get anything off the menu.The staff here is very friendly and helpful. I will definitely be staying here again.It's such a shame nobody goes to Detroit ever anymore because this hotel is beautiful. I travel frequently for work and this is the nicest place I've gotten to stay (we usually stay at Marriotts or Starwoods). Interestingly enough, it was also one of the cheapest - so if you're in Detroit take advantage of the unfortunate times and snag a room at this wonderful spot!The lobby is gorgeous and the regular rooms are pleasant. I was actually upgraded to at typically $1,500 per night suite with a living room and giant bathroom which was super exciting! The restaurant, Roast, is fantastic. I generally prefer to venture outside my hotel to eat but Roast is just as good as any other top restaurant. The food is wonderful and the atmosphere is very elegant. Oh, elegant! I just thought of the perfect word to describe the hotel as a whole 3/4 through my review! The Westin Cadillac is quite elegant!Yeah, it's in Detroit, so the once thriving neighborhood looks a little post apocalyptic. Fortunately, the valet service is very efficient so you don't have to walk through the empty streets to find your car. Let's hope the city recovers soon so that more people are inclined to enjoy this great hotel.It pains me to write this review but it needs to be written.A lot can go into a bad review that othersise tarnishes a good establishment and this is the case with this reviewCheck in staff-- 5 starsRoom - 3 ( minus 1 for the view and minus 1 for the broken safe) late night Room service food and service--4.5 starsBar staff at Roast--5+ starsBar staff and cocktails at the lobby bar near check in--5 starsThis disaster of a stay began just after 4 AM with a fire alarm. After several minutes we emerged from our stupor and joined dozens of other confused sleepy people making our way down the stairs. Some dressed in robes, and various mismatched outfits thrown together last minute.Eventually without any sort of assistance  we made our way out of the hotel. On the way out down the stairs we encountered   several elderly patrons who were really struggling down the stairs. Fortunately they were being assisted by other guests who were functioning as good samaritans. At no point did we encounter staff either to assist us with directions or to see if anybody needed help.Out in the street it was chaos and people just hanging about. Some sleeping in the street. Again zero communication from hotel staff. We were camped out right in front of the doors sniffing fire truck exhaust. Some people chose to leave and check into the holiday inn.After about an hour the unofficial word hit the masses that it was OK to repopulate the hotel. Again zero communication.The rumor mill was in full effect. Many folks headed for the nonfunctioning elevators and piled in. Others milled about dazed and confused. . Some elected to try the stairs, but the rumor mill again in effect said that the doors would not open from the stairs. We were on 17 and chose not to walk 17 floors at 6 AM only to be denied access.The elevators still would not work, which a senior fireman randomly told us was  because the hotel could not reset their alarm and also because there was perhaps smoke in the basement and they (the hotel) needed to "get some fans" to blow it out ( where they were going to just get fans at 6 AM on a Sunday?? seemed to be the question most of us asked)A single elevator, like a lifeboat from a sinking ship somehow departed, but went to floor 13 and moved no further as if stuck on 13.....for 2 then 5 then 10 minutes. THe rumor mill assumed the worst, but soon chimed in that the doors would indeed allow egress from the stairs. Several in our elevator chose to depart. It really was surreal. A few of us remarked that this was what it must have felt like to be on the Titanic where the wrong choice could be disastrous!The 4 or 5 of us remaining in the elevator were soon saved by a maint. man of about 20 years old who got in and said with his magical elevator key he could reset the lockdown feature Floor by floor and ferry us to our floor, resetting the system each time. And this is what he did. We were the first and as far as I know only folks that got an elevator out of the chaos.We arrived at our door only to find this poor unfortunate soul staying at the room across from ours inserting his now non functioning key into and out of his door....again and again and again. Stranded with a bad key and knowing full well there was no way down and up to remedy the situation.We later saw him just sleeping in front of his door. Poor chap.Fortunately our key worked and we somehow managed to  fall asleep for a few hours.Upon awakening we found a letter slipped under the door inviting us to a complementary buffet breakfast. . I found the tone of the letter to be apologetic but not really apologetic. It was an apology for inconvenience while not apologizing for making safety their priority. SAFETY WAS NOT THEIR PRIORITY  AS DEMONSTRATED BY THE LACK OF  PERFORMANCE OF THEIR STAFFSorry,  having an automatic fire alarm self-direct hundreds of people on their own evacuation with no assistance at all from staff , and then figure out, on their own, how to make it back to their rooms does not show me that SAFETY WAS YOUR PRIORITY. You were just cluelessWe woke up and  waited 20 minutes for an elevator ( just 2  were working  ) and hit every floor on the way down only to be met by sleepy and frustrated people stranded waiting for an elevator  but unable to board below floor 14 since by then ours was full.Fires happen, and evacuations happen and inconveniences happen and I do not fault a hotel for that.What I do fault them for was being a completely rudderless ship, absolutely devoid of leadership and communication to their guests. Nobody was out and about as far as we could see, at least if they were they were silent and without a plan of action or commiunication towards the guests.I would hate to see it had there been a real emergency. Serious simulation on emergencies is required by members of this staff. This is not only a customer service issue, this is a safety issue. I will never ever stay at this hotel againVery disappointed in the staff at this hotel.  At 4am the fire alarm went off in the entire hotel.  Everyone in the entire building had to evacuate.  My sisters were staying in a handicap room.  Their alarm and flashing lights went off 30 minutes before everyone else.  They went to the front desk to tell them about it.  The woman at the desk told them to go back to their room and that everything was fine.  They couldn't go back to their room because of the loud alarm and flashing lights.  They decided to wait in the lobby. That's when the entire building went off and everyone evacuated. Everyone was standing outside for over an hour and a half.  Four fire trucks finally came along after a half hour into the waiting.  They checked the building and it was safe to go inside.  There was no one on the hotel staff to come outside and tell everyone about the incident.  They didn't organize anything or help with the evacuation.  THEY WERE USELESS. My handicapped sisters go back to their room to find the flashing lights and alarm still going off in their room.  They couldn't sleep there obviously, so they came to my bedroom.  My fiance had to sleep on the floor while my sisters and I crammed into one bed together.  The hotel did not comp their room for the night, but instead offered complimentary breakfast.  The next day when we got to the return car rental parking lot, we told the attendant about the incident and how we were so tired.  The parking attendant said, "Oh yeah, we've heard about that.  It's happened a few times before."  The fact that the hotel has dealt with the fire alarm going off and still didn't know how to handle it... blows my mind!!!!I AM EXTREMELY DISAPPOINTED BY THE HOTEL MANAGEMENT AND STAFF.  I WILL NEVER STAY HERE AGAIN.
review_content_20: This beautiful hotel should be (if it's not already) a Detroit landmark, the exterior is a beautiful reminder of Detroit's yesteryear automobile hay-day. The interior is modern and cozy and everything I've come to expect from a Westin. The rooms are larger than most downtown Westins I've stayed in, and they are completely up-to-date with new TVs, irons, hairdryers, blackout curtains and freshly pressed robes. These are the things I care about in hotel rooms, and The Westin knocks it out of the park every time. Robes trump views... they just do. If you're doing things in downtown like taking in a sporting event, hitting a rad Yelp party or chowing down on coney dog after coney dog, this spot is very centrally located, and likely your best bet.I arrived at 4pm and had to wait for my room to be cleaned! They made me wait for over an hour!Warning .. The Cadillac hotel car valet is not managed by the Westin...Spent 40  minutes waiting for car.  Westin management did nothing to rectify the situation. :-(This hotel is hard to review. On one hand it is a nice hotel. On the other, there are a few too many elements of cheapness to make it really good.First, the good: the rooms are quite big, the bed comfortable, the lounge chair nice. The desk is large and well laid-out and the desk chair is more comfortable than most. The bathroom is big, though I could do without the fancy rainfall-type showerhead because it doesn't have much pressure. The food - especially the restaurant Roast - is excellent, including the room service. If everything else was consistent with this I'd give it 4 stars easy.Now for the cheap: my biggest problem is the doors which are not only an industrial-looking gunmetal grey but go BANG! anytime one of your neighbors lets their go of their door without closing it gently. Seriously, it about knocks the fillings out of your teeth and forget trying to sleep in the mornings or evenings when people are coming and going. I cannot over-emphasize how freakin' loud the CRASH!! is every time a door is closed by letting go of it. It's like the person deliberately tried slamming it off its hinges. BOO for this!Then there's the HVAC system. It has only one control - the temperature - with no control for the fan (auto, high, low). And it blows directly onto the bed - I tried changing the direction things but it did nothing - so if you like a little air movement while you sleep, you're going to get a LOT of air movement and it's all going to directly on you.I've already mentioned the slower. Low water pressure stinks.Finally...$30 for valet parking? In Detroit?? Apparently they think it's New York. Come on, folks, that's just silly.Would I stay here again? I suppose, though I wouldn't be thrilled about it. The location is good and it's quality. But I wish they'd do something about the doors and upgrade the HVAC system.Where do I begin? I suppose with the good.We stayed here for just one night on a quick trip to Detroit to see my sister-in-law. The hotel was beautiful! We were really happy with our room. The bed was super comfy and the giant rainfall shower head was the best!I really didn't think it was going to matter where we stayed as I knew we would spend very little time in the room. We were out until around 2am and wanted to be up before 8am to start our day.On arrival, we put our card on the account, however my SIL was paying for our stay and came by later to put her card on it. We double checked the account before we left for the evening that day and verified that her card was on file, not our own. Come time to check out and my husbands debit card was charged despite our efforts to ensure that didn't happen. The manager came and told us that in fact his card was not charged, but the money was taken out as a hold. Funny that it happened at check out and not when we put the card on as a reserve for incidentals. So hopefully that charge will be falling off in the next few days. I don't know about you all, but I don't just have a couple hundred dollars laying around so this really is a pretty big deal for us. The manager didn't make it out to be a big deal to her, of course not...it wasn't her money!Then the dreaded night. In their defense, it isn't completely their fault. There was a legitimate fire alarm that sounded around 4:30am. So we had to trek down 20 flights of stairs and were then ushered outside. During this entire time, no one from the staff came to check on anyone that I saw. Most people (including myself) were in their pajamas. It was chilly. It would have been nice to have been offered a blanket or something along those lines. After an hour we were allowed back in. They were directing some people to the stairs but I couldn't walk up 20 flights of stairs so we opted to wait for the elevators. Good thing, because we were later told that the doors in the stairs are locked from that side so no one could have gotten to their floor anyhow.They attempted to get people in the elevators (which are tiny!) but with the fire alarm still engaged (though silenced) the elevators wouldn't work properly until the smoke was cleared from the basement. They tried to use the manual override to make them work but someone with a key would need to travel in each car and reset the elevator each floor it stopped on. We were fortunate to get in the 2nd elevator that went up, but I can't even tell you how many people were waiting behind us. In total we were out of our rooms for 1.5 hours.The staff seemed completely unable to deal with the situation at hand. They definitely need more disaster training and perhaps more than 1 person with a key to the elevators. Thankfully this didn't seem to be too bad of a fire.The next morning we received a letter from the hotel management apologizing for the inconvenience the alarm caused. They offered everyone free breakfast. Great, I guess? We already had made brunch plans so we didn't partake. Then it took us a good 20-30 minutes to get downstairs to meet our family because only 2 of the 5 elevators were "working". I would use the term working lightly there, though. They stopped on every single floor going up and down. And of course, this was around the time most people were checking out so the elevators were extra busy. We had chosen a late check out so we didn't need to go then, thankfully.After a few trips up and down the rest of the morning, I was extremely happy to be leaving...until the fiasco with the room being charged to the wrong card. It was a very stressful night. I loved the hotel....but there were just too many things that went wrong. I don't know that we would ever stay there again.Beautiful spot for drinks!  Nice Jazz in the background!  Quick staff!  Good drink prices!  Flights are nice!  Elegant!I've live in Detroit FOREVER and this is the first time i've been here - It's very beautiful inside and i was greeted at the entrance.  Even though i wasn't staying and mainly using their stairs for practice (ALA stair climb) - everything was clean and straighten.The only thing reason i knocked off a star was due to there Valet team - I'm pretty sure they were great but staging the vehicle in the middle of street can cause an issue.  I would hate if I used valet and came back with an missing mirror.  (smh!)Booked a king room on the executive level, which includes executive lounge access. Would highly recommend getting an executive room! The lounge has breakfast which is basic but nice. In the afternoon and evening there are nice snacks, and the lounge is open throughout the day for chips, water bottles, sodas, TVs, and a free printer. The lobby is currently being renovated, but it's not that invasive. Overall looks nice. The executive King is a rather large room. The bathroom is also nice, and ours had a window. For about $150/night, definitely better value than the casinos.Pinch me!  No, not hard enought.  Pinch me harder!  This is what I said about my stay at the this Westin.  I thought I dreamt that I stayed in a five star resort in some hipster location.Nope, I stayed at the Westin Book Cadillac in downtown Detroit!  A M A Z I N G    H O T E L!The staff is wonderful...professional, helpful and engaging.For certain groups, they offer free shuttle service.  Nice perk!We loved the on-site restaurant and I typically shy away from hotel eateries.  I would come back to the restaurant without staying at the hotel.  It was that good.As other have said and I agree, the rooms are large, spacious, clean and the bathrooms...oh the bathrooms are a liitle piece of heaven.Detroit is lucky to have this gem of a hotel!Good and bad. I miss the speakman heavenly shower. My room:3 bad light bulbs. One even had a note from a previous user to replace the bulb. Stains and a burn mark in the carpet. No idea why but the minibar is locked. The heater kept raising the temperature in the room. I kept lowering the thermostat but kept heating up. I finally called the staff and this was corrected within 30 minutes. Pros:Westin staff are always 115% Very positiveVery professionalMake them the best hotel chainThe beds are still perfectLight tight rooms ease the morning after a long night out. Room rate was super reasonable for a non holiday or special event stay.I have been here 2x now not to stay but to drink and hang out with friends.  The service is very slow in the lounge and bar area.  The seating is spaced out so its hard to get a spot sometimes.  I would not be come here again for drinks.  The only reason for the 2 stars was they have good house wine.Date night! Excellent hotel, we'll be back, this is our go-to hotel going forward.The Pros: - Spacious room- Great bathroom- Everything appeared to be exceptionally clean- Very professional and courteous staff (very)The Cons:- Took longer than expected to get our luggage from the valet/doorman up to our room (we were in a time-crunch, so it made it a little more of an anxious experience than normal), they told us 5-10 minutes at check-in, but I had to call the front desk twice to get a status - it wound up taking about 20 minutes.- Check-in took a long time; the staff was great, it's just that the process seemed very slow (could actually be attributed to how helpful the staff was being with the customers...). - Wifi was not free. - The bathroom was a little chilly and difficult to get warm (But those bath robes though! Nice!)The location is perfect - about 10 minutes from most good things (the river, casinos, Fox, Masonic, etc). I remember someone else mentioning the People Mover proximity - we didn't hear it at all (15th floor), wasn't an issue.We stayed at the Ren Cen a month ago - it pales in comparison. For the price range ($250-ish), the Ren Cen room was about (...or felt about...) half the size with half the intangibles. However....the Ren Cen room was 40 floors up with a riverside view. Hard to beat that (...it did though).We didn't get a chance to try any of the amenities (bar, restaurant, gym, etc.), maybe next trip.I had an issue with another patron that caused me to lose sleep. I am writing this review because they handled the problem and I am leaving happy. I look forward to coming back. Room 922 5/23/15The woman on the phone around 9am was very helpful, thanks.Had to spend 18 days there, for business, and enjoyed every day.  Great hotel.  Great beds.  Great service.  Indoor pool and hot tub.  Great workout room.  Roast, in the lobby, is one of the best restaurants in town.  Two big thumbs up.They say they've renovated, but I was very underwhelmed by the room. And the air/heat was so noisy. Mediocre.Planned to stay at the Westin for a work trip, but it was canceled at the last minute. Nevertheless, I experienced really helpful and accommodating customer service from the hotel management which I think is worth mentioning even though I cannot directly comment on the rooms themselves.We had an amazing stay here. The hotel staff was so friendly and helpful, even treating us to champagne and strawberries for a special occasion! Loved how close we were to the people mover and how easy it was to get in and out. The hot tub was closed for repair but that was alright. The restaurants and coffee shops were wonderful and we will return again when staying in Detroit!Good rooms. Completely fell apart with a fire incident though. They couldn't get their elevators working properly the whole day after. They also managed to charge the wrong card for my stay. They need more disaster practice. Did not make me feel safe it felt more like they had no idea what to doBeautiful hotel in a great location. Also, coming from NYC, it seems like a great value! Stayed here for a conference and thought the food/drinks were fantastic. Staff was very friendly and helpful. Room was nice. My only complaint was that there was no hot water for one night/one morning during my stay--seems like it took a long time to correct the problem. Guessing this was a freak occurrence, though.This is a great hotel. If you're visiting Detroit, get yourself a room here. You can thank me later.The experience starts when you pull up in front of the hotel. The valets are right there, ready to help - Can I help you with your bags? How is your day? - friendly and polite. It almost seems like they enjoy parking other people's cars all day, which maybe they do, or maybe they hire out-of-work actors who are just really good at pretending. Whatever the secret, it's incredible. You walk into a marvelous, beautiful building. More smiling faces. Check in was a breeze - and again, it was like the woman actually enjoyed her job. I needed laundry done, so I threw it in a bag and sent it down. The laundry is a little ridiculously expensive, and they starched my underwear (bizarre), but then they hung the stuff up in the closet and it was there when I got home from work, so whatever. Can I have this for always?The overhead light was burnt out, so I called the desk, and the woman I spoke with kept apologizing (lightbulbs burn out, calm down) and had it fixed right away. Where do they find these people?My room was beautiful. Huge. Great views of the city. Comfortable, relaxing, wonderful. I felt like royalty. I love the Book Cadillac, and you will too.The not-free WiFi is a little stupid, though. This is 2014. Let's get with it.
review_content_40: Overall (architecture, amenities and restaurant) this place is fantastic. However, on our last visit we found torn streamers, balloon remnants and a used condom in our room. Gross! We complained to the manager a the front desk, but she only offered us rapidly embarrassed blinking reactions. Awkward and still gross.We stayed here for our anniversary. They gave us a corner room which is bigger, complientary wine in our room too! Beuatiful and clean room. Quiet. Great service. I will come back. Had dinner at Roast in the hotel. Very good.This is my second time staying here. Both times the hotel has been very clean and uneventful.  The staff is professional. The rooms are modern and decorated nicely with nice views of the lake. I would absolutely recommend and look forward to returning.The rooms were outstanding. Super comfy bed too and the shower and bathroom is the best!! So roomy. The brunch we had on Sunday as an event was amazing. Love the omelet station.  Friendly bartenders at the hotel bar. Highly recommend this hotel. Slightly pricey though.Great hotel location in the heart of Detroit. We stayed there for two nights and had a large room on the 22 floor with views of the city. The hotel is extremely well located, has a spa, two great restaurants, a bar and nice staff. We stayed two nights there and really enjoyed the place. Our only disappointment was the breakfast on the executive room : though the view is nice, you get the regular non appealing selection of eggs, oatmeal, non tasty fruits, highly sugary drinks, blend bacon and sausages... This is not happening only in Detroit but still, it is always so disappointing. Apart from this and the $5 coffee downstairs, everything is great.I arrived on Wednesday 7/30/14 at 4:45 p.m. at which time I was told my room was not ready. I was told it should only be about 30 to 45 minutes wait and that I would not have to stand in line again I could just pick up the key. We were asked if the room billing needed to be split in half my reply was no just one bill please. I got separate bills. When our room was ready the person who checked us in was no longer at the front desk so we waited in line another 15 minutes to receive a key. We were not offered a key to the mini bar or even told where the elevators were located. We dropped our bags in the room and went to have dinner in your restaurant. I can not even begin to express how bad the service was. I ordered a $78.00 bottle of wine and had to ask three times when it was coming. The appetizer arrived after 30 minutes unfortunately no one had given us silverware or napkins, we were still waiting on the wine. Our server handed us unfolded napkins and lose silverware he grabbed from somewhere. When the food arrived the carrots were raw and the mashed potatoes were cold and the chicken was dry from being over cooked.. We asked to speak to the manager who offered no apologies just said he would remove the meal from the bill. Which was the least he could do since none of it was eaten. We actually went to the bar to get an appetizer since dinner was uneatable. The server there was the only good point of our visit. The next morning when I got up I went to put the comforter back on the bed. Please see the attached pictures! Both comforters were stained. Not only were they stained but the were not old stains they appeared to be untreated. I am a business women who travels frequently, I just joined Westin  and was more than disappointed. I was in Detroit for a trade show and did not have time to go to the front desk to complain. I have contact management several times and have not been satisfied with a resolution.Took great care of us, despite having multiple weddings and a convention. Never noticed the activity.As usual with Westin, the bed was great. We had a nice sized king room with a great view of tiger stadium.One complaint, and this is the case with all upper end hotels - why do I need to pay for wifi when I am shelling out hundreds for the room???? Aloft gives free wifi to Starwood members - why doesn't Westin (The Ritz and 4 Seasons are no different). It makes no sense...This hotel is beautiful. Very snazzy and classy, looked like there were plenty of activities one could partake in.But alas, the one part of my stay that was not luxurious was my bed. I like a firm yet soft bed. Like a firm pillow top would have been perfect. I apparently got the handicapped Klingon room. The bed was firm but that is about it. Maybe a little softer than the wood plank I felt like i had laid on. I love it when they put me in one of these handicapped rooms as I am 6'6" and many hand operated switches/ buttons etc are placed low.Anyway - if you want a "pinky up" nice swanky hotel, this is your hotel. Hipster will like this too as it is in an old hotel building with a lot of history.We had a wonderful experience minus one front desk lady who was really rude.  Hotel is in a wonderful location and beautifully done.  It has all the amenities you need.  We were on the top floor and the club is very nice for breakfast.  Rooms are quite nice with a clean feel and high quality materials used for decor and building.  Prices are usually pretty pricey but in this case they gave a great wedding deal for the block of rooms... Valet is quick, easy, and accessible.My favorite place to stay in Detroit. Very plush for the price. Good location for downtown work, night spots, and sporting events.This hotel was absolutely beautiful. I was amazed. Spacious, gorgeous, comfortable!The bathroom was really big, there were two shower heads in the shower, I loved the soap they had, and the robes were so cushy!I had a great sleep that night.There was a fun bar just down the road which the staff advised us of. Bonus.I would 100% go back to this hotel.They even rent gym clothes! Shoes, socks, tops, and shorts. I've never seen that before!Classic hotel that's both historic and modern, both elegant and friendly. Only complaint is the parking, which is right next door but there's no hotel entrance on the parking garage side, and during many hours there isn't one on the other two sides of the hotel, either. So you have to trek all the way around the entire hotel to go back and forth to your car.I solved it by renting a bike and leaving the car mostly in the garage. I was worried about where I'd lock the bike safely, but the doorman just smiled and said "take it up to the room". Right answer! And the rooms are plenty big so even adding a bike or two didn't cramp us.I am in the hospitality industry and I stay in a lot of hotels across the US. This hotel exceeded my expectations the moment I walked in the door. The door staff was pleasant and accommodating, but not overbearing. The front desk agent was super friendly. I was upgraded to the concierge floor - and my room was extra large with plenty of bedside outlets, great amenities, a spacious closet with plenty of hangers, great views of Detroit - and great linens. The bathroom had a window (always a plus), And the bed was super comfortable. The hotel service levels all 4 nights did not disappoint. One night a colleague was leaving late after dinner and two valet's walked her to her hotel 3 blocks away after I jokingly asked that she be escorted because it was so late. The only reason I did not give this hotel 5 starts is because one of my pieces of dry cleaning was clearly only pressed and not dry cleaned as I requested and as I was charged. And a long distance phone was was charged to my folio after I checked out - time stamped hours after I left the hotel (no one uses hotel phones - that charge was bogus and I had it removed). Other than those two hiccups, the hotel did a great job. Helpful hint***the gift shop in the hotel sells RedBull for $4.99 each and the Starbucks in the hotel sells them for $1 less. Too bad I figured that out on day 3.Friendly helpful check in. Nice large room. Conveniently located to lake front. Iron Chef Michael Symon's restaurant Roast located in the hotel.This is one of my top hotel choices when I come to Detroit.  It is very nice with a decent size gym and pool.   The staff is friendly and restaurants "Roast" is attached to this!   I enjoyed my last two visits here.  No complains! :)It's a great hotel rated 4 stars but the room I was given had a problem with the heat. It stayed at 60F or below. The temp outside was 34 F and the room was cold. Called the front desk and she called the engineer . Tried fixing it remotely and then came to my room at midnight to check it with his tool kit! The guy tried hard but nothing worked . It was between using more sheets to cover myself and sleeping or moving to another room well past midnight . All this at The Westin!!! Is it my sheer luck or coz they are trying to sell some bad rooms cheap on Hotwire !!While they did upgrade me and offered to move my bags , since I was visiting for business and staying only for a night the upgrade didn't seem a huge bonus or comp compared to the inconvenience caused, my lost sleep and having to move rooms at 1am in my pj's!  Not something you expect at a big brand hotel like this. Are they not expected to check the A/C - heat etc when they get the room ready for a guest ???  Upgrade to a luxury suite in my circumstance didn't seem the most appropriate compensation! At least the engineer operator and Manager were apologetic and courteous thus the three stars !We stayed here for a week and had a very enjoyable time.  Great central location close to Comerica park and Ford Field.Helpful check-in staff.Room was kept clean. A few things occasionally forgotten during housekeeping but very quickly corrected when requested. Plenty of restaurants on site. Roast and 24 Grill both good.If you need transport, use Uber. These guys are everywhere downtown and great value.Definitely would stay here again.We had a great experience at the Westin Book Cadillac. Our room was very clean and spacious, there was free (and very good) Starbucks coffee in the room, and our floor was very quiet. We did the self-park and it was easy to do, as well as cheap. Don't forget to validate your ticket before you leave the garage in order to get the unlimited in and out privileges. I subtracted a star because we had to stand in line to check in and because the Westin (like most) charges for wireless. The room wireless does cover multiple devices, though. We were able to use 2 laptops and 2 iphones after registering once even though the website acted like we would get charged every time.love this hotel.  have been to Roast plenty of times and have always wanted to stay at this hotel.  We decided to just that while we were able to enjoy all of Detroit.  The hotel and room is beautiful, spacious and classic.   The staff - from valet to customer service - was very professional and knowledgeable. Our view from our room was lovely to see during the day and when Detroit lit up.   We will be return again for another stay.This hotel experience was fabulous from start to finish.  We were originally scheduled to stay only a Friday, but had to leave Toronto early due to an impending snowpocalypse.  I called ahead, they said they had rooms and to just come on in.We were greeted promptly at reception and because I had mentioned on the reservation it was my boyfriend's 30th birthday present, we got UPGRADED.  They also honoured my pre-paid room rate for the extra day.  Which was $129...for a 5 star hotel experience.  Amazing.The customer service was great.  Everyone was just so friendly and helpful.  I had a massage at the spa and have to give a huge shout out to Melvin!  He was amazing and gave me the best deep tissue I've had in years AND I chatted with him the entire time because he was so nice and fun to talk to, it was totally relaxing.  We had good experience at the restaurants in the building and it was in walking distance of Joe Louis Arena (we were there for the hockey game).  Now here's where the hotel gets the 5 star: it is the hotel that most visiting hockey teams stay at.  We were there to see the Oilers and not only bumped into a bunch of them, but also ate breakfast in the Boulevard Room with the coach just feet away!  It was an awesome experience. When we left, I was nothing but happy except for ONE THING: two 45 second phone calls to Ann Arbor cost us $15.  I figured they'd be expensive but we had to try and get in touch with our American friends for the hockey game.  That was the only disappointing aspect of our experience. Overall, I had a wonderful time and will be back again next time I'm in Detroit for sure!
review_content_60: This hotel definitely lives up to the Westin standard by which all Westins strive. A nice, extremely well-kept hotel near Downtown. Rooms are well-appointed and, as all hotels continue to upgrade, plenty of outlets available for your electronics and a nice, 42-inch flat-screen TV to enjoy.Rooms and bathrooms are kept meticulously clean, always so important to see!In this particular room, they have replaced the 'heavenly shower', a shower that has 2 shower heads, with a large 'rain' type of head installed on the ceiling, with a hand-wand spray adjunct. This would be a potential disaster except for the water pressure, which is excellent, so you do end up getting suitably drenched! The staff are extremely friendly and helpful, another fine example of their realization of how important good customer service is. Of all the hotels I've stayed in Detroit, this is by far my favorite so far.Hotel is beautiful rooms were great. Service awful. Front desk wait time was a nightmare. Valet and bellmen were great and helpful.We booked a block of rooms at the Westin Book Cadillac for our wedding and we hosted a brunch at the hotel the day after for all our out of town guests. We were really disappointed with the customer service. Many repeated errors were made in the reservations and rooms were blocked for people that weren't' even our guests. We had to correct reservations multiple times. Their follow-up with us was terrible and we went weeks without getting a response after multiple voice messages. Additionally, the food for the brunch was terrible and the bagels were rock hard. For the price we paid we were truly disappointed. Also the valet service was really slow and disorganized with back ups and a police incident one day. Terrible customer service all the way around.OK, first a trip down memory lane.   My folks would bring us to Detroit when I was young.  It was a great and vibrant city at the time.  Relatives owned a big (7 story) shoe store on Grand Circle called Fyfes.  Uncle worked as an underwriter for  an insurance company whose office was in Washington a block away from the Book Cadillac.  What a hotel that was.And what a hotel it's become!  Valet parking was a breeze---people were on the spot and very nice.  Check in is on the second floor.  People at the front desk were outstanding.  Pleasant, informative and a pleasure to deal with.The room was much bigger than I expected.  It has standard Westin appointments with a surprise.  The shower has a rain feature--which I normally don't like--BUT this one is adjustable with an added feature of a uniques hand held to boot.Had a cocktail and appetizers in the lobby bar--very good.  The sports bar was very good...one of the best burgers I have ever had---plus the house made to order chips were great.  Very good service here, too.This is a great hotel, not only for Detroit, it would be great anywhere.  Highly recommended.One of the nicest Westin hotel in the Midwest.  Excellent staff service, rooms are well appointed and the valet service is very reasonable.  All amenities you can expect from Westin!Impressive and much more than I expected!I have stayed at other Westin properties and thought this was going to be a mediocre experience. I was absolutely wrong.Valet was fast, friendly, and hassle free. Check in is on second floor. Customer service at the reception desk was friendly and helpful for recommendations in the surrounding area.Room was bigger than I imagined and very quiet. Didn't hear any noise throughout the nights of our stay.The Roast restaurant is phenomenal! A must try for fine diners. Reservations are a must and usually booked way in advance. If you are unable to obtain a table and don't mind dining at the bar; I highly recommend tasting the wonderfully fused foods!My overall experience was superb and I would definitely stay at this property again. Highly recommended!I don't know where to start. My experience at the Weston Book has not been favorable. Small things like food underneath the dresser in plan site, that hadn't been vacuumed up. Being woken up at 8:30 in the morning by a maid, who has the subtleties of Sherman tank.The room looks inward onto a roof top with A/C units, which by the way are on all day and night. Yes you can hear them. Small and petty is may next issue, Wifi is 7 bucks a day. Are you kidding me! The room cost close to $200 a night and you can't provide free Wi-Fi. I can afford the seven dollars a day, it's just the general idea of having all these little extra charges. It's almost seems like they're not satisfied with me choosing there hotel, so they need to constantly let me know that they want more money. If you want more money you just add the extra seven dollars a day to the price of the room. Why 7 dollars? There must be at least 100 guest within a week at  this hotel. If everyone paid seven dollars for one days use that's like two years of Wi-Fi. I'm only here for three days.I'm almost afraid to go down to the lobby because I have no idea how my "incidental" charges will be affected.I have no doubt that when I booked my reservation through the travel site, hidden in one of these contracts or agreements there is a Wi-Fi clause. I'll just have to make sure that I have produce of all of my documentation and contracts so when I show up at the front desk I can present my case as a guest of the Westin.Next time I come I will try another place. It's no big deal. Your hotel looks amazing and i love the beds, but really it is just so so.I just arrived home from a trip to Detroit with my husband. I must write to say what a wonderful stay we had at this hotel. The staff blew us away on their professionalism. From the front desk to the coffee shop and the 24 Grill staff we were treated with such great care. I would recommend this hotel to anyone.Thank you once at again Westin Book Cadilac for allowing the crew at Events To Remember Event Production and Design, LLC to set up a wonderful wedding at your facility this Sunday.  As usual your staff there was outstanding!  Jeremy the banquet houseman made sure that each and every one of our needs where met during set up.  We were required to flip the ceremony space into a reception space in 45 minutes and it went flawlessly due to the team effort between our staff and yours! We were done within 35 minutes!  Way to go!   Apryl , Mohammed and the bartender Wesley were so awesome to work with, very pleasant and kind people as well as the security staff on the dock. We thank you all so very much and can't wait for the chance to work with you all again!I stayed at other so called "High End Hotels" in Detroit, they're noisy and slightly unprofessional, If you're looking for first class hotel that treats you right, come here and only here!I booked this place for my anniversary, first off check in was pleasant, we told them it was our anniversary and they bumped our room up to a nicer room, (no extra charge) we went swimming and came back to a complementary bottle of champagne, and fruit. Cant tell you how much we appreciated that!The room was large and spacious, the bathroom had two  separate showers and rain spout overhead. beautiful tile work throughout. It was so quiet in our room, i didn't hear a peep. Things could not be better. Thanks Westin Book Cadillac, you have a fan for life.We stayed at the Book Cadillac for one night. We were in the Detroit area visiting family and were catching a game at Comerica Park our first night. The hotel is very swanky and beautiful. Our check in was easy and the front desk staff was very friendly. BDK is a Starwood member so our room was on the 21st floor, but when we got there, He thought he smelled residual smoke so he called the front desk and we were moved to a new room....and this time it was a suite on the same floor. The room was nice and spacious and we had a view of the ballpark from our bathroom window. This was a huge deal for me as I am a HUGE baseball fan. We were traveling with a 4 year old and we called for a rollaway bed which arrived promptly and appeared to be very comfortable. My favorite part of the room was the bed. Oh my goodness that bed! The linens were nice, the pillows were comfy, and the mattress was the right mix of firm and soft....sounds like a contradiction. The bathroom was very large: tub and a separate glassed in shower with a rainwater shower head. The only negative was that the vanity was very small.  We only stayed one night so it wasn't a huge deal. But for a longer stay it would be problematic as I tend to travel with quite a few toiletries. The location could not be beat! We were able to walk to Comerica and the following day we walked down to the river walk. One more thing, the doorman when we arrived was very friendly and very helpful with directions. As for value, I can't say. We got the room on Starwood points.We've stayed at just about every moderate to upscale hotel downtown and this was the cleanest, quietest, and best maintained hotel by far. Truly a luxury bathroom for the ladies. They've done a beautiful job of restoring this historic building.After eating at Michael Symon's Roast restaurant for dinner, I now can't stay there is any better romantic getaway downtown. The bed really is heavenly as advertised.The Book Cadillac is the nicest hotel in Detroit.  It has a great gym with a lap pool, a beautiful lobby bar and an elegant entrance.  That doesn't really tell the story...The Book Cadillac was the largest luxury hotel in downtown Detroit, until it fell to the forces that brought down many of Detroit's great buildings.  In this case the building was saved via a truly stunning renovation.  From the history display in the lobby, they took the building all the way down to the cement/rebar supports and rebuilt everything.  Its amazing to see.  If you just look at it as a nice Westin, you're missing how impressive this building really is.The rooms are spacious and everything about them is comfortable and well laid out.  But its far more amazing when you consider that at one point the first floor was under water from the roof.Downtown for a wedding here and overnight stay. I remember this hotel from when I worked downtown in 1982 and would come for lunch. The redo is spectacular! We had a lovely room on the 21st floor with peeks of the river and bridge from the window. Room was expansive, bathroom is large with a European style shower, beds were warm and comfy with lots of pillows to suit your preference. The wedding in the Crystal Ballroom was beautiful, the dinner and desserts (and late night pizza) tasty and filling. Breakfast this morning in the Boulevard Room was also fresh and special: Egg White omelette filled with Turkey, Cheese and Arugula with a side salad of Arugula, Avocado, the most finely diced Tomato on earth, and a delicious hollandaise slightly sweetened with OJ (try it for sure!) . Hands down and easily five start without hesitation. Well done Detroit!Great experience staying here.  I was in town for a conference for a few days and stayed at the Weston.
