The military room rate is always appreciated at the Marriott, the location is great seeing that it's downtown by the water and the people mover is accessible.  The room was nice and cozy,nothing too special. The service was mediocre, especially since originally they didn't apply my Marriott rewards number and tried to charge me for complimentary Wi-Fi.  They also don't have complimentary parking. Nevertheless, I would return.We stayed here during a trip to see the Tigers play the Royals.  I haven't spent much time (if any) in Detroit so I was pleasantly surprised to find the city very welcoming.  Like any city it had its share of "stuff" but overall clean.   The center has many things so you don't really have to leave much if you are just there for a quick weekend.  We left to go to our events (baseball game, murder mystery dinner, and escape from the room with a zombie.  However, other than that, we stayed in.  The hotel bar/restaurant Volt was surprisingly good.  Staff at the hotel were very nice.  No complaints at all about the room - the view was phenomenal.  We had a wall to wall view of the river and Windsor.  We had two rooms that were "suite-ish" (called executive suites).  Definitely if I ever go back to Detroit, I would stay there... unless I stayed in a casino (which I didn't know that had or might have stayed there! :)This is going to have to be another good/bad rating because there is a lot.Good:  Great location, walking to distance to wherever you need to go or you can jump on the train.Good/Bad:  This hotel is huge, overwhelmingly huge. It is easy to get lost in this hotel.Bad:  Most of the restaurants close early.  The do cater to the Mon-Fri guests.  Good:  When they are open, there is a huge assortment of places to eat.Great:  The fitness center.  It is up to date and has great views.  Even better was the staff.  The women who runs the gym was so sweet and kind.  She even gave me some fruit to take back to my room with me.  She went out of her way to make sure that she was able to meet my whole family.Great:  The concierge lounge.  The food was good, always well stocked and the staff members were friendly.  We had extra hockey tickets and they helped us try to sell them. We were in a basic room, the room was nice sized and clean.  the only negative I can give is where we were, the blue lights from the top of the GM building flashed all night long.  We tried to close the curtains, but you could still see the lights.Like:  We loved being able to see Canada out the window.Now, the huge negative... the bar.  We went down to have a few drinks not realizing how expensive the drinks were. There were four of us there, 6 beers and 2 martinis later, the bill was just under $100.00.  We were shocked.  I don't mind paying for a drink, but the prices were crazy!I am familiar with the Ren Cen since I'm from the area and have attended events here.  I had seen the rooms at the Ren Cen Marriott many times but not stayed here.This winter, I booked a last minute weekend stay.  It was intended more as a surprise weekend "getaway" for the person I was dating.  It was a busy winter with work and a lousy winter with bad weather so we needed a break.I was able to get a room at a good rate (less than the $200/night I expected).  We had a beautiful river view (and view of Canada across the river at night).  The room was clean and spacious and modern looking with a cozy bed (great warm comforter and nice pillows).  The bathroom was a bit basic (if this was Chicago or something maybe a jacuzzi would have been nice) but without any flaws.  The room was very clean too.Service was excellent from reservation to check in and during the stay.  We didn't do much except relax (had a dress up night at Andiamo for dinner and just hanging out at Volt lounge and then to nearby Greektown more casually the next day) but the fitness center was very nice.  I can understand some of the criticisms of reviewers.  The Ren Cen is confusing.   Where is the main level?  Where are the elevators?  Where is the food court?  Where do I park and get in or out?  Oh the shopping is here?  Why is it so quiet and empty on the weekend (well it is the middle of winter)?I don't know if I would spend this much on a romantic weekend again though.  It doesn't really change problems in a relationship but at least in the end we had a great weekend to remember.  I do think save this and keep it in mind for an anniversary or a wedding if you are from the area.  The service is good for that.The management here sucks.  They wouldn't work with our schedule to extend our stay.  They were the most inflexible hotel managers I have ever seen.  I'm Platinum Premiere and stay at a lot of Marriotts.  We a Flight Crew members and have a late flight out and needed a little later checkout.Really cool hotel and very convenient because it has almost everything you need located inside, only thing is that it gets a little confusing trying to get to some of the places inside but a little extra walking never hurt anybody, the bar is really cool tooThis is the second year in a row that I stayed at this hotel while attending Movement Festival. Besides the horrendous line to check-in, there isn't much to complain about. The hotel was very considerate of the events in town and supplied all guests with a box of Red Bull and ear plugs since the event went from noon to midnight and could be heard from the hotel. The rooms are always clean and sterile. I shared the room with my boyfriend so naturally, when we saw only one bath towel, I called the front desk to have more delivered. They were never delivered, however, in the morning, when the maid came to check on us, she was extremely concerned that we didn't have enough towels and immediately went and got us some. The staff at the hotel was very friendly and polite. The hotel itself is very accommodating. There is a CVS Pharmacy, gift shop, liquor store, gym, Starbucks, bar, and several restaurants to choose from. The hotel is walking distance to the River Walk and also to Hart Plaza. The wifi in the rooms cost per day, but if you go to the lobby, the wifi is free. There are also kiosks where you can print out your boarding pass if you are heading to the airport.The Concierge Lounge puts this Marriott over the top! Yes, I had excellent sevice on check in and the room had a great river view. But, the 1 huge differentiator was the Concierge Lounge.I checked in and ran about 4 miles as I was tired and stiff from traveling. After getting back, I washed my running clothes in the sink so as to not have stinky stuff in my suitcase. Only problem was there was no place to dry it. I decided to work in the Lounge and the very wonderful woman asked if there was anything she could do for me. To which I responded, yes, please let me use a dryer. I explained the scenario and she said, "go get the running clothes and I'll go take care of this using Housekeeping's systems".  She did and she brought out ice cream with hot fudge and fresh strawberries. OMG! what a delectable treat.Breakfast in the lounge this next day way also very, very good.This isn't the newest or swankiest place I've stayed. Not even the top Marriott. But, the staff make this a 5 star experience.We've staked here several times and the beds are so comfy and they have nice sheets. Room service was a bit slow but the food was very good. For some reason they gave us a handicap room and the layout it a bit weird and the room is noisy. You can hear everything going on in the hallway. This room is located by the elevator so you can imaging the noise! The valet employees are super rude and very unprofessional. When they took our car they rushed us out and I forgot something.(medication) my husband called to get them to bring the car so we could retrieve it and they were mad and actually said "what the fu#% for "when another employee said they have to re park the car!  They also pealed out of the parking lot with the car in front of ours! Not impressed at all!!!! I give the valet staff a 1 star!!!!Got to my room and only had one pillow per bed, called to the front desk and asked for some pillows and was told that they did not have any and that they had to locate some. I'm sorry I didn't know pillows were lost children, should we put pictures of pillows on milk cartons? Oh also I had to watch a guy get tased  in the hallway. Boo this place. And room service isn't 24 hours.Weird round hallways with squiggly carpet makes getting ice an adventure. Room service Pizza was delicious. Almost 25.00 a night in tax.  13.00 a night for Internet  yikes.  Glass round floors looking down on other floors.  Look for high rooms bc you can totally see into the office buildings and see what they are eating for a snack. Weird.  Pillows rock once your eyes refocus from vertigo.   Staff is a mixed bag either they avoid eye contact and make comments about how happy they are to leave shift... Or they are the nicest people I ever met!  It's a crap shootSo there I was hooking up for a nooner with......kidding.  I came here for a few meeting events over the years.  Don't know about the rooms, so can't comment on those.The event rooms are...dated.  They're seriously in need of a good scrub and refresh...but, then again, I guess that makes it "quintessential Detroit" then, on some level. :)Food service...typical, meh, "I'm at an event in a hotel" food.The serious pain here is with LOCATING the damned room you're supposed to be in.  Now, I get that I'm "a guy", and I'm well aware that I am navigationally challenged...but when I follow the arrows, signs, and directions explicitly...and STILL wind up TWO FLOORS AWAY from where I'm supposed to be...that's a problem.  That alone was annoying enough that I almost walked out of the hotel without even attending the last event.Parking is easy, valet is available, and lots of cool stuff within walking distance (we washed away the hotel food with the beer selection at the nearby Jacoby's), so get out and explore a bit.We called the week before our stay to check concierge room hours. The person verified the concierges room was now open 7 days ago, and Friday and Saturday evening is 5:00 p.m. - 10:00 p.m. In addition, the concierge will be open for breakfast 7 days a week. We just checked out and the concierge room is not open in the evenings 7 days a week. In addition, the room isn't open in the morning at the time listed. The parking has a text feature to request your car from valet. The text response reads, "Your request requires payment. Please see a valet attendant." So, I went to the front desk to be sure there were no issues with my card. The young lady at the front desk says, "You have to go to valet, they're separate from the hotel." I said, "I know parking is managed by Central Parking. The text said their is an issue with payment (while showing her the text I received). I'm paying Marriott for the parking, not Central." She checked the room and valet parking was charged to the room and no issues with the card. She continued to repeat, "Valet is separate from the hotel." I then asked, "Would you mind calling downstairs to valet to let them know there are no issues?" She said, "You have to go to valet." I said, "I know, but there's obviously a problem." I gave up at the front desk and went to valet. Valet was showing no payment, yet we were charged in our room for valet. The lady at valet fixed the issue.This hotel has a lot of work to catch up to the standards of the Marriott brand.This hotel is slightly smaller than the Bat Cave. We found the rooms to be clean and tasteful. Most of the views are spectacular. Not only are a ton of famous Detroit landmarks within walking distance, the hotel staff is knowledgeable about local public transportation and overall seem to be a very friendly lot. We were a bit confused as to where to park. The Beaubien garage is fairly reasonable. I can't speak for the food; I don't think I've ever eaten at a hotel, come to think of it. The drinks are pricy but they don't skimp on the portions. It would seem that other reviewer's concerns about the modernity of the rooms has been addressed, by the way. Everything seems brand new and spotless, but again, it's all about the staff and the people here are very nice.I made a reservation in February for my anniversary thinking that everything was all set I called today to confirm my reservation only to find out that our reservation was cancelled apparently in march by a email that was not the email used to make the resrvation.  After being on the phone with multiple represenatives I found out that the hotel is over booked by 120 rooms and their is nothing left open.   Odd that my reservation was "cancelled" and they are over booked all at the same time.  Now I am left hanging with only a couple days before my anniversary trying to scramble to find a place.Pros:+ great views of city and riverfront + convenient location in heart of downtown+ easy access to People Mover Public transit+ plenty of on site options for dining+ meeting rooms are variety of sizes and great with technology+ beautiful fitness facility overlooking river cons:- very confusing to navigate. Once you're on floor three or higher, you're set though- shops and restaurants seem to be targeted more at employees of GM in the complex (only open Monday- Friday business hours)- rooms on floors 40 below are not renovated and are quite dated (as of May 2014)- you have to pay for Internet ($13-16 per day) and the basic package isn't very fastAs a newcomer to Detroit from Boston, I've not stayed at the Detroit Marriott at the Ren Cen, but am disappointed in the utter lack of response from their Sales Office regarding a block of rooms for an upcoming event. Not only did I submit a form online via their website nearly two weeks ago [read: using THEIR intake process!], but placed a call and left a voicemail, to no avail. Absolutely no response. As someone who has planned many personal and professional events, I am shocked by this Marriott's inability to respond to potential customers' needs in a punctual, professional manner, which doesn't bode well for a good stay to say the least. I'll be sure to recommend other establishments, of which there are many with much higher standards, to friends and colleagues planning events, or to friends visiting from out of town.This hotel is housed in the GM headquarters building in downtown Detroit. It is a total of 70 floors. My room was on the 18th floor. You can valet at the hotel or self park in the deck right across the street (which is the same place where the valet takes your car but charges you more money). Within this huge GM building, there are various retailers, a CVS, a food court, a full movie theatre, and a few restaurants. You can also catch the people mover train (which I didn't do). There are probably more things in it that i dont know about  The hotel sits right on the Detroit River so it is easy access to the Detroit Riverwalk. You can see across the river to Windsor, Canada and the hotel sits right next to the tunnel to go across the border. There were about 2-3 weddings going on the weekend I was there and it didn't seem like the hotel missed a beat, nobody was going crazy behind the counter. I'm not sure if this is the only hotel (other than casino hotels) that is decent to stay at, but I would probably lodge here again. It's safe.
review_content_60: BEDBUGS.  We stayed there June 12 to 19.  Our first night revealed bedbugs in one of the beds.  We tried to find another place to stay, but couldn't.  Marriott gave us one nights free stay and $50 in restaurant food.  Oh, and they ran all of our clothes and suitcases through their industrial dryer so we wouldn't infect another room.  Ruined my handbag.  Nightmare scenario.  The only reason I didn't give them  one star is because the employees at this hotel are super, duper nice.  I wish them well, but never, ever, ever will I ever stay at this hotel again.Ok rooms with a view if you're lucky. Terrible service. Let's face it; the average person in Detroit is lazier than the average person in Dallas, LA, Chicago, DC, Atlanta, San Fran or other places. We had a problem with the doorman; we had a problem with valet; we had a problem with the desk clerk (chose people out of line ahead of us, for not apparent reason other than color) and we had terrible experience as the bar downstairs. Can this really be harder to get a beer than it is in the Gingerman in Manhattan?  I can get to the bar, but no service. Also, no bar in the room. Not even water. This place is kind of like a glorified La Quinta.Hotel Stay for July 11th and 12th, 2014. First off I would like to focus on a couple of areas that has triggered the Detroit Marriott at Renaissance Center to be an awesome establishment. Those areas are the views, location and guest services. From the time I walked in my mouth dropped. This hotel was massive with beauty. Not only were the river views breathtaking but the architectural designs gave phenomenal elements. Location location location, what else can I say. Well positioned in the heart of downtown Detroit. This Marriott property allows you to leave your car and venture out.  As many mentioned before it is really easy to get around on foot and is safe to a degree but every big city has safety precautions. The valet parking was hectic because there was a lot going on, but well organized with a kiosk and a visual on your car process. I wish they had a parking garage near that gave in and out privileges for a flat fee because this could eliminate the valet congestion and help those who just like having their car keys.  Yes the hotel is massive but if you are paying attention its easy to explore. Just remember,  from the first floor lobby just take elevator to 3rd floor and from there you will have the elevators to access your room floor. The building is a full circle so its hard to get lost. As other reviews mentioned, within this Marriott there are many eating options that will fit your budget also shops.  Now for the good ole nightlife. I was there during the weekend and I all have to say is wow. Crossing over to Beaubien Street to the strip and yes walking, was easy and amazing. From casinos to dive bars, this was nightlife heaven. So if you are traveling solo and looking for an adventure this hotel should be your one stop shop. Even if you are looking to tour the city by car, the 75 freeway is right at your doorstep. Tylisa Jones was my first point of contact. She was amazing with stellar professional qualities. From there the staff, concierge, and security was a delight and well informed on their surroundings. This property will be my Detroit go to.The worst hotel experience I've ever had. It took an hour to park anywhere near the hotel. When I attempted to check in at 3:00, after waiting in line for almost an hour, I was told that the hotel had been overbooked and they did not have a room available. The room had been reserved for over 2 months. They offered to put us in a different hotel 30 minutes away in another town. There was never an apology, never a word from a manager, despite requesting several times both in person and on the phone that I be able to speak to someone. For $189 a night one would think you could at least rely on decent customer service, but that was not the case here. It was a horrible experience from beginning to end.We stayed at this hotel prior to the Detroit Free Press Marathon. The staff was friendly and the recently remodeled room was clean and appealing. My only complaint is that the hotel's Starbucks closes at 12 on Saturdays.  The Ren Cen makes staying here a unique Detroit experience.I really wasn't thrilled by the Marriott at the Ren Center.First, it's obvious the property is older and the rooms have not been updated.  The rugs and furnishings were definitely older than other Marriotts that I've stayed at.There was an obvious stain on the sheets in the CENTER of the bed when we pulled them back.... why would you make the bed and hope no one saw that?  They responded quickly to our call, though, and remade the bed.The bathroom was tight --hard to open the door and get access to the tub.  They also only supplied 2 towels for the 2 people in the room, so we had to call for extras (personally, I use 2 just myself because of my long hair!).Our view was very nice of the Detroit River looking out to Canada, however.My biggest concern with the Marriott is that my grandmother requested a handicapped room.  They gave her a non-accessible room at first and then moved her down to one that she could use.  When she was seated after a shower on the handicap seat in the bathroom, it COLLAPSED because there were screws loose.  My grandfather couldn't lift her up, and so they had to call EMS.  It turned out that one of the loose screws cut her leg and they had to do wound care.  Yes, the Marriott apologized and took pictures/offered them a free breakfast, but they should have offered to remove the first night's fee from her bill.  (Which they did when I went downstairs to speak with a manager.)Again, I feel like the accident was a result of this being a older property and there not being regular upkeep.  Not sure if I'd stay here again.It SHOULD be noted that the lobby bar serves food until 1am, though, and that was awesome.  I was pretty pleased with their drink options and the plentiful seating.Hotel is significantly understaffed.  They advertise (even in the elevator) that they can accommodate up to 2200 but at our convention, it was clear they weren't able to do so.  Our convention was just starting, only 40% of the attendees had arrived, and the hotel was already ill prepared.Took 25 minutes to check in.  Not enough staff at checkin.  Hotel is very confusing to navigate.  It would help if they provided details at checkin of all thats available in the hotel AND added better signage around the hotel to direct guests.But where they really fail is housekeeping.1) Housekeeping deserves 0 stars.  My first thought was that they were lazy but they, too, are probably understaffed and being pushed beyond what's possible.  With that said, I'd quit before I allowed my work ethic to be compromised to this degree.  The lack of cleaning is unacceptable.We checked into a room that had:- urine on the toilet- hair all over the bathroom floor- food and drink spills remained on the office desk - phones were super dirty - dust caked on...all from previous guest.Called housekeeping.  They came and cleaned half of the items - toilet and food.  Left hair.  Called again.  Brought towels.  Didn't clean the hair.  Hmmm??  Called 3rd time.  Someone finally came and swept floor as we watched.2) Next day - arrived back to room and noticed that bed had been made but sheets hadn't been changed.  There was a suspicious yellow stain on sheet night before.  Stain still there.  Obviously sheets weren't cleaned.  Too late to complain.3) Day 2 - returned to room.  Trash remained on floor and in receptacles.  Beds were half made - pillows weren't in right place.  Sheet was bunched under comforter.  Bed skirt was caught in comforter.   Sheets were not changed and yellow stain remained.Called housekeeping.  Always very friendly but the horrible level of service and lack of attention to detail was unreal.Other members of our party also complained of dirty rooms.  Some arrived to trash in their room, upon checkin!  Hotel is nice, in theory.   The staff again is always pleasant but the hotel needs attention to detail and not just pleasantries.I recently stayed here on business. The staff were great which is why I'm giving it 3 stars. The room service breakfast was terrible. I had a bagel which was so rubbery. The fruit cup was decent. I realized I forgot a toiletry item and needed an OTC medicine. I went to the CVS in the hotel which was closed by the time I got there. So I went to the gift shop. I expected to pay a premium as it is a hotel gift shop and not somewhere you'd normally buy shampoo. The prices were beyond outrageous. I think they're taking advantage of the fact people are there on business and have expense accounts and also that people may be leery of wandering around Detroit. I also think that WI Fi wasn't free is also unreasonable. Again, taking advantage of expense accounts.Had a nice time at the Marriott Detroit, room was clean, beautiful view, people mover right there although on a beautiful day great to walk to comerica park! Cocktails and appetizers at the hotel Volt lounge after the game...perfect!I thought the Renaissance Center Marriott was super nice.  Goods and bads:Goods: Right on the People Mover line, on the river and in the Ren Cen.  Wow.Rooms were nice and spacious.  Nice decor.  Updated.  Comfy beds.Nice staff.  People were super friendly - being from Detroit I know that the friendly thing is a challenge - so this was a nice surprise.Relatively cheap.  You can stay at the casino for more money, but why?  This place is nice.Bads: Super confusing to get around.  We wandered in circles looking for the People Mover.  The signage makes it worse.Elevators can be very busy.  The good news is they are seperate for lower and upper floors to eliminate really lengthy lines.  But put your bag down so your shoulder doesn't seperate while you wait.Bar is super expensive.  I understand that is the norm in the hotel bar scene, but the pricing is really high.When they get busy, the valet gets crazy unorganized.  And they charge for the high floors because of the "view".  Get over it.Overall I loved it.  Maybe it is cause it was my bday and it was a surprise, but I thought it was a nice one.Meh....got a "cheap" rate on a package for a Spacing Trip....Plus: right on the People Mover which gets you where you need to go for 75 cents- the comfiest bed EVER- minus -- time wasted trying to resolve the totally unintuitive layout and multiple levels with escalators hidden in dark corners. I'd air bnb it next time. This place feels like the borg: just getting outside is a major undertaking. And wi-fi for $15/day, have we also rocketed back to 2003?Great view, ideal location, very nice room, but absolutely the worst conference food ever. In addition they over booked our groups room and it took over two hours to get the mess straighten out.  Seriously, the food was awful, bland and not served at correct temperatures. This was the general consensus of many attendees in our group. Take that into consideration with your budget.Although it is a nice hotel, guest services is not accommodating and downright unhelpful to their guests. I had the misfortune of visiting on a busy weekend, and I was met with a rude staff and absurd "procedures" that made no sense to me. I do not recommend this hotel.Not quite sure about the hotel rooms because I live close to the ren cen, but the bar at the Marriott is amazing. The hotel is huge and the deck outside of the bar is so relaxing. On a hot day it is nice to just have a double vodka while over looking the riverwalk and Canada. Bartenders are nice but sometimes people have events and throw weddings on the huge balcony which can be extremely crowded.Not sure what so many people are complaining about. The service here is really casual, but still extremely helpful. The views are even better. Was here with a friend on the 29th floor, and we had a view of the waterfront, the Ambassador, and the US-Canada tunnel. Stunning stuff. The tv checks you out, and the amenities are pretty decent. They also host a numerous amount of events, including the car show this weekend, which coincided with the Detroit Marathon, which I did with my friend. The beds are a little too soft, and the elevators whoosh on by, sometimes leaving you woozy in the head, but hey, there are 70 floors; they kind of need to move quickly. Here's what I learned from my stay here and in the Detroit area: people are just really nice, whether or not they work for the Marriott (but people who work in the Marriott are particularly kind).We came down for the night to have a nice dinner then attend a concert. We chose the Marriot for the view and because of it's reputation. We were not impressed. The view of the river was great, but the quality of the room was not worth the $275 that we paid.  The check in process took 2 1/2 hours which caused us to miss dinner as we had to go straight to our concert. Management was very rude and kept blaming the long wait time on guests. They wanted guests to split up and wait on the patio or in the lounge while the other checks in. It was highly disappointing!The view facing the river can't be beat. They are finally remodeling some of the rooms. It is much better but they should have gotten better beds. They seem just as old and sway as always.I loved this hotel! Stayed here on my wedding night and it was both private and had a good sized king bed. Our room overlooked the Detroit river and out into Windsor. I am a Quicken Loans team member so I was able to get a discounted rate which might explain why I loved he hotel so much. Cheaper rates always skew emotions. They were able to accommodate my wife and her down allergy which made the world to us. We don't feel like there was anything to shoot down about Tue hotel. Valet was quick and luggage was speedy. Check in and check out were painless as well as the front desk was personable. We will definitely stay here again! I also love the RenCen and enjoy being in downtown Detroit as it is. I have had the food before so I know it's good and would probably order room service next time. Overall a great night and great room.Drunk high school kids running through the hallways, puking in elevators and generally being annoying. No security or control. This hotel is not for business travelers.If I could give the hotel zero stars, that's what this hotel would receive. I'm so disappointed in this hotel that carries the Marriott name. From the time I checked in , the service has been horrible. I felt like they were very unprepared to host our convention.  I booked my room in March for an August convention. I should have had 2 double beds in the room, but there was only 1 king size. I should have been told that at check-in but instead I got that surprise when I opened the door. When I asked about switching rooms I was told none would be available until Saturday.  However, on Friday when I asked again suddenly they already had a room available (mind you, I had already called corporate the night before) but I felt like had I not came to the front desk, I would have never known about it. The "managers" were rude. When I inquired about getting a refrigerator in the room I was told they would send one right up. After an hour, I called back to check on the status & explained that there was medicine that needed to be refrigerated & was told by the "manager" Cory, "well you should not have bought that!" I was appalled at this response.  If I were speaking to her rudely or acting in any way irate or irrational,  I would be able to understand her defensive & extremely rude behavior,  but since I never once raised my voice & was never rude to her, I could not understand her treatment to a customer that was spending $500 to stay in this hotel. The saga continued since the whole weekend went by and the room was never cleaned, the trash cans were never emptied, clean towels that were requested were never brought. As I met with other people that were attending the convention I heard the same complaints over & over. I don't understand how someone can request toilet paper, towels, blankets, pillows, etc & never receive 1 requested item. This review doesn't reflect the entire staff because there were some courteous workers in the hotel but the rude ones I encountered unfortunately soured my experience for the entire hotel. On this day as I am preparing to check out, my mind is saying I will never spend my money at another Marriott hotel & I will pass my complaints on to the corporate office. Good customer service goes a long way & I am sad to say that this hotel is lacking in that big time. I have not even written about everything that has happened here this weekend.  For any employee that reads this review, I know you have a customer service acronym that you are supposed to use called "l-e-a-r-n". Please note that it needs to be put in practice, especially at times when you feel overwhelmed with your customers.
review_content_80: We stayed for the car show January 17th. When I made the reservation I was told check in was 3pm, which was when we arrived. The girl at the desk told me I was wrong and that check in was 4pm, but she would see if we could get early check in and someone would call us by 4. I wonder if they told the front desk to lie about check in time? I later found out from another employee that she was lying and check in was 3. By 5:30 pm still no call and we FINALLY got a room after I stood in line to talk to the desk again. We drove for 5 hours and had to stand around in the lobby all that time waiting. The lobby was filled with other people waiting so we could not even sit down while waiting. The next morning valet took an hour to bring my car. We lost 3 hours of time at the car show because we could not check into our room. Worst experience ever, I will never stay there again even though I will be returning to Detroit every year. I also emailed them and got no response.Hi Ami I spoke to someone from the hotel finally and they said check in is 3 lol.. Pretty weird to lie on here but ok.For the price, I think this place is slightly overrated.  There are a few restaurants onsite but as soon as you get offsite, you better make sure your wallet is in your front pocket.  The area downtown in Detroit is pretty sketchy.  The building is well designed however you can tell the hotel only upgraded certain features because the decor is not modern in all areas.  The gym (health club) was nice, I'm sorry that I didn't use it every night I stayed there, I only had the opportunity to use it once.  Would I stay there again?  Maybe but if you aren't meeting downtown or need to be downtown for your vist, I would recommend that you stay elsewhere.  There isn't much to see around this area.  At night, there is no nightlife and it reminds me of a cavernous maze at night.  During the day there are tons of people since there are lots of offices including GM.Oh yeah, and the Wifi sucks here.WOW!  The view from our room here in early January was breathtaking!  A snowstorm came through overnight that was incredible from our vantage point...an all around wonderful time! :-)Great service. I cannot speak enough about how well the staff here treated me. They were extremely accommodating and helpful for the proposal of my now fiance. I had booked a room, utilizing the romantic views overlooking Detroit city, the river and Canada as my backdrop. I had checked into the room earlier in the day to sex it up with rose petals, (electric) candles, champagne and various photos of us throughout our lengthy relationship. I returned downstairs to the front desk with an odd request. I returned them my room key and asked if they could check me in again later that evening as if I have never been there before. The key to surprising my lover was placed in the acting abilities of the front desk staff. To my delight, the plan was executed beautifully. That night, I was greeted at the front desk and asked if I have ever been to the Detroit Marriot before, which I slyly replied with a "no." They went through all the motions of checking in, asking for my credit card and ID. My fiance didn't suspect a thing. Upon arrival to our romanticified room, she was definitely surprised by the gorgeous views and the lovely decorations. However, her face was completely melted when I got down on one knee and pulled a sparkling ring out of my pocket....Later when I returned to the lobby to thank them for their assistance, I learned they had placed post-it notes on every computer to keep an eye out for my return. The staff here definitely went the extra mile for me to pull off my proposal that night. I would not hesitate to stay here again!Oh yeah, and she did yes.I've stayed in many Marriott's around the world & this was not as impressive for the price that we are paying. The rooms are small and outdated in furniture & designs. We have a great view of the river & west part of the City. The hotel is connected to the GM buildings & it's a maze going from one level to the next trying to get to places within the building. It's literally right next to Hart Plaza for those attending Movement Music Festival which makes it awesome to get to.Had to stay here on business and thought it was fine.  The check in service was great.  Their beds were comfy too.I will also give them kudos for decent catering.  Not only was the food edible but also tasty.  Had no problems with service during my stay.I've stayed at this hotel over a dozen times for about a decade. It was pretty much my preferred hotel in Detroit. I stopped staying here after a couple of bad experiences and have stopped going to Marriott hotels altogether.Prior to these bad experiences, I thought this hotel was OK (probably three stars out of five). The rooms were pretty good, the beds comfortable, and the bar and restaurant are alright, though not spectacular. The main appeal was the views of the Detroit River, Canada, and the city of Detroit, depending on what side of the hotel you're on. But I did have some gripes about the place. 1) Parking is kind of a pain because you have to park in the garage to the east, then walk through the Renaissance complex to get to the hotel. 2) It's a bubble, i.e., if you stay in the hotel and don't venture very far from there, you won't get to experience many of the terrific things about the greater downtown and midtown areas, much less the rest of the city. But then I had a couple of bad experiences. The first bad experience occurred during a longish stay. I actually reserved and paid for two rooms: one for me and another for a colleague. The front desk screwed up my Marriott Rewards number, so the points didn't register on my account. So instead of accumulating points for a four-night stay for two rooms, I got no points. After I tried to rectify the situation by faxing my receipt and claim to Marriott, then calling a couple of times to follow up, I got no response then gave up in frustration.. The second bad experience was way worse. I checked in and the room appeared to be ready, because the bed was made. But when I checked the bathroom, the toilet hadn't been flushed and there was hair all over the bathtub--and who knows what else. When I asked for a new room, I was told that the hotel was fully booked. They weren't able to send housekeeping quickly because I checked in so late. The front desk person very helpfully encouraged me to just flush the toilet. Unfortunately, I had to sleep in that room that night. The next day, I switched to another hotel: the Inn on Ferry Street, which is now hands down my favorite place to stay in Detroit, and probably my favorite in the whole darn U.S. It's just a delightful bed and breakfast consisting of old Victorian mansions. When rooms aren't available there, I stay at the Westin Book Cadillac, which is also very good. So I guess I should be grateful for my horrible experience at the Marriott because it led me to explore other, better hotels in Detroit and now I'm much happier for it. I haven't stayed in a Marriott since, because 1) in Detroit, I like the Inn or the Westin better and 2) in other cities, I can usually stay at another Westin or other SPG hotel. It doesn't make any sense for me to accumulate Marriott Rewards points anymore. That was two years ago. Farewell, Marriott.My favorite Marriott ever! This hotel rocks. I've been coming to Detroit all of my life because of family but never stayed in hotels until recently.The staff was awesome. There were several conferences going on as well as regular guests and their professionalism never wavered. Even if there were a problem, like a mix up with my car in valet or not satisfied with the meal at the restaurant, I was quickly compensated and taken care of.I so love the GM cars on display in the lower level and our view of Canada was fabulous. Even though I was visiting for a funeral, the ease and comfort of this hotel made my visit easier.We stayed at the Marriott Renaissance Center for 4 nights, leaving on a Sunday morning.We stayed on the 60th floor facing the river and the view was tremendous.  My wife said during check-in the staff took extra time to find us a room with a nice view.  We were paying $125 per night (rate tied to wedding reception package).Rooms were clean and nicely furnished, with room to move around.My son (the groom) had a very nice "junior" suite for Saturday night after the wedding reception.  It was very spacious, had great views and lots of sitting area.The only place we ate in the hotel was the 42 Degrees Restaurant (breakfast only). They offered a buffet with the usual fruits, cereals, etc., and hot hash browns, French toast, sausage, etc.  They also had excellent chefs cooking omelets / eggs to order, and it didn't take too long.  The staff was friendly but it can be a bit slow when they are busy, but no too bad.We used the Marriott to host / cater the wedding reception.  They did a very good job, providing snappy bar service and plenty of wait staff.  The food was quite good.  There were cheeses and crackers, meatballs, etc. early, followed by breads and salad.  The main entree was a baked chicken with a delicious sauce, and veggies, complimented by a rice side that was great.  They also provided the wedding cake, which was nicely sized for the wedding party (110) and tasted great.All-in-all, I give high marks for the wedding reception.Down sides to this location are:- wifi costs $12.95 per day for use in the guest rooms, but was pretty speedy at least.- the the entrance you drive to valet or drop off is difficult to get to...you have to go around the north side of the building (which is also GM headquarters!) then circle back toward the river and back south.  Quite confusing the first time you do it.  Use this address in GPS to get to the hotel entrance:400 Renaissance Dr NDetroit Michigan 48243United StatesValet staff seemed a bit disorganized at times, and the price for parking is high - $20/day to park yourself, or $25/day for valet.- elevators were another problem.  You have to use your room card to go to guest floors, which is fine, but the card readers often did not work.  During our 4 days there we had several occasions where a group of people got stuck riding up and down the elevators because the card readers did not allow selection of the proper floors.  I saw some elderly folks we tried to help having a very difficult time.  This needs to be seriously looked at.- hotel operators - we never had a problem when in the hotel, but several times we were away from the hotel and called the main number and it just rang rang rang - for 10 minutes straight once.  I had to call numerous times to finally get someone to answer.  This was a problem because speaking to a person was the only way to get connected, since there was no auto-attendant to allow self direction of the call.I would stay at this property again.Just a so-so Marriott but very convenient if you are needing to be close to GM-Land. The rooms are a little dated, supposedly they are remodeling it next year- they need to. The gym is decent but no hot tub or pool. The heating system is old and loud. Room service was pretty good though.Here goes: At check-in we found out they did not have a refrigerator or a microwave available for us. As a matter of fact, they did not have microwaves at all. We get to our room and there was no chair (or bench). After they brought the chair we realized the safe had been left locked by the previous guest and had to call guest services back. They sent up security then an engineer. They left our room at approximately 4:30 am. When I got ready to leave to attend my meetings later that day the safe would not lock. Of course, I had to call guest services again. I waited over an hour and a half for security then engineering to come up. They finally showed up and I put my things in the safe only to return later that night to find I could open the safe to retrieve my belongings. Again (3rd) time waiting for security! Needless to say, we could not use the safe our entire stay. Over the course of our 7 night stay, the housekeeping staff half cleaned our room every day. They left dirty dishes, trash and did not wipe down anything, did not change the linen, vacuum or leave clean towels on several days. My comforter was not even in the duvet. The duvet was just laying on top of it! We were advised by the housekeepers that they were out of towels. Day 3 after returning to our room at 10 pm from all day meetings the room was not cleaned at all! I did call guest services and they sent a young lady up to service the room. This was inconvenient due to us being tired and needing to rest! When the Concierge is rude to two elderly ladies needing help, you know you have a problem. Guest Services employees were hard to reach and when you did reach them they were rude. Even hanging up the phone on me. I patronized Volt on several evenings. The wait was unacceptable and my order was incorrect each time which made me have to wait even longer. To make matters worse they were also rude. I also patronized the seafood restaurant and the service was unacceptable there as well.  Our stay was a total of 7 nights and it was disappointing to say the least. Several of our conference attendees had similar unsatisfactory experiences during their stay as well. Including being locked out of the room each time they would leave the hotel. Waiting over an hour and a half to get in the room because they were advised that someone was coming up when no one was ever dispatched to the room. The noise was high due to remodel and thin windows (I guess). I was attending a very large convention and it seemed that Marriott Renaissance Center was not  equipped or prepared for a convention such as ours. I could go on and on about this experience  however I will end my review here by saying, I am definitely writing a letter to Marriott's Corporate Offices!  2 stars, 1 for convenience and 1 for the remodeled room with a view (my stay was in August).I can only presume that this hotel suffers from being in a city that's still in the throes of a major economic collapse. The hotel, itself is still pretty decent - meets most of the standards you expect from a Marriott. Being in one of the tallest buildings in the city, the views from the upper rooms were spectacular. That said, given how much of a ghost-town downtown Detroit has become, there wasn't much to do in or near the hotel. Even though it sits in a commerce center, everything closes extraordinarily early.One MAJOR WARNING: if you're expecting to do business elsewhere in Detroit and think that you can get away with not having a car, you would be sorely mistaken. When we went to catch a cab, Sunday afternoon, to catch our transportation, it quite literally took over 25 minutes for them to find a cab for us. Every other Marriott I've stayed at in the US and Europe, there's always at least a couple cabs waiting to pick up passengers. Not only were there no such cabs waiting nearby, the hotel didn't have any kind of immediate-dispatch arrangements made with any of the Detroit cab companies. Nor do they offer shuttle service to make up for this lack. Eventually, the bell-stand guy was able to call an off-duty buddy of his to do an off-meter run. That guy was very solicitous, but resorting to a gypsy cab to transit through an economically destroyed area is an exercise in faith that I was very uncomfortable making. Obviously, we made it home and *just barely* made it to our transport (really glad I'd padded our travel schedule to account for these kinds of snafus)I'll be writing a letter of disappointment to Marriott Corporate when I have time to compose something civil.Nice place, but walking to your room can take a bit.I had to stay a bit to pickup my family as they came down for their luggage.  No hassles from the valets or hotel staff even though it was about 1/2 hr.When I saw some of the reviews I almost didn't go to this hotel but I'm glad I did. I stayed at this hotel last weekend and was impressed. The front desk staff was very friendly, courteous and accommodating. The room was clean and looked just like the photos. The view from our room on the 37th floor was amazing, overlooking the river showing the Ceaser's casino in Windsor. The bed was comfy. The hotel is close to Hart Plaza, Greek town, restaurants and other downtown sites so we walked everywhere. The only downer was that the walls were thin. I could hear people's conversations in the hallways. Also valet parking was a little expensive at $25 a day but most downtown hotels do have expensive parking so that was no surprise. This hotel has all the bells and whistles like room service, a restaurant, rooms with a great view and good customer service. I would definitely go back. I think either the hotel has improved  over time or the other reviewers are just a bunch of debbie downers.We stayed at this Marriott last weekend for a wedding that was held at the Detroit Yacht Club on Belle Isle.  Several family members stayed at this location so we were able to check out multiple rooms.  The views from the higher rooms are really spectacular due to the floor to ceiling windows!  The hotel is clean and rooms well appointed.  Staff members were as helpful as you need them to be.  We weren't sure where to park when we arrived so we ended up using the valet parking service which was $25 per day.  There is a touchscreen valet kiosk near the front desk when you're ready to retrieve your car and want to bypass the desk.  This hotel is in walking/ driving distance to many of Detroit's downtown attractions.   Anyone staying at this location should take caution and be aware of Detroit's many potential "challenges".  On our way back from the wedding there was a shooting directly in front of our hotel which made getting back to our room a bit of a task...to put it mildly.  After ducking and running into the hotel, we headed straight to the Volt for cocktails and snacks.  The following day we all agreed that the black-out curtains over the gimongous windows happened to be the pinnacle of room features at this Detroit Marriott.The Bad & Ugly:  Outrageous valet parking charge per day.  Even just parking yourself in their lot will put you back the cost of a decent lunch.  And what the heck conference was in town that weekend, with people dressed all in white laying around on the floor?  Huge, impersonal hotel.The Good:  UPGRADE!  I used hotel points to stay here for our anniversary... and when we checked in they directed us one of the elevators that takes you to the top floors.  Sweeeeeeet suite!  Floor to ceiling windows, view of the river, two, count 'em two bathrooms.  Followed by a knock at the door and complimentary chocolate covered strawberries to help us celebrate.Now, I travel a fair bit for work (and I love me some Marriott), but I've never ever gotten this nice of a perk.  Maybe it was all due to the wonderful woman who took my reservation, or maybe the place is just awesome.  I'm afraid to book there again though - how can our stay be topped?I found my stay at the DR-Marriott to be quite nice.First we were greeted by a very friendly valet and doorman.  Both smiled nicely and the doorman gave us directions for check-in, without being asked.  Just a lovely, "Welcome to the Detroit Marriott -- please take the elevators to the third floor and exit to the left for check-in services" -- I mean how wonderful!We arrived in the check in lobby and waited all of 15 seconds before a lovely smiling girl offered to assist us.  We walked up and she politely checked us in.  My boyfriend asked for a nice view and she obliged w/ no hesitation.  We took the elevator to the 67th floor where we had a river view.  Our room was clean and spacious -- the king size bed over-adorned in fluffy pillows.We went to the Volt bar before our wedding, which is the hotel bar located on the third floor.  I found the prices to be reasonable for a hotel bar ($9 for house wine).Our bed was super comfy.  The only downside was the towels -- they skimp on how many they give you.  I know hotels are trying the "go green" approach, but at the end of the day, all women use two towels and men at least one -- so please put three large towels in a room.Great stay though!Cheerful service and attention. I was pleasantly surprised. Nice double queen room, quiet and efficiently run. I had a bathroom light go out. Within 15 minutes of my calling, a maintenance man tapped on my door and changed it. Lots of levels you have to get used to when entering and exiting. Security quiet and comfortable. I think the staff is great. The hotel looks out on 'The Riverwalk' good for runs and enjoying the view. Bike rental around the corner.DO NOT USE THE VALET.They tell you to call down 10 minutes before you want to get your car.  I did.  But NO ONE ANSWERED.  Tried several times.  Took 10-15 minutes before I got ahold of anyone, and I ordered my car.  Then I got down to the curb, and waited forever for my car.  Never came.  I ended up having to jump in  cab to make my morning meeting, and I had to come all the way back to the hotel to pick up my car, before rushing out for a flight.I called the hotel and the valet company to get the charge removed.  The hotel said they couldn't do anything, and that I had to talk to the valet service, as it's a completely different company.  I called the valet company, and they've flat out refused, saying that I should have talked to the manager immediately... which would have made me miss either my meeting or my flight.Terrible service.  Avoid this hotel.I recently attended YoumaCon here at the rencen, and while the building was impressive, it's complexity detracted from the event. First off, the meeting space is on the lower lobby floors, 3-5 I believe. That's great and everything is connected by escalator. However, want to go to your hotel room? Our room was on the 48th floor, so no stairway, no how. This turned into an epic fail by about 10am friday for the rest of the weekend, as there was no way the 6 elevators could keep up with the massive demand.Kudos to the hotel, as a "mystery fridge" appeared in our room sometime Friday afternoon, we didn't ask for it, didn't pay for it, but boy did we use it.Tried the starbucks, but not the hotel's food, but who would with the ren cen attached.Rooms were clean, bathroom was smaaaaaaaaaaall. Otherwise ok.
